DOC.HEAD: Cuban Medics in Bluefields Face Uncertain Future
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The Caribbean moon casts a silvery light that is kind to the shabby streets and crooked docks of this steamy port town on the Miskito Coast. The doctors who set Bluefields' broken bones and deliver its babies gather on a porch, catching the breeze, catching their breath, waiting for dinner. They are the Cuban medical brigade, 15 idealistic envoys of a revolution becoming isolated and stale because of changes sweeping the rest of the communist world. Suddenly, they don't know where they stand. Change has hit Nicaragua, ousting President Daniel Ortega's leftist Sandinistas, one of Cuba's only remaining allies. Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's new government will be conservative and pro-American. Will it ask them to stay? Will Cuban President Fidel Castro let them remain to taste post-revolutionary democracy? The story of the doctors and their compatriots in a 300-strong construction brigade here is a story of a community in need, hard-won acceptance, and the vagaries of politics. It began a decade ago, when Bluefields was torn by anti-Cuban riots. Today, many Bluefilenos dread the Cubans' departure. It would strip Nicaragua's isolated south Atlantic coast of its only surgeons, anesthesiologists, obstetricians and orthopedist. It would shatter the vision of a thousand sturdy new homes replacing shacks flattened by Hurricane Joan in 1988. ``It would be chaos,'' said Dr. Donald Weil, the Nicaraguan director of the Sandino Regional Hospital, where more than half the staff is Cuban. A few blocks away, the Cuban doctors gather around their communal dinner table, talking about work, about home, about what lies ahead. ``We'll be here as long as they want us,'' says Dr. Ernesto Diaz Trujillo, a 40-year-old intensive care specialist who is 11 months into his two-year tour. Bluefields got a taste of life without the Cubans when they stayed home in the tense days after the Feb. 25 election. ``They didn't want to come out on the street because they didn't know what would be happening,'' said Johnny Hodgson, a local Sandinista official. Things fell apart at the 118-bed hospital, which has only 12 Nicaraguan doctors. Some patients had to be sent to Managua, 190 miles west and reachable only by plane or boat. Most just had to wait. ``We couldn't handle it,'' Dr. Weil said. After two days, community leaders went to the Cubans and persuaded them to return to work, reassuring them they were not only safe, but desperately needed. The experience converted all but the most fervent anti-communists in Bluefields, Weil said. ``People changed colors like chameleons.'' Back at the Cuban residence, the table falls silent as the brigade's orthopedic surgeon shouts into the telephone, reassuring his mother back home in Cuba. ``No problems,'' he yells, jamming the receiver into one ear and his finger into the other so he can hear. ``Absolutely no problems.'' Their voices crossed only 800 miles, but it might as well have been 800,000. Nicaragua's Atlantic coast _ an enclave of mestizos, Miskito Indians, the descendants of British pirates and of African slaves _ is a universe away from both Havana and Managua. Anti-communism runs deep, a legacy of the region's ties to the Yankees who mined its gold, cut its lumber, fished its waters, and to the missionary fervor of the Moravians and the Capuchin priests who educated its children. ``I remember when I was studying in secondary school, we had to pray after every class,'' Hodgson recalled with a laugh. ``And if you didn't mention Cuba and communism in your prayers, it was as if you were not praying.'' Acceptance was a long time in coming for the Cubans, who began arriving in Nicaragua soon after the 1979 revolution. The people of the coast resented the Cuban teachers and their highly political curriculum. In September, 1980, anti-Cuban riots erupted when the government announced plans to send in more teachers. Thousands of people, mostly blacks, took to the streets. The government sent in the army to put down the riots, arrested hundreds of people and accused Bluefields of trying to launch a separatist movement. The teachers were eventually withdrawn; the doctors stayed, nearly irreplaceable because of the shortage of physicians in Nicaragua. But it took the fury of a Hurricane Joan on Oct. 21, 1988, to bridge the gulf between Bluefields and Castro's envoys. It was Cuba that arrived first with aid and was most generous. When Bluefilenos gathered the boards of 5,000 homes, scattered like matchsticks by 135 mph winds, there were Cubans by their side. The construction brigade has put up more than 100 of a planned 1,000 sturdy, prefabricated homes. The first residents began moving late last year into what is now the best neighborhood in town. ``This is the first time, with the construction of these houses, that the people of Bluefields really live with the Cubans, you know, walk with them and pass the whole day with them,'' Hodgson said. The construction brigade lives in a Cuban-built complex that will become a university after they leave. There are touches of home such as Cuban cigars, cigarettes and coffee. ``All of them has a girlfriend or boyfriend. They are courting,'' said Marvin Taylor, a local politician. At the former British diplomatic mission where the doctors live, dinner is over. The doctors head back to the porch, to the rocking chairs under the sign, to the lazy moonlight. Trujillo lingers for a moment, making a point about people and politics, about isolation and coexistence. ``If I drink red wine and you drink white,'' he says, holding a glass high, ``there is no reason we can't toast.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Becomes President ... Of What?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has once again shaken up the Soviet political system, this time to give himself even more power as the country's first Western-style president. But as Lithuania leads other small republics toward independence and Russia itself contemplates electing a chief executive, the question down the road for Gorbachev is: president of what? The Congress of People's Deputies, the Soviet Parliament, grumbled and complained more than usual, but Thursday acknowledged Gorbachev as the political master from Poland to the Bering Strait and Iran to the Arctic Circle. The area includes more than 100 nationalities and almost 300 million people. Gorbachev's moves early this year leading to his election appeared to complete a revolution of the political structure that even he until recently did not expect. In December he fought Andrei D. Sakharov to prevent the parliament from eliminating the Communist Party's guarantee of power, but two months later he led the fight to end it. His close Politburo adviser Alexander N. Yakovlev told an official newspaper that Gorbachev opposed a presidential form of government, and only recently came to believe it was needed to hold his country together. Gorbachev told parliament he intends to be president of all the people, including 3.7 million Lithuanians, whose leaders hastily declared independence before Gorbachev could gain his new powers. ``Our country is living through difficult times. But if we act energetically and as a team, we certainly will be able to overcome the difficulties,'' he said. ``The Russian people and all the peoples united with it in a great multinational state will succeed in reviving their common homeland, and will surely achieve that on the road of perestroika and socialist renewal.'' But his dealings with the wayward republics give little grounds for such optimism. When it declared independence, Lithuania changed its Soviet name and emblem, and activists report that one-third of its 15,000 potential draftees refused to show up this year for service in the Soviet Army. It announced plans to start setting up border checkpoints. On Friday, Gorbachev gave Lithuania until Monday to answer a parliament proclamation that the declaration of independence was invalid. Even as he assumed new powers that do not exclude direct presidential rule of an area, he was faced with the Lithuanian contagion spreading. ``The Soviet Union will have its president, and Estonia will move toward independence,'' said Endel Lippmaa, a leading deputy from the Lithuania's fellow Baltic republic of 1.6 million people. An unofficial Estonian Congress demanded that the Kremlin name the time that it would pull its soldiers out. Estonian government officials said they agreed. Latvia, the third Baltic republic, also is pushing for independence, and the Caucasus republic Georgia has demanded negotiations about restoring independence. Moldavians are looking more closely across the border to their ethnic brothers in Romania after the revolution there. Armenia and Azerbaijan, locked in a bloody territorial dispute, share a mutual antipathy for Gorbachev. All those republics make up only about 10 percent of the country's population. They were collected by the czarist empire, which broke up after the Bolshevik Revolution and then gradually gathered again by the Soviet Union. The Baltics were independent countries between the world wars and were the last to join the Soviet Union. They were absorbed by Josef Stalin in 1940. Central Asia, home to about one in five Soviets, increasingly has been wracked by ethnic violence, but so far there has been little talk of secession. But the long-slumbering Slavic heartland of Russia, the Ukraine and Byelorussia is showing signs of waking up. The three republics, which contain more than two-thirds of the country's people, held local elections March 4. Run-offs were required in most districts, but progressives appeared to do well, perhaps presaging drives for autonomy similar to those gripping the smaller republics. But the Rukh movement has gained a foothold in the Ukraine with its demands for more autonomy, and there are appeals for outright independence for the second-most populous republic. In Russia, nationalists say that it is the Russians themselves who have suffered the most from Soviet rule. Unlike other republics, Russia does not have its own capital, its own hymn or its own Communist Party structure. Nationalists are pressing people to think of themselves as Russians rather than Soviets. The Russian federation, by far the largest republic, already has decided to elect its own president. One of the announced candidates for the job is Gorbachev's populist nemesis, Boris N. Yeltsin. Yeltsin has nationwide popularity, and nationwide ambition. He said in Italy earlier this month that he would like to be Soviet president, if there were a popular vote. While Gorbachev has paid a price in popularity for his leadership over the past five years, Yeltsin has sniped at him for not moving faster and his popularity has twice translated into impressive electoral victories. In March 1989 he won almost 90 percent of the vote in sweeping a parliament seat from Moscow. Two weeks ago he outpolled more than 70 percent of the vote in his Ural Mountain hometown of Sverdlovsk in a race for a seat in the Russian federation Congress. It is that body that will choose the Russian president. If Gorbachev cannot hang on to the non-Slavic republics, there will be less and less difference between the territory of the Russian federation and the territory of the Soviet Union. The two chief executives almost certainly would find their interests and powers in conflict. Even without the 14 other republics, Russia would be a huge country _ but not necessarily big enough for two masters.
Mark J. Porubcansky has reported on the Gorbachev revolution from Moscow since February 1987.

Six Months After Storm, Slow Rebuilding Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
Eds: Harriett is cq in 8th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The clock on St. Michael's Episcopal Church is still missing its gold hands _ mute testimony to the 135 mph winds of Hurricane Hugo that passed this way six months ago. But just as yellow-green leaves have sprouted on trees stripped bare by leviathan winds, South Carolina is mending after the worst storm to batter its coast in centuries. Hugo smashed ashore at Charleston on Sept. 21, killing 29 people, leaving thousands temporarily homeless and thousands more without electricity for weeks. With damage estimated at $5.9 billion, it was most costly hurricane to ever hit the U.S. mainland. Now spring has come around. Horse-drawn carriages drift through downtown. Azaleas bloom behind wrought-iron fences. The historic district is cleared of debris and tourist attractions have long since reopened. But in outlying areas, on the sea islands northeast of town, and in Sumter, 90 miles inland, recovery has been slower, even as volunteers from across the nation continue to donate time, money and energy to help in the recovery. Leroy Miller, a Mennonite volunteer from Weatherford, Okla., who arrived in Charleston on Jan. 9, has helped replace roofs on 35 homes through the county's Raise the Roof program. There are still 200 people on a waiting list. ``People have a problem understanding why we would do this without pay,'' Miller said. ``I don't know what to tell them. It's just another way of reaching out to humanity.'' Among those he helped was Harriett Yates, who after the hurricane was forced to make do with a blue tarp to cover the roof of her tiny, five-room house. ``I appreciate it,'' she said. ``I couldn't have done it without them.'' On nearby Sullivans Island, which was home to 2,500 people, many buildings crushed in the 12-foot tidal surge that accompanied the hurricane still await the bulldozer's blade, and piles of hurricane-related debris await pickup. Julie Britt lost her home, but she moved into an apartment rather than leave the island. ``I have never felt a love of place as much as I love this place,'' she said. ``The way we deal with it is a blessed amnesia in which you don't remember how it looked before.'' On the Isle of Palms, where damage was estimated at $100 million, only about half the 3,500 residents have returned, and some never will. Mayor Carmen Bunch said many older residents already were pinched by rising living costs. Rebuilding continues slowly in hard-hit McClellanville, where the shrimping industry was decimated, and farther north in the resort community of Pawleys Island, which was cut in half by the hurricane's tidal surge. And in many poorer areas, jobs were lost when marginal businesses were forced to close because of storm damage and disruption. Marvin Lare, executive director of the South Carolina Institute on Poverty and Deprivation, said the storm could push more than 180,000 people in the state below the poverty level. In Charlotte, N.C., 200 miles inland, workers still are picking up tree limbs, brush and other debris at the rate of 32 truckloads a day, said Linda Sherrill, a spokeswoman for the city. Electrical crews continue to erect utility poles in a city that was left virtually powerless after the storm. The Charleston council approved a temporary 14 percent property tax increase to cover storm expenses and make up for declining collections. The Federal Emergency Management Agency distributed nearly $100 million to help individuals cover uninsured losses. But, as in any relief operation, there have been problems. FEMA spokesman Frank Mosco said about $500,000 was returned after the agency discovered people received money they were not entitled to. As many as 130 people who failed to respond to FEMA letters asking for repayments could face criminal charges, he said. In Carolina forests, crews are using tractors, helicopters and mule teams to clear thousands of splintered trees. An estimated 1 billion board feet of timber _ 4.4 million acres _ was toppled, a blow to the $4.3 billion-a-year industry. Larry Edmond of the U.S. Forest Service said crews hope to salvage at least 25 percent of the downed timber. An acre of forest normally has 3 tons to 20 tons of fuel in the form of fallen timber. Many spots of forest in the Carolinas have 200 to 1,000 tons per acre of drying debris, officials said. South Carolina's $5 billion tourism industry is gearing up amid optimism that business this summer will be as strong as ever. Myrtle Beach escaped the brunt of the storm and Hilton Head Island, another popular resort, was unscathed. Even with the storm, tourism rose 4 percent last year, the state tourism department says. Advertisements promoting the state make no mention of Hugo or the aftermath. But there are some who believe that such silence is unneeded, that articles about the state's recovery will be do nothing but help the economy. ``We've had so much additional exposure on Charleston in the positive sense,'' said Helen Stansell of the Charleston Trident Chamber of Commerce. ``South Carolina is going strong and coming back.''

DOC.HEAD: Foster Children Try to Sell Themselves At Easter Fashion Show
DOC.TEXT: Two sets of models waited to cross the stage for the spring fashion show in a New Orleans mall. The young beauties had been hired to sell clothes. The 12 nervous children hoped to sell themselves. The children were wards of the state who had volunteered for Saturday's Easter fashion show in hope that someone might see them and want to adopt them. ``We're going back in time,'' said Gloria Mitchell, who attended the fashion show at the Lakeside Mall. ``This is like slavery. We're auctioning off these kids.'' But officials from the state Department of Social Services said fashion shows, like the department's weekly television spots, help find something that's in short supply: families to adopt some of Louisiana's 5,000 foster children. Except for 1988, when officials objected to having the children shown along with cats and dogs from the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the department has used fashion shows as a chance to show some of these children in as good a light as possible. ``I would love to not have to do this,'' said Kerry Ermon, whose job is finding adoptive families in the New Orleans area. ``I would love it if we had more families than children, but that's not the reality.'' Only children who volunteer participate. The younger ones say they do it for fun. The older ones say they have to. ``I want to get a family,'' said Mark, 13, a veteran of the fashion shows and television spots. Since most people prefer to adopt infants, a child's hopes of adoption grow slimmer with every year. Television and fashion show appearances become more urgent _ especially for black children, for whom there are few potential families, Ermon said. Even the high-visibility events tend to attract more prospective white parents than black, Ermon said. She said it's a constant frustration for social workers that even white children who have severe emotional problems find homes more quickly than well-behaved black children. Black families in New Orleans adopt less often than white families, Ermon said, and white families rarely adopt black children. The recent fashion show brought that point squarely home. At a show at another mall a week ago, nine of the 12 children were black. On Saturday, seven of the eight children were black. Yet after the shows, almost all of the questions were about the white children. Linda Burvant, a court reporter, said she and her husband have been considering adoption. She said she didn't like to see the children made to feel uncomfortable, but the fashion show was her first chance to see some of the children in state custody. ``I would think in order to go up there they have to really want a home,'' she said. ``It's sad.''

DOC.HEAD: Billionaires Battle For Support As Voters Weigh Farm's Environmental Safety
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A battle over an experimental hog farm that pitted billionaire against billionaire will be decided by voters who will choose whether to require the farm to spend $10 million on a waste treatment plant. In effect, Weld County voters must judge Tuesday whether the Bass brothers of Fort Worth, Texas, have set up an operation using unproven methods that could pollute the water supply _ or whether such criticism is a smokescreen orchestrated by a rival tycoon who has other reasons for wanting the farm closed. ``It's very debilitating to be attacked for the very thing you think is very special,'' said Bill Haw, president of National Hog Farms. What Haw thinks is special is the hog farm built by his company 15 miles east of here along the South Platte River. Financial backers include four men on the Forbes magazine list of richest Americans: Texas brothers Robert, Sid, Lee and Edward Bass. In its October issue, the magazine estimated that Robert was worth $1.44 billion, Sid and Lee $1.25 billion each, and Edward $1 billion. But Philip Anschutz, owner of the Southern Pacific Transportation Co. and the subsidiary Denver & Rio Grande Railroad, doesn't think the hog farm is so special _ especially since his 32,000-acre Eagles's Nest Ranch is downstream from it. Forbes put Anschutz's worth at $1.25 billion, also chiefly from oil. The 25,750-acre farm, which began operating last year, plans to raise 300,000 pigs a year in a sterile environment that avoids use of antibiotics or other commonly used drugs. To get rid of the hog waste, the farm treats it and uses it to fertilize grassland used by grazing cattle. Haw calls it ``the most environmentally sound livestock operation in the world.'' Haw said Anschutz is just using the environmental issue as a ruse to try to acquire the land that National Farms now owns. Haw said the farm thwarted Anschutz's hopes of expanding his ranch, where he raises cattle and shoots wild game. ``I can't imagine what Mr. Anschutz expects to accomplish other than vengeance,'' Haw said. ``We're certainly not going to leave.'' Initially, Anschutz and Haw took the issue to court but now it is the voters who get to pass judgment. The farm's owners haven't said what they will do if the ordinance requiring the treatment plant is approved. Both sides have hired Denver public relations firms to press their arguments, and Anschutz founded and helped finance a citizens' group called Protect Our Water. A vote for the proposed ordinance, said Gretchen Cutts, a spokeswoman for the group, would send ``the right message to the right corporations and the right message to the wrong corporations that this is a community that cares about environmental concerns.'' But it isn't just the Anschutz-funded group that has raised environmental questions. At a hearing last week, JoAnn Silverstein, a University of Colorado civil engineering professor, said the farm's waste disposal process already may be increasing nitrate levels in ground water and in the South Platte River, and would undoubtedly do so further if the farm isn't forced to change its methods. Nitrates are dangerous to pregnant women and have been linked to ``blue baby syndrome,'' a potentially fatal disease in newborns caused by lack of oxygen in the blood, she said. At the same hearing, however, Weld County health director Randy Gordon called the fluctuations in nitrate levels normal and said there is no proof they are caused by the hog farm. Dan Luecke of the Environmental Defense Fund in Boulder agrees that opponents have a legitimate concern about nitrates from hog waste seeping into water. ``On a conceptual level, you could say spraying the waste water on farmland makes sense, but I have seen no data on the quality of the water going on the land,'' he said. While both sides expect to win, each also concedes that Weld County's 125,000 residents are probably confused about which way to vote. According to County Clerk Mary Ann Feuerstein, Protect Our Water spent $38,500 in campaigning through March 4. National Hog Farms has reported spending $5,600 up to that date, but Haw estimates his company will spend at least $70,000 before the campaigning is finished. Nonetheless, Beverly Cruz, bartender at the Scotch Pub in Greeley, said she hasn't heard any of her customers talk about the hog farm or the waste. ``Usually if it's something they're concerned about they will be talking about it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Governor's First Legislative Session Shows Cautious Approach
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Republicans who warned last fall that L. Douglas Wilder was a liberal hiding behind conservative rhetoric praised the nation's first black elected governor for his cautious approach in his first legislative session. Wilder opened the General Assembly session in January with a lecture on fiscal discipline, demanding that the legislature come up with a $200 million reserve fund for 1991-92. He ended the session by orchestrating a power play to repeal the sales tax on non-prescription drugs, a cause he has long championed. But for most of the session, Wilder took a hands-off approach, allowing the legislators to do their job. His style contrasted sharply with that of his predecessor, Gerald L. Baliles, who routinely had aides buttonholing legislators to lobby for his bills. Wilder said at a news conference on the last day of the session March 10 that he thought the lawmakers appreciated his approach. ``We know how to communicate, and we've been doing it a long time,'' said Wilder, who served 16 years in the Virginia Senate and four years as lieutenant governor. Wilder's style served him well. He got his reserve fund and the non-prescription drug tax repeal. Only four of the 119 bills proposed by his administration failed to pass, and legislators from both political parties went home happy. ``Governor Wilder in his budget restraint showed more of a Republican philosophy than we could have hoped for,'' said House Minority Leader Raymond R. Guest Jr. ``Baliles spent everything he could. Wilder is trying to get us back on track.'' Early in the session, Wilder endeared himself to Republican leaders by calling him into his office to brief them on his legislative agenda. ``We had more time with the governor today than we did the previous four years,'' Guest said at the time. Larry Sabato, a political analyst at the University of Virginia, said the approach was vintage Wilder: ``He's inclined to win groups that would not otherwise be allied to him.'' Sabato said the session was a good one for Wilder, whose historic election last November is viewed by many as the first step to national office. ``His agenda is in two parts,'' Sabato said. ``There's the Virginia part and there's the national part. The bottom line is he did well for both. He projected the image of being a fiscal conservative and a tax-cutter. Virginians are pleased, and it's a message he can sell to the national Democratic Party.'' With the exception of the money initiatives, Wilder did not have much of a legislative agenda. Sabato said that will surprise many national observers. ``Part of it is the race thing,'' he said. ``It's the belief that black governor equals activist governor. That's not necessarily so.'' Most of the 119 administration-proposed bills were not controversial. Just two were rejected outright, companion bills that would require state employees to pay part of their insurance costs. The other two, one addressing rules governing notaries, the other on unemployment compensation procedures, were tabled or withdrawn. Mark Rozell, a political analyst at Mary Washington College in Fredericksburg, Va., was more critical than Sabato. ``I don't think he's really had a coherent program, per se, that he has articulated,'' Rozell said. ``Part of that is derived from the budgetary crisis, which understandably places serious constraints on his ability to be a more activist governor. ``Nonetheless, there have been some issues on which Wilder could have taken a much more assertive leadership role. To that extent, his first session has not been very successful.'' Rozell criticized Wilder for failing to take a clear position on such issues as public smoking restrictions and admission of women to all-male Virginia Military Institute. The legislature passed a bill imposing modest statewide restrictions on smoking, once unthinkable in tobacco-producing Virginia. Wilder has said he's for reasonable smoking restrictions but hasn't said whether he will sign the bill. Another bill proposed by a legislator, to prohibit sex discrimination in public college admissions policies, was killed. Rozell said Wilder's late-session tax repeal victory ``demonstrates how effective a leader he can be should he decide to be more assertive.'' Wilder argued that the tax on non-prescription drugs, while not a large cost to the average household, was unfair in that it fell disproportionately on the elderly and poor. Sabato and most legislators liked the way Wilder distanced himself from the legislature. ``The governor doesn't have to get involved in every little squabble,'' Sabato said. ``He picked and chose his fights very carefully.'' ``Governor Wilder's big goal was to get the budget in shape,'' said Delegate Leslie L. Byrne, a Democrat. ``He trusts the legislative process, and he gave us a free hand to meet the goals. He wasn't intrusive.'' Delegate George Allen, a Republican, said he appreciated Wilder's silence on many controversial issues. ``The legislature was able to work its will,'' Allen said. ``They weren't having their arms twisted into doing things they didn't want to do.''

DOC.HEAD: The Case of Exxon Valdez Skipper Joseph Hazelwood Turns on Two Key Issues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: From its beginnings as a case of many issues, the trial of Exxon Valdez captain Joseph Hazelwood has come down to just two key questions: Was Hazelwood drunk, and was he reckless to leave the bridge just before his tanker grounded? Beyond the specifics that jurors will consider when they receive the case this week is the implicit question of whether the nation's largest oil spill was an accident or a crime. ``This was a maritime accident. Captain Hazelwood was not responsible for that accident,'' defense attorney Dick Madson told jurors in opening statements. He is expected to make a similar point when final arguments are presented Tuesday. ``The ultimate responsibility for the tanker is with the captain,'' said Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole in his opening statement. ``The most dangerous part of the journey was after Hazelwood absented himself from the bridge.'' Although many civil suits were filed after the grounding of the Exxon Valdez a year ago next Saturday, Hazelwood was the only member of the ship's crew charged criminally. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y. is accused of one felony, criminal mischief, and three misdemeanors _ reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, he could face 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. The tanker rammed a charted reef in Prince William Sound, spewing nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska North Slope crude oil, devastating fisheries and wildlife and fouling the rocky shoreline for hundreds of miles. Cole promised at the outset to prove Hazelwood was drunk and away from his appropriate post on the bridge during the most treacherous part of the tanker's voyage in Prince William Sound. But his claim that the sound was treacherous was disputed by tanker captains who testified for the defense. One called it ``a mill pond.'' Another said it was ``like navigating the Pacific Ocean. ... It was so wide open.'' Even the prosecution's last witness, a Texaco tanker captain, said the sound was not a particularly difficult area to navigate and was not crowded with the tanker traffic that often blocks other ports. As testimony piled up over six weeks, it became clear that headline-making reports of a drunken skipper were based on circumstantial evidence. Hazelwood was seen at a bar in the port city of Valdez the day his ship sailed. Witnesses reported that he drank vodka, but how much he drank and at what hour remained in dispute. Three witnesses said they smelled alcohol on the skipper's breath that night. But not a single witness described Hazelwood as appearing drunk. No one saw him stagger. No one heard him slur his words. Crew members said he negotiated a precarious gangway without missing a step. They called him cool, calm and in command before and after the grounding. The question of inebriation was muddled because authorities failed to do a timely blood test. Hazelwood wasn't tested until 10{ hours after the disaster, making the results a dubious gauge of his condition at the crucial hour. The prosecution called an expert witness to ``calculate backwards'' and figure from Hazelwood's .061 blood alcohol reading at 10:30 a.m. what the level might have been the midnight before. The expert said Hazelwood would have been drunk with a reading of perhaps .14. But defense experts said the calculation method was ``nonsense'' and involved too many variables including whether Hazelwood had something to drink aboard ship after the grounding. Hazelwood, who did not testify in his own defense, never explained. Neither did he say why he left the bridge in control of a third mate and went below during the transit in icy conditions. The third mate, Gregory Cousins, tesified that Hazelwood discussed with him a navigational plan to leave the shipping lanes, maneuver around ice floes, and return to the shipping lanes. ``He asked if I felt comfortable with what we were going to do and I said, `Yes,''' recalled Cousins. ``He said, `Do you feel comfortable enough that I can go below and get rid of some paperwork? I said I felt very comfortable.''' Cousins did not hold the special Coast Guard pilotage endorsement for Prince William Sound, a technicality which has been magnified during the trial. Hazelwood was the only officer with the special license. The defense suggested that the Coast Guard may have waived the pilotage requirement. That, too, remained unsettled. Cousins' competence became less of an issue than the abilities of the helmsman, Robert Kagan, who was blamed by many for the disaster. Cousins indicated that Kagan, who had past problems with steering, failed to follow his command for a 10-degree right turn which would have taken the ship out of harm's way. Did Hazelwood know of Kagan's deficiencies? Did he err in leaving the bridge with this seaman at the helm? The jury must answer those questions and decide whether Hazelwood's actions constitute recklessness according to a legal definition as actions that are ``a gross deviation from the standard of conduct that a reasonable person would observe in the situation.'' Monday is set aside for legal discussions on how the judge should instruct the jury. Final arguments are scheduled for Tuesday, and Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone has said he hopes to instruct jurors in the law and submit the case to them the same day.

DOC.HEAD: Lights Seen in Sky Over Several States
DOC.TEXT: Bright lights in the sky puzzled observers in several states Saturday night, and authorities said the phenomenon wasn't caused by space debris. People reported seeing strange lights _ described variously as white streaks, flashing lights or a fireball _ in Missouri, Southern Illinois, Iowa and Arkansas. A spokesman for the North American Defense Command, which tracks objects in space from Peterson Air Force Base in Colorado Springs, Colo., said the lights didn't result from bits of a satellite or other man-made debris falling through the atmosphere. ``We are quite confident it is not caused by the re-entry of man-made objects,'' said Maj. Dick Adams, NORAD spokesman. The lights could have been meteorites, Adams said, but he couldn't be sure because the agency doesn't track natural phenomena. The National Weather Service in St. Louis reported getting numerous calls, some from people who said they saw a white light, followed by an explosion. ``I was outside when it happened,'' said Highway Patrol Sgt. Thomas Lefaivre in Kirkwood, Mo., outside St. Louis. ``I saw a big flash like one of my halogen lights burned out. But then I noticed my lights were okay and figured it must have been lightning.''

DOC.HEAD: Burst Levee Forces 1,000 To Flee Homes In Flooded Alabama Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 4 grafs with Georgia fatality; pick up 5th graf, `No injuries ...'. SUBS 21st graf, `In Georgia ...', with 2 grafs adding fatality; pick up 22nd graf pvs, `Several roads ...'; EDITS to trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MY1, AX5
DOC.TEXT: Muddy floodwaters filled a Southern Alabama courthouse, submerged a school and forced at least 1,500 people out of their homes after a levee burst Saturday under the strain of 16 inches of rain in two days. ``I have a feeling when I go back everything I own will be gone,'' said Debra Samuel, who fled her home less than a mile from the ruptured levee on the Pea River at Elba. Also in Alabama, six people drowned when their car ran off a back road into a rain-swollen creek where a bridge had washed out, while a Georgia woman died after she apparently drove into a creek and her car was washed away. Most of western Georgia was under flood warnings Saturday although rain had finally tapered off after a two-day deluge. In Mississippi, about 35 homes were flooded in Jackson County and several roads were washed out after 14 inches of rain fell in two days, officials reported. No injuries were immediately reported in Elba, a town of 4,400 about 70 miles southeast of Montgomery, where the earthen levee gave way about 6:30 a.m. Rescuers in boats plucked residents from rooftops and trees as the waters rose, said Sheriff Brice Paul. The town was without electricity, and officials said there were many gas leaks but no fires. Military helicopters picked up at least four people, said Bill Hayes, an Army spokesman at nearby Fort Rucker. The helicopters also were ferrying food to flood-stricken areas. Witnesses said water was up to second-story windows of the Coffee County Courthouse, higher than it reached in a record 1929 flood. Cecil Rainey, a representative from Gov. Guy Hunt's office who toured the area by helicopter, said, ``Water in downtown Elba is up to the rooftops. It's to the top of the school.'' Mark Oberfield, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Birmingham, said rain had been heavy throughout southeast Alabama, including 16.8 inches in Troy and 16.3 inches in Andalusia over the past 48 hours. While the sun peeked out Saturday in the region, forecasters said rivers would continue rising. Weather service records showed the flooding was the worst in more than 60 years in some areas. The weather service said the Pea River was expected to crest at about 47 feet at Elba late Saturday, 17 feet above flood stage. The river reached 43.5 feet in 1929. Elba Mayor Fred Moore said at least 1,500 people had been forced to leave their homes. Most roads were flooded and telephone lines were down, and officials were trying to set up emergency communications. The Red Cross was sending in rescue workers from as far away as Birmingham, some 160 miles away. Downstream from Elba in Geneva, more than 300 people were evacuated in anticipation of flooding, said Margaret Mixon, director of the Geneva County Emergency Management Agency. About 50 miles southwest, downtown Brewton was covered by 6 feet of water from the Murder and Burnt Corn creeks. Also south of Elba, near the Florida border, six people died when their car ran off a county road into a roaring creek late Friday. Coroner Norman Hobson said the driver apparently did not realize the bridge on the road between Florala and Samson was gone. ``There was a small barrier there, but nobody knows whether it was put up before or after the wreck,'' he said. State troopers identified the dead as driver James Ingram Burkett, 43, of Florala; his wife, Sandra, 44; their son, Jamie, 14; Jason Randolph Johnson, 20, of Miami; Michael Chambers, 29, of Florala; and Lorraine C. Campbell, 29, of McAplin, Fla. Authorities in Henry County, Ga., found the body of a woman in a creek Saturday afternoon. The woman, whose name was not immediately released, apparently drove into a creek and her car was washed away, said county Sheriff's Capt. Kenneth McBrayer. Elsewhere in Georgia, Peachtree Creek in Atlanta flooded, the weather service said, and the entire Chattahoochee River was under a flood warning from Atlanta in northern Georgia to Lake Seminole in the southwest corner of the state. Several roads in the counties surrounding Atlanta were closed early Saturday and scattered neighborhood evacuations were reported. Two traffic fatalities in Cobb County north of Atlanta on Friday night were attributed to rain-slicked roads. Rain that had pounded southeastern Mississippi for two days stopped Saturday after flooding about 35 homes in Jackson County. ``Before the weekend goes, we could see at least another 30 (homes) with water in them,'' said Hank Turk, Jackson County public safety director. Road crews were working to put down sandbags as the Pascagoula and Escatawpa rivers rise. In southeast Tennessee, nearly a foot of water was reported Saturday in the streets of Copperhill and Ducktown in Polk County, but it was receding by afternoon. An undetermined number of people had voluntarily left their homes, but there was no ordered evacuation, said David King, emergency operations officer from the Tennessee Emergency Management Agency in Nashville.

DOC.HEAD: Polls Open Amid Accusations Of Planned Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to restore byline and LaserPhoto info. Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with polls open. Pickup 6th graf `An East...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XBER1,3,5; NY5
DOC.TEXT: Polls opened in East Germany's first free election Sunday, with the speed and manner of expected German unification a prime issue. Opposition parties alleged ex-secret police may vote more than once to prop up Communist candidates. About 12.2 million voters were eligible to cast ballots for a 400-seat Parliament. With the likelihood of a merger with West Germany, Sunday's balloting could be the 41-year-old nation's first and last free election. The vote marks the full transition to democracy from the once iron-fisted Communist rule, and help set the pace of unification with West Germany. All major parties support unification but at a different pace. Some conservative parties urge a quick merger, while leftist groups favor a more cautious approach. Most East Germans agree such a joining is inevitable. Voters will choose from a dizzying array of 24 parties and groups. The nation's 22,000 polling stations were to stay open from 7 a.m. (1 a.m. EST) to 6 p.m. Sunday. West German television is expected to give computerized projections Sunday night, but official results are not expected until Monday. An East German television official said his crews for the first time had to make elaborate arrangements for an election. ``This time, we don't know what the result is going to be. Everything is new for us, and we should expect some chaos,'' said the official, who refused to give his name. Many voters have been bewildered by the slates of candidates ranging from radical leftists and Communists to arch-conservatives. The campaigning was bitter, and there is continuing fear about the once-dreaded secret police. Seven East German political parties claimed Saturday that former secret police agents planned to use sets of false identity cards, each with a different name, to vote several times. ``There is the suspicion of well prepared vote-rigging planned for March 18,'' the parties said in a statement. The Communist-led government claims the secret police force has been virtually disbanded, but many East Germans have doubts. The secret police force, which officials say once numbered nearly 200,000 agents and informers, was the hard-line Communists' main instrument of controlling East Germans. A popular revolution forced the ouster of hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker on Oct. 18 and opened the way for the elections. Most former secret police agents reportedly remain loyal to the Communists, who were not expected to receive more than 18 percent of the vote. In the city of Erfurt, the Social Democrats, Christian Democrats and five other parties demanded the use of fingerprints to prevent secret police agents from casting extra ballots. The parties also said they were making their concerns known to the U.N. Human Rights Commission in Geneva. An election commission representing all political parties has said vote-rigging is impossible. The election will be monitored by observers from the 34 members of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which was founded to monitor compliance with the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki accords. An American observer team will consist of staff members at the U.S. Embassy and six members of Congress, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. The secret police, known as the Stasi in German, already have played a part in the election. The top candidate of a conservative East German party resigned last week after admitting he had worked with the secret police for years. And Martin Kirchner, the general secretary of another conservative party, the East German Christian Democrats, admitted having contacts with the secret police during ``several sporadic visits'' during the early 1980s. He denied cooperating with them. Most campaigning ended Friday, but a few political parties made final pitches Saturday. The East German election is seen by many as a dress rehearsal for West German elections in December. West German politicians have worked hard to build up an East German base for the time when unification comes. In Bonn, President Richard von Weizsaecker said the elections would clear a ``healthy path to the unity of the Germans.'' ``The voters in the GDR (East Germans) aren't just deciding their own fate, but also the stability of the European home in which we all want to live with equal rights and without fear of each other,'' Weizsaecker added. Many East Berliners complained about what they considered West German arrogance and interference in their elections. East German flags with the Communist hammer-and-sickel insignia flew defiantly from several buildings. ``It's sad that we are so dependent on the West. We feel like beggars, as if we are asking for alms,'' said Marlies Clausenitzer, a 50-year-old arts teacher from the town of Schoenhausen just outside East Berlin. The election will be followed by efforts to form a new government to replace the Communist-led coalition now ruling East Germany. The large number of parties could make it difficult for one party to win a majority, creating the need for another coalition. Also on election eve, a West Berlin newspaper reported that East Germany's caretaker government has demanded an immediate financial bailout from Bonn to prevent economic collapse. ``East Germany urgently needs 5 billion marks ($2.94 billion) to provide for the population and prevent economic collapse,'' the Berliner Morgenpost newspaper said. According to the report, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has refused to act on the East German request pending the outcome of Sunday's elections. Kohl has said he ``is not willing to pour good money into a bad system.''

DOC.HEAD: Mother Reunited With Daughter
DOC.TEXT: An American mother who went to jail rather than reveal her daughter's whereabouts during a custody battle was reunited with her 7-year-old child over the weekend, a news report said Sunday. The New Zealand Press Association said Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, who spent 25 months in jail in the United States, went Saturday to the motel where her daughter Hilary has lived with Ms. Morgan's parents since mid-1988. Morgan's estranged husband, Eric Foretich, was reunited with Hilary last week before returning home to the United States. The child custody battle has centered on the mother's claims of sexual abuse by the father. Foretich denies the allegations. The New Zealand Family Court is to rule on the custody issue, but no date has been set for the hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Elections In Five Republics; Latvian and Estonian Movements Hope for Victory
DOC.TEXT: Voters in five Soviet republics elected local legislators Sunday, with crucial runoffs in the Slavic heartland and pro-independence candidates in Latvia and Estonia hoping to prevail as in neighboring Lithuania. The elections in Latvia and Estonia are the first multiparty balloting for the parliaments of the two Baltic republics. Latvian People's Front spokeswoman Anda Anspoka said Saturday that the group nominated 185 candidates for the 200 seats in the parliament. It hoped to gain a two-thirds majority ``in order to fight for independence.'' Estonian backers of independence dominated the field of 392 candidates competing for the republic's 105 parliament seats, according to activists and the Estonian Election Commission's list of nominating groups. In Latvia and Estonia, elections held in December gave pro-independence movements in the two republics up to half the seats in local governments. Pro-independence candidates swept the field in neighboring Lithuania in February elections, and the republic's new parliament issued a dramatic declaration of independence last Sunday. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev pronounced the move ``illegal and invalid'' and gave the republic until Monday to take back the proclamation. He has not said what the Kremlin will do if Lithuania refuses. The Soviet Union annexed the three Baltic republics in 1940. Gorbachev's reforms have given voice to swelling independence movements there. Runoff elections were held Sunday in Byelorussia, Russia and the Ukraine, the vast Slavic heartland that makes up 80 percent of the Soviet Union's territory and is home to some two-thirds of its population. Most of the 1,800 races held March 4 in the three Slavic republics required runoffs because no candidate won 50 percent of the vote. Pro-democracy groups predict they will gain a voice _ and in some areas even majorities _ in republic parliaments and local councils. Polls in all five republics were scheduled to close at 8 p.m. (noon EST in the Slavic republics and 1 p.m. EST in the Baltics). Results from all the republics were not expected for several days. In the republic of Georgia, pro-independence radical organizations decided after a three-day conference to boycott elections scheduled for March 25, Tass reported. ``The conference decided by a majority vote to hold future elections to an opposition council, which will control the actions of the republic's government until complete independence is achieved,'' Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Pipeline Blast In Tehran Kills Iranians
DOC.TEXT: A gas pipeline exploded and burned in western Tehran Sunday, killing several people and injuring scores more, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the 11.30 a.m. (3 a.m. EST) blast in Jamalzadeh Avenue, one of the district's main thoroughfares, started ``a massive fire.'' Fire crews were still battling the blaze 90 minutes later, it said. At least 10 cars were destroyed and 15 buildings badly damaged by the explosion, the agency reported. A fleet of ambulances took the casualties to hospitals in the capital, IRNA added. It gave no other details.

DOC.HEAD: 15 Killed in Fire at Supermarket
DOC.TEXT: Fire raged in a supermarket in a western Japanese city Sunday, killing 15 people and injuring six, police said. A total of 57 fire engines were dispatched to fight the blaze at the Nagasakiya store in Amagasaki, 300 miles west of Tokyo, said fire department spokesman Hiroshi Kawamoto. The fire broke out shortly after noon on the fourth floor, filled with about 100 shoppers at the time, said Kawamoto. It took about four hours to put out the blaze, whose cause was not immediately known. Kawamoto said all 15 victims probably died of smoke and gas inhalation, although detailed examinations of the bodies had not yet been conducted. Police at the scene had mistakenly said earlier that 16 people died in the blaze. The victims were found on the fifth floor, where the employees' cafeteria and offices are located. Of the six injured, two, including a 12-year-old boy, had jumped from the window on the fifth floor, Kawamoto said.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Vote in Crucial Election
DOC.TEXT: East Germans voted Sunday in a free election made possible by their pro-democracy revolution, and the ballots they cast were expected to decide the pace of the drive toward reunification. In a last-minute warning, opposition parties alleged that former secret police may vote more than once to prop up Communist candidates. About 12.2 million voters were eligible to cast ballots for a 400-seat Parliament. With the likelihood of a merger with West Germany, the balloting could have been the 41-year-old nation's first and last free election. West German television was expected to make its first projections two hours after polls close at 6 p.m. (noon EST). Final results weren't expected until Monday. Hans Modrow, Communist premier of East Germany's caretaker government, was among the early-risers to go to the polls. Modrow was greeted with applause when he showed up at a polling site in East Berlin. ``The last days and weeks have shown that the citizens of the GDR see this election as very important for the country's further development,'' Modrow said, according to East Germany's ADN news agency. Modrow repeated his belief that the process of German unification cannot be separated from what happens in the rest of Europe, said ADN. ``Only then, if we proceed with level-headedness, will people in Europe be able to have a good opinion of us. And that is the responsibility we are carrying,'' ADN quoted him as saying. Voters chose from a dizzying array of 24 parties and groups. All major parties support unification but at a different pace. Some conservative parties urge a quick merger, while leftist groups favor a more cautious approach. Most East Germans agree such a joining is inevitable. International election observers fanned out to monitor the balloting. In East Berlin, 10 members of an election-monitoring delegation from the Council of Europe started headed for their destinations in various parts of East Germany. ``The group wants to visit as many voting places as possible,'' delegation head Sir Geoffrey Finsberg of Britain was quoted as saying by ADN. Most polling places opened at 7 a.m., but many industrial workers were permitted to start voting two hours earlier, just before they went to work. Juergen Myrau, an engineer at the Buna chemical factory near Halle, showed up to vote shortly after the 5 a.m. poll-opening time. ``It's a great feeling to go to a free election,'' ADN quoted Myrau as saying. Wolfgang Koegel, an employee at a power plant in Suhl, a southwestern city near the West German border, was the first to vote in his district. ``No one really knows who's going to b elected. But by all means I am for a better future, especially when I think about my two children,'' he told ADN. Like other countries in the Soviet bloc, East Germany's political landscape was redrawn last year by a pro-democracy revolution that ousted its hard-line Communist leadership. In the upheaval that followed, hundreds of thousands of East Germans fled to the West, the Berlin Wall was opened and reunification became a rallying cry in East and West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: 3 Killed, 20 Injured in Train Crash
DOC.TEXT: Two freight cars and a passenger coach disconnected from an engine and fell into a river near Dhaka, killing three people and injuring 20, railway officials said Sunday. The accident occurred late Saturday at Golaghat rail bridge in Gazipur district, 20 miles north of Dhaka. When the engine separated from the three cars it was pulling, the driver stopped and the cars rammed the engine and fell into the river. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said three bodies were recovered from the river Sunday morning and the injured were hospitalized. It was not known how many people were on the train, which was traveling from Dhaka to Bahadurabad, a distance of 80 miles.

DOC.HEAD: Pirate Radio Ship Sets Sail For China
DOC.TEXT: A pirate radio ship supported by Chinese dissidents set sail for China, where it will broadcast news programs in Chinese from the safety of international waters. Officials in La Rochelle said the ship, a 1,200-ton, 260-foot former British oceanographic vessel, left Saturday night. The ship is named the Goddess of Democracy, after the statue erected in Beijing's Tiananmen Square when the democracy movement was at its height. The vessel was dedicated a week ago by French singer-actor Yves Montand and Chinese dissident leader Wu'er Kaixi. It is sponsored by 18 news organizations in several countries, including the magazine Actuel in France and in collaboration with the Federation for Democracy in China. The ship, operated by 11 French sailors, contains two radio studios and a television studio. The vessel is expected to arrive in international waters off the coast of China between April 20 and April 25. It will broadcast programs of music and news.

DOC.HEAD: Crew Member Killed in Cruise Ship Fire
DOC.TEXT: A fire in the engine room of a cruise ship off Australia killed one crew member and injured another Sunday, but the blaze was put out before it could reach the 1,200 passengers or disable the vessel. P&O-Sitmar Cruises, owners of the Fairstar, said a 44-year-old boiler attendant died after suffering burns to 75 percent of his body during what was to be a routine testing of an auxiliary boiler. Officials said another crew member suffered minor burns but that he will remain on board the ship until it docks in Sydney on Monday morning. The P&O-Sitmar statement said none of the 1,200 passengers on board the ship was injured. It was off the New South Wales state coast and heading back to Sydney after a 10-day South Pacific cruise when the fire occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Names Six Auxiliary Bishops in Czechoslovachia
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II named six auxiliary bishops to Czechoslovakia in a further sign of the improved relations between the Vatican and the former Communist country. The bishops will work in the dioceses of Prague, Olomouc and Trnava. Until 1988, the Prague government had blocked the nominations of new bishops for 15 years. Pope John Paul II, who announced the new appointments Saturday, will visit Czechoslovakia on April 21-22, his first trip to a Warsaw Pact country other than his native Poland. The Vatican has been moving quickly to take advantage of the new climate in Eastern Europe in order to boost the position of local Roman Catholic churches.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Dies of Wounds, Strike in West Bank and Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: Masked Palestinians armed with axes and knives roamed a West Bank town Sunday to enforce a strike called in protest of U.S. plans for preliminary Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, Arab reports said. Also Sunday, a Palestinian man died in a West Bank hospital Sunday, three days after he was hit in the head by a rubber bullet fired by Israeli soldiers, hospital reports said. The strike closed shops and schools in the occupied West Bank and Arab east Jerusalem. The fundamentalist Islamic group Hamas, or ``Zeal,'' called it to protest Secretary of State James A. Baker III's proposal for preliminary Israeli-Palestinian talks in Cairo. A recent Hamas leaflet called the proposal ``an American-Zionist conspiracy.'' Arab reports said that in the West Bank city of Hebron, about 50 masked Palestinians armed with axes and knives stopped cars and slashed the tires of at least 10 vehicles that defied the strike call. Disagreement over the Baker plan led to the collapse last week of Israel's coalition government. President Chaim Herzog began consultations Sunday required by law before he chooses a leader to form a new government. The right-wing prime minister, Yitzhak Shamir, opposed U.S.-backed compromises to get the preliminary talks under way, while more liberal lawmakers supported the compromises. Shamir's rival, Labor Party leader Shimon Peres, engineered a vote of no-confidence that passed and brought down the government. Herzog was expected to give the mandate for forming a government to Peres. The man who died Sunday was identified as Salim Yacoub Rihan, 50. Arab reports said he was shot Thursday night as he drove a horse-drawn cart through the Al Amari refugee camp in the West Bank. A doctor at Ramallah Hospital said Rihan was hit in the head with a single rubber bullet ``fired at close range.'' The doctor asked not to be identified. An army official confirmed that Israeli had fired rubber bullets in Al Amari on Thursday to disperse stone-throwers. The official, who cannot be identified by name under briefing rules, said the army was checking further into the incident. Rubber bullets are generally not lethal, although they can cause death if fired at close range and if they penetrate the head, chest or abdomen. Rihan's death raised to 664 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since the uprising against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip began in December 1987. Forty-three Israelis have died. An additional 198 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs. In the Gaza Strip on Sunday, an 18-year-old Palestinian was in critical condition after he was hit in the head by a plastic bullet in a stone-throwing confrontation with soldiers in Gaza City, Arab hospital officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Down-and-Dirty Texas Governor's Race May Set Tone for 1990
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 campaign season opened in slashing style in Texas, setting a nasty tone that experts predict will mark many races this year. Candidates may sign clean-campaign pledges, commentators may criticize nasty ads, but if negative tactics work, politicians will use them, analysts say. Political consultants see nothing wrong with that. ``The standard should be, do you tell the truth and is it fair _ even though the truth is painful,'' said Bob Squier, who is handling Democrat Ann Richards' media spots in the Texas gubernatorial race. ``I rely on the press for accuracy, which is probably a mistake, and the public decides whether it's fair,'' said GOP media consultant Roger Ailes, who handled George Bush's ads in 1988 and this year is working for Senate hopeful Lynn Martin of Illinois and others. In Texas, the three Democratic candidates pledged not to attack the character, integrity or honesty of their opponents, with this result: _Richards, now facing a runoff against state attorney general Jim Mattox, ran an ad charging that Mattox and former Gov. Mark White got rich off public service and had ``the worst resumes money can buy.'' _White ran an ad telling viewers to watch Mattox's lips: ``If they're moving, he could be lying.'' _Mattox took aim at Richards' refusal to discuss whether she ever had used illegal drugs. ``Maybe after you've decided not to tell the truth about yourself, it's pretty easy to lie about your opponents,'' his ad said. John Buckley, a former spokesman for the National Republican Congressional Committee, said Richards might not have made it into the April 10 Democratic runoff had she not gone negative. ``The (Texas) candidates were not making a lot of headway with positive appeals,'' acknowledged Mike McCurry, a spokesman for the Democratic National Committee. ``There's some discussion that ... when everybody is up and running, the only way to break through that clutter is to go sharply negative.'' While the Texas Democrats appear likely to continue their bloodletting through the runoff, some candidates have had second thoughts about using negative ads this year. In Florida, Rep. Bill Nelson, a candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, opened his campaign by trying to blame GOP Gov. Bob Martinez for the early release of a convict who later was charged with killing two police officers. Nelson quickly shelved the strategy after a rival Democrat accused him of trying to ``Willie Horton-ize'' the election and a circuit judge scolded him for calling the convict a killer before he had been tried. Horton, a convicted killer, became a campaign issue in 1988 when George Bush criticized Michael Dukakis for supporting a Massachusetts furlough program from which Horton escaped. Nelson's campaign is not the only one that has backed off from negative ads. Texas Republican gubernatorial hopeful Kent Hance had a change of heart provoked by a drop in the polls. With his support waning, Hance withdrew a confusing TV ad questioning the integrity of GOP rival and eventual victor Clayton Williams. Some observers cited the Hance incident as proof that negative ads don't pay, but others argued the ad's flaws had nothing to do with its tone. ``There's good and bad, effective and ineffective, smart and dumb,'' said Squier. ``If you do a dumb ad, it will probably backfire on you.'' While much of the Texas mudslinging was done through television ads, candidates and their surrogates are on the attack live and in person, as well. In California, for example, Democratic Attorney General John Van de Kamp turned his candidacy announcement into a tirade against primary opponent Diane Feinstein, former mayor of San Francisco. Van de Kamp blasted Feinstein's record on civil rights, insurance, the environment and women's issues, and accused her of budget mismanagement that turned San Francisco into ``the city that could not pay.'' Feinstein's surge past Van de Kamp, meanwhile, was largely attributed to early ``positive'' ads that discussed her experience and support for the death penalty. Other are taking the positive approach, as well. In Florida, Martinez is touting his record on the environment. Martin has run a soft, getting-to-know-you spot in Illinois. And Rep. Ronnie Flippo, D-Ala., a candidate for governor, ran an ad featuring a county development chairman praising his work for a new economic project. There's no guarantee, however, that any of these races won't turn nasty, particularly when the field narrows after the primary season. Martin's opponent, Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., has invoked the negative-ad threat as a fund-raising tool. ``Roger Ailes, Bush's media hitman, who produced some of the most vicious campaign ads of 1988, is now at work on TV spots for Martin. We must be ready to respond,'' Simon wrote past contributors earlier this year. Some analysts believe the nastiest races in 1990 may be those in which the candidates are the most alike, leaving character as the only battleground. By that theory, candidates with substantive disagreements can take the higher road. Already, however, reality is departing from theory. In Iowa, where GOP Rep. Tom Tauke is challenging Sen. Tom Harkin, a liberal Democrat, the recent focus has been on Harkin's homes in Virginia and the Bahamas. The state Republican chairman charged that Harkin is a hypocrite who's out of touch with Iowans. Desperate, vicious, negative, countered the Harkin campaign. ``GOP flings mud first,'' the Des Moines Register said. Business as usual, the experts say.

DOC.HEAD: Drug-Using Teens Three Times More Likely To Try Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Teen-agers on drugs are at least three times more likely to attempt suicide than drug-free adolescents, according to a study of patients at drug treatment centers. Dr. Richard H. Schwartz, a Vienna, Va., pediatrician who co-authored a report published in the American Journal of Diseases of Children, said the research shows that drugs play a powerful role in the large numbers of teenage suicides. ``There's no question that the drugs themselves can lead to depressive effects that lead to suicide attempts,'' he said. `` ... The more easily obtainable is the drug, the greater the adverse effects. Suicide attempts increase dramatically.'' Suicide is the third leading cause of death among 15- to 24-year-old Americans. In Virginia, Schwartz said, it is the second leading cause of death among this age group. Schwartz said his study involved testing and questioning 298 adolescent patients at four treatment centers he identified only as being in three separate areas east of the Mississippi River. Two-thirds of those surveyed admitted they had thoughts about committing suicide and 30 percent said they had made actual suicide attempts. Earlier studies, said Schwartz, show that between 6 and 7 percent of the general population attempt suicide in adolescence. Schwartz said the patients in his study were between 13 and 19 years old. Most, 93 percent, were white, and 66 percent were male. The most popular drug among the group was marijuana, with alcohol a distant second. Other drugs, such as crack, cocaine, angel dust and LSD also were used. Among those who attempted suicide, 40 percent said they made the attempt within eight hours after using drugs. Although there probably are ``multiple factors'' that lead to suicide attempts, Schwartz said the higher rate among drug users may be attributed to the depressive effects or ``low'' that develops after using some drugs. ``Some drugs, in and of themselves, have depressive effects. Alcohol does, and so does PCP (or angel dust) and LSD,'' said Schwartz. For drugs that are stimulants, such as crack or cocaine, ``the depression is a rebound. They go up very high, and the higher the high, the lower the low.'' Following a crack binge, for instance, he said, there will be an ``almost intolerable'' depression and many drug users see no way out but suicide. Most of the suicide attempts were ``of low lethality,'' said Schwartz, with 61 percent requiring no medical attention. But 10 percent tried to kill themselves at the wheel of a car and 8 percent tried to hang themselves. ``About 15 percent (of those attempting suicide) spent time in intensive care,'' said Schwartz. ``These were not superficial wrist slashings'' but serious attempts that could have resulted in death without prompt medical care. The physician said he and his co-author, American University psychologist Alan L. Berman, were ``astounded'' that almost half of the teens who seriously attempted suicide reported that lethal means for doing it again were still in their family homes. Schwartz said 23 percent of those who tried to kill themselves said their families continued to keep firearms and ammunition around the home afterwards. ``You cannot keep weapons at home like that if there is an adolescent on drugs,'' he said. ``You can assume a one-in-nine chance of multiple suicide attempts so you need to get rid of firearms. Among successful suicides, there's a growing tendency to use firearms.'' The study by Schwartz and Berman is in the March issue of the American Journal of Diseases of Children.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Defused, Christian Rivals Battle With Artillery
DOC.TEXT: A driverless car packed with explosives rolled toward a hotel early Sunday where Syrian soldiers are based, but it careened off course into sandbags and the bomb was defused safely, police said. A police spokesman said the target of the car bomb was almost certainly the Commodore Hotel, which houses about 100 Syrian soldiers. The seven-story hotel in Moslem west Beirut was for years the main base of Western correspondents covering Lebanon's civil war. It was wrecked in 1987 in fighting between rival Moslem militias. Police reported that before dawn, the navy blue Audi sedan, its motor and lights off, was rolled down a street leading to the Commodore Hotel. ``But it veered slightly to the left and hit a sandbag position on a road intersection about 20 yards from the Commodore, and luckily failed to go off,'' said the police spokesman. He cannot be named under standing regulations. The spokesman said bomb disposal experts established that the explosives were set to detonate at 4 a.m., but they could not determine why they did not go off. The car bomb remained undetected for more than two hours, until Syrian sentries began patrolling the area at 6 a.m., the spokesman added. Two boxes of explosives, weighing a total of 132 pounds, were taken from the car. No group claimed responsibilty for the attempted bombing. Had it gone off, the bomb would have been the second such attack in Lebanon this year. Lebanon's warring factions have used car bombs as weapons of terror since the civil war broke out in 1975. On Jan. 27, a car bomb exploded 50 yards from the home of Sheik Mohammed Mehdi Shamseddin, spiritual head of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiite Moslems, in an apparent assassination attempt. No one was hurt. It too was rolled down an incline but detonated after it bumped into an earth mound at the side of the road. The Syrians maintain 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. They control about 70 percent of the country and have long been targets for Moslem rivals who seek to undermine their peacekeeping mission. The Commodore is across the street from a seven-story block housing the Beirut offices of The Associated Press, CBS and NBC, the British Broadcasting Corp. and Kuwait's al-Qabas daily newspaper. Elsewhere Sunday, police reported new battles between renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and fighters of the Lebanese Forces militia, headed by Samir Geagea. The rival Christian forces pounded each other with artillery and tank barrages all night in the Christian enclave north of Beirut, police said. There was no immediate report of casualties. The exchanges in the mountains of Kesrouan province followed mortar duels Saturday in which six civilians were killed. The victims included a family of four trapped in a burning underground shelter. By police count, 762 people have been killed and 2,115 wounded since Jan. 30, when Aoun launched his attempt to crush Geagea's militia. The Lebanese Forces militia is the only serious military challenge to Aoun's leadership of the estimated 1 million Christians in the enclave.

DOC.HEAD: Disabilities Bill Gets Second Wind in House
DOC.TEXT: A bill that would guarantee equal rights to millions of Americans with handicaps is moving toward passage this spring, although disagreement over a related civil rights proposal threatens that timetable. Backers of the Americans With Disabilities Act say the bill has regained momentum after a nearly four-month interruption that included adjournment of Congress. Supporters had planned on full passage before Christmas. The bill would grant disabled people equal employment opportunity, although business with fewer than 15 employees would be exempted. It also would grant equal access to transportation, telephone service, business and entertainment, and professional services. On March 6, a subcommittee of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee sent the Senate-passed bill to the full committee after modifications favorable to the transportation industry. The House Education and Labor Committee approved the bill last November on a 35-0 vote, adding only a clarification sought by the business community on the status of drug users. More importantly, the House Energy and Commerce Committee reported the bill last week on a 40-3 vote with no amendments to the Senate-passed version except for more compromises over transportation requirements. The recent actions mean that only the Judiciary and Public Works and Transportation committees must act on the bill before it goes to the House floor. ``We are confident that the Americans With Disabilities Act will be enacted into law in either April or May of this year,'' said Ralph G. Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a coalition of civil rights groups. The National Federation of Independent Business, the small-business advocacy group that is trying to change the bill substantially, says it has made gains through lobbying at the grass roots level and in Congress. To that end, NFIB in February persuaded the House Small Business Committee to conduct a hearing on the bill even though it lacks jurisdiction. Among witnesses were businessmen in wheelchairs who said they objected to portions of the legislation. ``I think that we're making progress and I think that the momentum is shifting somewhat,'' NFIB lobbyist David K. Rehr said. Rehr said both Democrats and Republicans in the House are looking at the bill's economic impact more critically than the Senate did when the bill passed that chamber, 76-8, in September. The supporters of the bill say business concerns were considered at every step. The bill provides long timetables for implementation, a number of exemptions and a promise of technical guidance, supporters say. They say the bill's costs will be offset by more disabled Americans entering the economic mainstream and depending less on government payments. The NFIB and others contend the bill is laden with legal abstractions that will force the typical Main Street proprietor to spend even more on lawyers' fees, both inside and outside of court. NFIB also wants a tax credit for businesses that accommodate disabled employees or customers. The group argues that the disabilities bill is the only civil rights legislation that imposes a direct cost on business. But those issues will be set aside until a bigger one involving the White House is resolved. Vocal White House support helped move the bill through the Senate and helped win over Republicans in the House. When disabled activists demonstrated at the Capitol last week _ many of them later to be arrested in their wheelchairs for acts of civil disobedience _ Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Md., told them: ``We are 25 years late in having a civil rights bill for the disabled. We understand that.'' Hoyer's oblique reference to the Civil Rights Act of 1964 pointed to the new threat. The same civil rights community that backs the disabilities law as a logical and morally necessary extension of the 1964 act also backs the Civil Rights Act of 1990, which was introduced in February. The new law would change Title VII of the landmark 1964 law to make it possible to sue employers for damages if they intentionally discriminate against blacks, other minorities and women. Title VII currently limits relief to non-damage remedies, such as back pay and injunctive relief, that could be awarded by a judge. The disabilities bill refers directly to Title VII as the source of relief for job discrimination against the disabled. The Bush administration opposes the modification to the civil rights act and has asked that the Title VII reference be stripped from the disabilities bill. Instead, the specific remedies would be spelled out.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Demand Democratic Changes, Denounce Aging Politicians
DOC.TEXT: More than 20,000 people rallied in a downtown park Sunday to demand swifter democratic change and to denounce elderly members of the electoral college that will choose Taiwan's president this week. The protest was the largest in Taiwan since the lifting of martial law in 1987. It highlighted growing anger with a political system largely dominated by aging members of the ruling Nationalist Party born on mainland China. Police said there were about 10,000 protesters, but reporters estimated the crowd at more than 20,000. Many, however, were onlookers. In a reference to the elderly Nationalists who control the electoral college, protesters shouted, ``Old thieves, step down!'' and ``People elect the president!'' Demonstrators beat drums and gongs to galvanize the crowd.
