Leaders of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which organized the demonstration, urged President Lee Teng-hui to dissolve the electoral college, known as the National Assembly, and allow general presidential elections. The National Assembly elects the president Wednesday, and Lee is the only candidate. About 500 college students continued a sit-in they began Friday in front of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Park to protest the aging assemblymen. Democratic Progressive Party politicians urged the crowd to support the protest by staying in the park overnight and delaying the filing of income tax. ``This park will become another Tiananmen Square if the ruling party still refuses to listen,'' said opposition party chairman Huang Hsin-chieh, referring to last year's pro-democracy protests in China. ``We have tolerated this absurd parliament for 40 years. We cannot and should not stand it any longer,'' said Chang Kuo-lung, a physics professor of the National Taiwan University. In the park, some protesters burned a national flag after they chopped off the flag pole. A man and two women who tried to stop the flag burning were slightly injured in a melee with the protesters. Demonstrators forced several photographers to pull out their film. The white gates and a facade of the Chinese-style park were painted with slogans such as ``Old Thieves Go, Democracy Comes'' and ``Long Live Taiwanese.'' About 100 protesters later marched one mile to the presidential building and demanded a meeting with President Lee. They were blocked by hundreds of riot police behind barbed-wire barricades. The group then staged a brief sit-in and returned to the park. Students, mostly from the prestigious National Taiwan University, vowed to stage a one-week class boycott beginning Monday to press their demands for democratic change. The focus of the anger are the 668 elderly deputies in the 752-seat National Assembly who were elected on the Chinese mainland before 1949. In 1949, they fled to Taiwan with the rest of the Nationalist government after losing a civil war to Communist forces. The deputies, many in their 80s and 90s, have been frozen in office to support the Nationalist claim to still be the legitimate government of China. They have defiantly rejected demands they retire. In an attempt to ease growing public criticism, President Lee appealed to the nation in a televised speech Saturday night to ``use a calmer and more responsible attitude to face our present political development.'' Critics said Lee's address was too vague because he failed to give a timetable for introducing more democracy to this island of 20 million people. Lee is a 67-year-old native Taiwanese. Many aging assemblymen distrust Lee because they believe he is not committed to their dream of returning victoriously to the Chinese mainland. But they dropped efforts to draft their own candidate for Wednesday's vote because of intense public pressure.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Leaders Faced With Tough Amendments to Clean Air Bill
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders, struggling to keep a compromise clean air agreement from unraveling, hope this week to fend off a series of ``strengthening'' amendments that the White House calls too expensive. Returning from a weeklong recess, senators renew debate Tuesday on the far-reaching air pollution control legislation that has preoccupied the Senate most of this month. Among the thorniest issues are whether to go along with a plea from Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., for assistance to any coal miners who lose their jobs because of new pollution curbs and over attempts by more than a dozen senators to toughen controls on smog-causing pollutants from automobiles. Meanwhile, similar legislation in the House has begun to move. The House Energy and Commerce Committee begins this week to consider details of the bill. Although President Bush has indicated he would like to have a clean air bill in time for his signature by Earth Day, which will be celebrated April 22, no one on Capitol Hill predicts a bill will be ready by then. The clean air legislation _ somewhat different versions in the Senate and House _ represent the first major changes in 13 years in the 1970 Clean Air Act. Bush as well as most members of Congress acknowledge tougher controls on air pollution are overdue. But getting a bill through Congress has pitted regional groups against one another and prompted intense lobbying by a variety of industries who argue that the controls under consideration are too expensive and threaten the nation's economy. The House and Senate bills impose significantly tougher controls on smog-causing pollutants from both automobiles and industrial sources; require industry to install new equipment to curb toxic chemical releases that now total more than 2.7 billion pounds a year; and for the first time require sharp reductions in sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide emissions from coal-fired electric power plants to curb acid rain. But a coalition of senators argue that a compromise agreement with the White House after weeks of closed-door negotiations substantially weakened the Senate bill, especially its curbs to control urban smog by tightening emissions from automobiles. Sens. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., and Pete Wilson, R-Calif., planned to push an amendment early in the week that would restore a tougher second round of tailpipe controls and require automakers to produce a specific number of alternative fuel vehicles. The tougher controls in the Wirth-Wilson amendment have been strongly criticized by the Bush administration and characterized as likely ``deal breakers'' that could scuttle the compromise agreement and threaten passage of clean air legislation altogether. Byrd's coal miner assistance amendment also has been called a threat to the Senate-White House agreement and will have to be dealt with before serious progress can be made on other provisions, according to Senate aides. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, had been prepared to vote on the Byrd proposal before the Senate adjourned for its recess. But Mitchell postponed a vote after it became unclear whether he had enough votes to rebuff Byrd, who wields considerable power among senators because of his chairmanship of the appropriations committee. The Byrd plan calls for the government to pay miners between 50 percent to 80 percent of their most recent salaries for four years after they become unemployed if their job loss stems from tougher acid rain pollution controls on coal utilities. The controversy over the coal miner provisions threatened to complicate attempts by Mitchell and Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, to keep support for the compromise legislation intact. If the assistance program is approved, it could cause the White House to withdraw support for the legislative package and cause other senators to seek similar job protection provisions for other workers _ such as the petrochemical or steel industries _ who also face possible harm. But if Byrd is rebuffed, he could persuade enough senators to oppose the bill to prevent its passage. In the House, meanwhile, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, said he wanted to complete action on clean air legislation before the Easter recess April 6. Dingell last week cautioned committee members to proceed ``without undue delay and procrastination'' but said he anticipated ``long and difficult'' committee sessions, with the consideration of amendments scheduled to begin Tuesday. Among the yet-unresolved problems facing the House committee is whether to provide assistance to coal-burning utilities in the Ohio Valley and elsewhere in the Midwest that meet tougher acid rain controls. The Bush administration staunchly opposes a national fee or tax to help the dirtiest electric plants cut pollution, but Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., is planning to seek such a fee on industrial emitters of sulfur dioxide. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., and other members also are expected to seek tougher emission controls on toxic and smog-causing pollutants from industrial sources and further reductions in automobile emissions both through tighter tailpipe controls and wider use of alternative fuel vehicles.

DOC.HEAD: Here's $25, Now GOP Will Debit Your Account
DOC.TEXT: Rita Schattman isn't old enough to vote, but the Republican Party thinks she's got enough cash in the bank to automatically hand over $12.50 a month to its ``Secret Candidate Support Weapon.'' A 16-year-old Democrat from Fort Worth, Texas, Miss Schattman was surprised to find a genuine $25 check mailed to her recently from an arm of the National Republican Senatorial Committee. But it wasn't until she got to the 11th paragraph of a three-page letter touting the GOP's new ``Candidate Escrow Funding'' concept that Miss Schattman realized that by cashing the check she was agreeing to let the party take $12.50 a month out of her bank account. After a two-month trial at the GOP's expense, Miss Schattman could either cancel participation or continue letting the party automatically transfer $12.50 a month from her bank account to a fund to help Republican candidates. Trouble is, the high school junior says she doesn't even have a checking account. ``It's the oddest thing I think I've ever received,'' she said after school Friday. Republican officials are also at a loss to explain how Miss Schattman, who hopes to get her driver's license this week, wound up on a mailing list for prospective members of the Republican Presidential Task Force. When she saw the check, Miss Schattman said her first reaction was: ``That's pretty stupid for them to send me money, I wouldn't do anything for them.'' Miss Schattman said she then tried to think of a way of endorsing the check over to a cause like Habitat for Humanity or the Abortion Rights League. But she decided she didn't want to risk having her name show up in the ``charter issue'' of ``Who's Who in the Republican Party.'' The fund-raising letter, paid for and authorized by the National Republican Senatorial Committee, said recipients who deposit their checks before the expiration date would be included in what promises to become ``one of America's most prestigious reference books.'' ``I want to know if it's legal for them to have done that (send out the checks). Old ladies, who don't read the entire thing because it hurts their eyes might think, how nice. And they can't read the tiny print on the back of the check,'' Miss Schattman said. Buried on the back of the check, in tiny type, is a notice that the $12.50 monthly charge would be going up by 10 percent on each one-year anniversary. Other Democrats also are questioning the Republican's strategy. Joe Louis Barrow, deputy director of communications for the Democratic National Committee, said a Democratic lawyer in Pennsylvania received a similar letter and has apparently asked the Federal Election Commission for a ruling. Bob Slagle, Texas Democratic Party chairman, called the fund-raising effort ``too deceitful and fraudulent to be funny.'' ``Leave it to the Republicans to figure out another way to con you,'' Slagle said. Since the Feb. 23 letter went out to several thousand people, the National Republican Senatorial Committee has made several changes for its next edition, including adding a toll-free number for recipients confused about the plan, said spokeswoman Wendy DeMocker. ``We do want good will attached to our fund-raising efforts,'' she said. Ms. DeMocker said the first mailing went to current members of the Republican Presidential Task Force who mail in a monthly $10 contribution, and to prospective members. She said using electronic fund transfers instead of soliciting individual checks from thousands of contributors was a ``more streamlined'' way of doing business. But she didn't know how a 16-year-old wound up on the mailing list. ``How she found her way onto our mailing list is,'' she paused, ``interesting. ... That's pretty unusual.'' Slagle complained some recipients of the check might deposit it without realizing what they were getting into. ``Most people aren't interested in reading three pages and I'm sure some people are going to be suckered by it,'' Slagle said. Ms. DeMocker, however, said participants would see on their bank statements that $12.50 was being taken out ``and there is a three-page letter.'' Slagle, an attorney, also questioned whether the contract printed on the back of the check is enforceable under a Texas law which requires the use of large type for certain contract provisions. ``I'd hate to be a lawyer enforcing that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Fuel Efficiency Slipped in Past Two Years, Group Says
DOC.TEXT: Average fuel economy for automobiles has declined each of the last two years, reversing an earlier five-year trend toward more efficient automobiles, an environmental group said Sunday. The Environmental Action Foundation cited statistics from the Environmental Protection Agency and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. According to the government figures cited by the group, the average fuel economy of 1990 model cars is expected to be 28.2 miles per gallon, compared with 28.3 mpg for 1989 model cars and 28.7 mpg for 1988 model cars. An analysis by the EPA attributed the trend to the manufacture of heavier cars with quicker acceleration times and the use of larger engines with greater horsepower. ``In terms of fuel efficiency we're heading south on a northbound, one-way street,'' said Robert Dewey of the Environmental Action Foundation. The figures showed that between the 1983 and 1988 model years the fuel efficiency of both domestic and imported cars increased steadily from 26.4 mpg to 28.7 mpg. Dewey said the government figures also show that the gap between imports and domestic cars is narrowing in terms of fuel efficiency. In 1986, imports on a fleet-wide basis were 8 mpg more efficient than domestic cars. In the 1990 models, the difference has narrowed to 3 mpg, he said. ``These figures clearly dispel the myth that Japanese automakers still hold a huge efficiency advantage over domestics,'' said Dewey. The advantage of Japanese automakers in past years over domestic fleets in fuel efficiency largely has been based on the fact the Japanese built smaller cars. In recent years with government restrictions on the number of imports, the Japanese imports have consisted of more large, less fuel efficient vehicles. There has been increasing concern among environmentalists over the fuel efficiency of cars because the more gasoline cars use the more they emit carbon dioxide, which is linked to global warming. Legislation expected to be considered later this year in the Senate would require automakers to achieve a fleetwide 40 mpg by the end of the decade. Efforts also are expected to put a similar provision into the clean air legislation that now is before House Energy and Commerce Committee. The automakers have vigorously lobbied against such legislation.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Finds Strong Public Support for Organic Foods
DOC.TEXT: Advocates of organically grown fruits and vegetables say a new poll shows that the popularity of produce grown without chemical fertilizers and pesticides is more than just a passing fad. The Louis Harris poll being released Monday does show, however, that national publicity about possible pesticide dangers has prompted more people to try organic produce. The 1989 survey found that 84 percent of Americans would prefer organically grown fruits and vegetables, the same percentage as in a similar poll conducted in 1988. The first poll was taken before a deluge of negative publicity about Alar, a chemical used in growing apples that was taken off the market after reports that it might cause cancer. ``This shows that the organic mandate is not a passing fad fueled by fear, but a clear preference fueled by reason,'' said Stevie Daniels, executive editor of Organic Gardening magazine, which commissioned the survey. ``With organic food gaining faster acceptance, the lack of a federal organic standard is often cited as the reason why such foods are not more readily available at large supermarket chains,'' said Organic Gardening analysts. ``The large retailers are looking for a USDA label to make sure they have a label the consumers will understand,'' Daniels said. Some 30 percent of those surveyed said they had changed their eating habits, of whom 28 percent actually sought out organically grown food. The latest survey found a big increase in the percentage of people who had eaten organically grown food. Nearly 58 percent of those surveyed in 1989 reported they had eaten organic foods, up from 38 percent a year earlier. The increase shows the increasing popularity of organic foods after the negative pesticide reports of 1989, according to Organic Gardening's analysts. The reason given by 65 percent of the respondents for eating organically grown food was long-term health effects. The next largest group, 19.5 percent, cited nutritional value. More than 52 percent said they would buy organically grown produce even if it cost more, down from 58 percent in the 1988 survey. Eighty-four percent said they would buy organic foods if they cost the same, virtually the same percentage as a year earlier. Interviews for the nationwide poll were conducted by telephone between Nov. 6 and Dec. 13, 1989. The previous survey was done between Nov. 9 and Dec. 23, 1988. Sampling error for the results is plus or minus 3 percentage points. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, has introduced legislation that would set a national standard enabling qualified growers to label their produce ``organically produced.'' The bill would: _Prohibit farmers from using synthetic chemicals for at least three years before their products could be labeled organic. _Mandate periodic residue testing and periodic unannounced site inspections. _Allow states and-or independent agencies to run the certification programs. _Allow states to enact stronger standards. Leahy said the bill is designed to reduce consumer confusion over self-proclaimed organic, or ``natural'' foods. ``It's downright dishonest to call foods `natural' when they are grown with heavy doses of toxic chemicals,'' Leahy said in a statement after introducing his bill. ``Increased demand for organic foods will help farmers save money in pesticide costs and protect them from overexposure to toxic chemicals,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Single-Parent Families Impoverishing Youths
DOC.TEXT: The United States trails its foreign competitors in the health and care of children and fares poorly in a comparison of child poverty rates, a House committee reported Sunday. The report by the House Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families said the United States has the highest percentage of children affected by divorce and its male youths are far more likely to be murdered than those in other developed nations. ``What this shows is there are some very serious questions about the status of America's children when compared to others,'' said the panel's chairman, Rep. George Miller, D-Calif. The committee based the report on a new study by the U.S. Census Bureau's center for international research, which compared statistics on U.S. children with those of 11 other nations. Among its findings: _U.S. children experience the highest parental divorce rate. One in four children now live in single-parent families, which have higher poverty rates than two-parent families. The proportion of children living in single-parent families increased since 1960 in all 12 countries but the gap between the United States and the 11 others widened. _Among six industrialized countries, the United States and Australia had the highest poverty rates among families with children, 15 percent and 14 percent respectively, even after tax and transfer benefits were applied. _At least 99 percent of poor families with children in the other developed countries received government assistance, compared to 73 percent in the United States. _The rate of teenage pregnancy was highest in the United States than other countries examined. _Infant mortality rates ranged from a low of 5 deaths per 1,000 live births in Japan to 25 deaths per 1,000 in the Soviet Union. The U.S. rate was 10 deaths per 1,000 live births, equal to or worse than nine countries. _The United States had a murder rate for male youths four to five times that of other developed countries. But Mexico had a rate twice that of the United States. _The United States compared favorably in rates of youth unemployment and suicide. Miller said statistics on infant mortality show the United States does a good job of saving ill babies that would have died in less developed countries. But low average birth weights suggest the United States does a poor job of prenatal care, he said. ``It's lack of will,'' Miller said. ``We're not willing to spend those preventative dollars. It's criminal, really.'' He said the comparisons suggest the United States will not meet goals set by President Bush to make the United States rank first in science and math education by the end of the 1990s. The report compared 12 industrialized countries: Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hungary, Italy, Japan, Norway, Soviet Union, Sweden, United States. It also provided some information on four countries listed as developing: Israel, Mexico, India and China. The study used various types of data from the countries, and comparisons often were based on figures from different years. In a minority report, Republicans on the committee said such variations limit its value. They said the report ``cannot be used as evidence to prove that a new child policy agenda is needed.'' Republicans said the most significant comparison showed the United States has the highest proportion of single-parent families. ``While 22.9 percent of family households in the United States are headed by a single-parent, less than 6 percent of households in Japan are headed by a single parent,'' they said. ``This factor has widespread implications for many indicators, including poverty, infant mortality rates, teenage pregnancy rates, abortions, out-of-wedlock births and even educational achievement,'' the Republicans said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Dissidents Meet Together For First Time
DOC.TEXT: A dream Vaclav Havel cherished through years of persecution came true Sunday: the brave 2,000 people of Charter 77, Eastern Europe's oldest human rights movement, met for the first time. They were packed into the elegant Prague building where Havel last November negotiated the overthrow of Stalinism with Communist leaders. Aged men, bent old women, bearded hippies and fresh-faced youth relished their freedom to be together at last. ``The feeling is excellent,'' beamed Petr Pospichal, a longtime dissident who works for Civic Forum, the movement born out of Charter that overturned Communist rule last fall. ``After all these years, we just now realize how many we are.'' ``For many years,'' prisoner-turned-president Havel said in brief opening remarks, ``I had a dream. I had this dream when I was free, but more often when I was in prison. ``It was a dream that all signatories of Charter 77 would meet one day in some Prague hall, and will talk without being disturbed by the police. This dream, this archetypal vision, is being fulfilled today.'' But the joy for Havel, and many others, was tinged with grief for those who did not live to see the triumph of the 13-year struggle waged by Eastern Europe's oldest, and arguably most diverse, movement for freedom and human dignity. Among those mourned was Jan Patocka, a philosopher who like Havel was one of the first signatories of Charter 77. He was one of its first spokesmen and spiritual father of its vision of founding a civic society in which free citizens take responsibility for their actions. Patocka died in March 1977, two months after Charter was born, after intensive police interrogation. Charter, whose ideals are now expressed in state policy rather than underground literature circulated among friends, was unique in Eastern Europe in uniting many different strands of thought. It began as an association of 240 intellectuals who signed a New Year manifesto protesting the suppression of freedom in Czechoslovakia, and grew to become one of the most vigorous supporters of human rights in Eastern Europe. In Charter, religious activists worked with ex-Communists expelled from the party in the purges that followed the crushing of reform in 1968, wildly unconventional rock musicians met staid intellectuals, young peace campaigners aligned with aging, pre-World War II democrats. Maintaining that unity will be the tough task facing Chartists in Civic Forum after free elections June 8, in which it is expected to garner the largest share of the vote. These are very different worries from those of the past 13 years battling the repression of Communist rulers who feared such broad and potentially dangerous dissent. Men like Havel and Jiri Dienstbier, now Foreign Minister in the post-revolutionary government, were constantly detained, interrogated, watched and jailed. The harassment brought them international renown as defenders of human rights and democracy in Czechoslovakia and Eastern Europe as a whole. But Charter was also signed by hundreds of lesser-known individuals who braved persecution to subscribe to the founding document's ideals, exercising what Havel, in a famous 1975 essay, dubbed ``the power of the powerless.'' Stanislav Stransky, an upright 68-year-old, was one of those. First jailed in 1948 by the Communists and forced all his life to work only at menial, manual labor, he helped Charter by maintaining an illegal printing press. For him, Sunday was a great day, ``because I met all these people I only ever heard about.'' During the Communists' rule, Chartists considered a gathering of even 30 of their number a success over the secret police. On Sunday, about 2,000 people came from all over the country to chat, listen to speeches and buy the once-underground publications that as recently as last October earned their editors months in jail. Mulling the future, however, Jan Urban, a prominent former dissident who now heads Civic Forum, found trepidation clouding his joy. ``On the one hand, it's beautiful to see all these people together and to feel that something has happened,'' Urban said. ``On the other hand, it's frightening to see what may happen very soon in this country, to see that after so many years of no politics, people aren't prepared for the problems they will face.'' Under a Stalinist system which politicized everything except politics itself, Charter tried to initiate debate and a broad range of political thought. Its members typed out by hand hundreds of documents discussing issues from the environment to ethnic tensions, the economy to women's rights. It was this activity that enabled Civic Forum to assume control within just three weeks when the Communist hold on power crumbled last November. ``Discussing all those things for such a long time, it made us ready to serve,'' Urban said. ``At a moment of crisis, people were able to go not to a stoker's place (Dienstbier`s former job), but to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.''

DOC.HEAD: Najib Says Ruling Party Should Surrender Monopoly on Power
LaserPhoto BK1
DOC.TEXT: President Najib told his ruling Communist Party on Sunday that it should surrender its monopoly on power and hold a special session to write the change into the constitution. The announcement was made during a meeting of the Central Committee of the ruling People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan. The meeting also debated changing the ruling party's name. One choice favored by liberals was the National Unity Party. Another, the People's Party, was supported by hard-liners. No decision was made. ``The party should take voluntary, legal steps to cancel its privileged status,'' Najib said in a speech to the Central Committee, according to the official Bakhtar news agency. ``We must give up our monopoly on power.'' The meeting also removed 24 Central Committee members, but this did not reduce the party's hold on power, as its members retained control over all government ministries. Najib's speech was seen as an attempt to make himself and his party more acceptable to U.S.-backed guerrilla groups, which have been fighting his party more than a decade. Following the withdrawal of Soviet troops last year, the guerrillas said Najib must step down before peace talks could begin. Afghan government officials said they interpreted Najib's tentative steps toward political reforms as a sign of his weakness and perhaps of the Soviet Union's unwillingness to back large-scale change in Afghanistan. The Soviet Union is Afghanistan's closest military and economic ally. The Central Committee meeting was attended by high-ranking Soviet diplomats and officials from the Soviet Foreign Ministry, Afghan government officials said. Diplomats in Kabul have said a March 6 coup attempt has brought Najib to his weakest position since being installed as president in 1986. A high-ranking government official said Sunday that about half of the officers in the military are being replaced following the insurrection. The coup attempt was led by Shah Nawz Tanai, who was defense minister at the time. National security remains compromised because Tanai escaped and joined forces with the guerrillas. Najib called for a meeting to modify references in Afghanistan's constitution to the ``guiding role'' the party plays in national affairs. The National Assembly meeting would be held within two months, a government official said. It would include representatives from Afghanistan's largely powerless National Assembly along with appointed members from government ministries and important tribes around the country. ``In spite of all our success, war still continues and the people still suffer,'' Najib said. ``But we have taken steps toward giving up the monopoly on power. Recently we've been going slowly. We need to accelerate the trend toward democracy in our society.'' Najib also said the ruling party would meet soon to revise the party's charter, removing references to its Marxist past. The structure of the People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan remains Leninist, but over the last few years its ideology has begun to change from Communist to nationalist. Free enterprise flourishes in Kabul, and the government has lately begun allowing state-owned enterprises, such as Ariana Airlines and the Continental Hotel, to operate as private businesses. Eastern European diplomats cautioned against making parallels between Afghanistan and Eastern Europe, where hard-line Communist leaders have been ousted from power by popular revolutions that Moscow allowed to proceed. ``Moscow doesn't deal with Kabul the way it does with Budapest,'' said one diplomat. ``It treats Kabul like it treated us in the 1950s. Afghanistan is more like a colony. We, at least, are becoming independent.'' Diplomats in Kabul say Moscow does not want Najib to adopt reforms too quickly because that could hurt the bargaining position with the United States, the main supporter of the guerrilla groups, in future negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Ann Landers says ``a lot of people need professional help,'' including those who write excessively long letters to advice columnists. The veteran agony aunt said she skimmed through 1,500 letters on a flight Friday from Chicago to Seattle where she spoke to the Northwest Women's Show. Letters on old themes, like those from teen-agers asking how to get more attention from a potential mate, can be boring, she admitted. And, naturally, she prefers letters that are reasonably concise. ``Sometimes I'll get people who write 14 pages or so, but those people are probably psychotic, though,'' she said. ``I tell them they need professional help. You know, a lot of people need professional help.'' One recurrent theme is whether toilet paper should be hung over the top or down against the wall. ``I'm very compulsive about it,'' she said. ``The toilet paper needs to be hung down along the wall. I'll actually rearrange it myself if I'm over at someone's home and I see it hung over the top.''

Dennis Quaid's surprise when a doctor made a house call during filming of ``The Big Easy'' in 1984 got the actor involved in trips to Central America as a chaperone of ailing children. ``I just couldn't believe a doctor made a house call for me, and I told him if there was ever anything I could do for him, ... '' Quaid said. ``And he returned with, `As a matter of fact ...''' The doctor was Mayer Heiman, who has brought more than 100 sick children from the world's poorest regions for treatment in U.S. hospitals since he founded the International Hospital for Children in 1981. Quaid returned to New Orleans on Saturday from his second trip to Central America, escorting six children ranging in age from 6 months to 12 years. The youngest child, a Honduran, will have open-heart surgery. The oldest, from El Salvador, will be treated for eye problems. ``This is such a special program for me because I get to work directly with the children. It's a real hands-on experience,'' Quaid said, smiling at a 3-year-old girl in his arms. ``Everyone wants to do something in their life that helps others,'' he said. ``If you save just one soul, then you feel like you've saved the whole world.''

Audrey Hepburn will team up with a symphony orchestra to tell the story of Holocaust victim Anne Frank in music and words. Miss Hepburn said she identified closely with the girl who retained innocent hopes for the world despite her own predicament. She will narrate ``From the Diary of Anne Frank'' at its premiere Monday night, the first of four ``Concerts for Life'' in aid of the United Nations Children's Fund. ``It's a very, very important piece of music,'' said the 60-year-old actress, who collaborated with composer Michael Tilson Thomas. ``I feel very privileged to be allowed to be the first one.'' ``If the words of Anne Frank have lived this long without it, they will live forever with this music,'' she said. Miss Hepburn re-entered public life two years ago as a UNICEF goodwill ambassador to help the world's needy children. Though she retired from movies in 1965, she made a cameo appearance in Steven Spielberg's ``Always,'' released in December. Miss Hepburn will narrate while Thomas conducts the New World Symphony at the concert in the Academy of Music. Other concerts will be held in Chicago on Wednesday, in Houston on Friday and before the U.N. General Assembly in New York City next Sunday. Miss Frank, a Jewish teen-ager, and her family hid for two years in an Amsterdam office building during World War II before being captured by the Nazis. She later died in a concentration camp. Her diary was first published in 1947. Miss Hepburn was born the same year as Miss Frank and lived in Holland during the war.

Marc Summers, who is host of ``Super Sloppy Double Dare,'' isn't sure why the messy stunts in the cable TV game show are so appealing to so many kids. Young contestants bombard each other with soda water and bananas, or wade through molasses and baked beans, to earn points. ``There are some things about our show that I'll never understand,'' Summers said. He brought the show to Dallas to give its fans a close-up look at the mayhem. Summers knows of at least one adult who thinks the show isn't the least bit funny. While passing out Halloween candy at his home last fall, one woman realized who he was. ``She took one look at me and said, `You're that guy on ``Double Dare!'' I hate your guts!''' Apparently, her son had duplicated a stunt from the show by creating an obstacle course of ground coffee through the family living room. ``I thought she was going to kill me,'' Summers said.

DOC.HEAD: Election Day Is Emotional Time For East Germans
With AM-Germany-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Annelisa Schoen choked backed tears of joy as she tried to express her feelings about East Germany's first free elections Sunday. ``This is the greatest day of my life after being put down all these years,'' whispered the 66-year-old woman. After four decades of Communist rule, East German voters were filled with emotion and enthusiasm as they lined up at city polling stations, and in rural areas at makeshift voting booths in pubs and eateries. Adelgund Fernschild cast her ballot from a hospital bed in Leipzig. Even former Communist Party functionaries and leaders being held for alleged abuses in office were allowed to vote, the official ADN news agency said. ``Before I couldn't choose. I could only hand in my ballot, and today I can choose between many. This is a very special day,'' said Elfriede Matzko, 53, as she strolled along in the sunshine after voting. Her family was divided over the best candidate, and her daughter voted for the Communists. ``But I am 53, and she is in her 20s. That makes a lot of difference. I never could accept that they built the Wall, and refused to let us travel for no reason,'' Mrs. Matzko said. She said she was looking forward to German unification. ``I think we will have a good future. This is a very special day.'' Karsten Simmert, 24, a trampoline artist with the East German state circus, said he went to the polls first thing Sunday morning. ``I had the feeling that my vote counts. That I am helping to decide something special,'' Simmert said. Ines Hohenstein, 27, brought her 5-month-old son along in a stroller. ``We are very anxiously waiting to see what the results will be tonight. We'll be in front of the television waiting for the results,'' she said. ``My husband Hans and I are of the opinion that something must happen here and that it won't come with the Social Democrats or the Communists. We are going to vote CDU,'' Mrs. Hohenstein said. She was referring to the Alliance for Germany, a coalition of three parties supported by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. About 12.2 million East Germans were eligible to vote in the parliamentary elections, and they had 24 parties and organizations to choose from. The broad slate perplexed some East Germans. ``Of course we're all happy that we can vote,'' said Christel Wilke, a poll supervisor at a makeshift booth in a restaurant in the village of Schoenwalde, 18 miles north of Berlin. ``But we have nothing we can draw from, no experience with the new parties that we can use as a measure. There's no way we can know if we are voting for the right person.'' Most polling places opened at 7 a.m., but many shift workers in industry were permitted to start voting two hours earlier. Wolfgang Koegel, an employee at a power plant in the southwestern city of Suhl, was the first to vote in his district. ``No one really knows who's going to be elected. But by all means I am for a better future, especially when I think about my two children,'' he told the ADN news agency. Even prison inmates were able to vote. According to ADN, prisons throughout the country set up private voting areas.

DOC.HEAD: Aftershock of Upland Quake Rattles Southern California
DOC.TEXT: A small aftershock of the quake that rocked Upland last month jolted Southern Californians awake early Sunday, but no damage or injuries were reported. The aftershock struck at 5:56 a.m. and measured 3.3 on the Richter scale, said Robert Finn, a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. Its epicenter was 3 miles northwest of Upland, he said. The Feb. 28 Upland earthquake measured 5.5 on the Richter scale and caused nearly $13 million damage, the state Office of Emergency Services estimated. Upland is 40 miles east of downtown Los Angeles. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of magnitude 2 is the smallest normally felt by humans, while a quake of magnitude 3 can cause slight damage. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Aspin: No Decision on B-2 Funding Until Air Force Turns Over Test Data
With AM-Soviet Threat Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force has failed to provide Congress critical data on the B-2 stealth bomber, making it difficult for lawmakers to take up the Pentagon's budget request, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee says. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., in a letter to Air Force Secretary Donald Rice released Sunday, said his panel some time ago had sought the results of laboratory and scale-model tests of the radar-evading characteristics of the B-2. ``Regrettably, the Air Force has, to date, not submitted this essential information to appropriately cleared committee staff members,'' Aspin said in the letter dated March 12. Aspin said it would be ``difficult, if not impossible'' for the committee to consider the Bush administration's fiscal 1991 budget request for the stealth bomber. President Bush has proposed spending $5.5 billion and procuring five B-2s in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The administration hopes to buy 132 planes, considered the most expensive in history, for a total cost of $70 billion. Air Force spokesman Maj. Dick Cole said Friday that Rice spoke to Aspin on Tuesday, the day after the letter was written, and pledged the service's full cooperation. A congressional source, who requested anonymity, said Friday that the panel's chairman had received assurances that the information will be forthcoming, but the committee still had not received the data, which the Air Force has withheld despite repeated requests. In a separate letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, dated March 9, Aspin asked the Pentagon chief to provide to the committee by March 31 an analysis of alternative plans for buying the stealth bomber. The pricetag of $530 million per plane has sent shock waves through Congress. Lawmakers have questioned investing in a costly bomber in light of the rapid changes in Eastern Europe. ``It is essential that the committee understand precisely the implications of reducing B-2 production for fiscal year 1991 and beyond,'' Aspin wrote Cheney. The chairman suggested that the analysis consider the cost and impact of reducing the buy of bombers in fiscal 1991 from five to zero, one, two or three planes. Those same series of purchases should be assessed for fiscal 1992, fiscal 1992-1993 and fiscal 1992-1994. The Pentagon, in arguing for the fleet of 132 bombers, has said any reduction in the buy will increase the cost of a single plane to nearly $1 billion a copy. The department has invested more than $23 billion in the program to date.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: The sky's the ceiling for Karla Taylor. Ms. Taylor specializes in painting skyscapes dotted with majestic clouds on people's ceilings. But don't ask her to include un-sky-like things. Stars and moons are OK; but no cars and no balloons. ``I had a request to do balloons,'' she said. ``I knew that was not going to look good. All you would see would be the bottom of the balloon.'' Her parents might well be to blame for her artistic proclivities. Her father was a house painter, her mother an artist. A ceiling takes about three days to complete and, for an average room, the bill would be about $400, she said. Her business is looking up, she says, but not all the time. On her studio floor, she's painted a rug.

Can a television show that depicts Cincinnati as a Midwestern backwater help the city's image? Sure can, say local leaders, if it's ``WKRP in Cincinnati.'' The comedy series about the goings-on at a fictional Cincinnati radio station is a welcomed contrast for a city bedeviled by the Pete Rose gambling investigation and pollution problems at the nearby Fernald uranium processing plant. ``I don't mind `WKRP,''' Mayor Charles Luken said. ``Obviously, it makes us seem less than cosmopolitan on occasion. But I take the attention the city can get where I can get it.'' Producers hope to sell a syndicated version of ``WKRP in Cincinnati'' to individual TV stations in the fall of 1991. The original 90 episodes were first broadcast on CBS from 1978 to 1982. ``If you're asking if 10 companies will make their relocation decision based on the revival of `WKRP in Cincinnati,' that probably won't happen,'' said Roger Ruhl of the Greater Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce. ``But is it a plus in Cincinnati's image arsenal? Yes. It certainly creates an awareness or a hook to the city.'' When Lois Smith joined the Greater Cincinnati Convention and Visitors Bureau in the 1970s, the city didn't have much that outsiders knew about. ``But once WKRP hit, it was immediate recognition,'' she said. ``It was one of the greatest things that ever happened to us, publicity-wise.'' At travel and trade shows, the visitors bureau began giving away T-shirts with a Cincinnati skyline and the letters WKRP. The souvenir shirts were grabbed up as fast as they were offered, she said. Mike Rozow, vice president of public affairs and tourism for the visitors bureau, is no less enthusiastic. ``It certainly isn't harmful to the image of the city,'' he said. ``It's a fun show. ``We're not talking about a show that deals with brain surgery here. It's a show that people enjoy. That enjoyability is translated into the name of Cincinnati.''

DOC.HEAD: Communists' Advisory Body Begins Annual Meeting
LaserPhoto BEJ1
DOC.TEXT: More than 2,000 deputies from the ruling Communist Party and other political and social groups began their annual meeting Sunday, and Communist leaders urged them to improve their ties with the masses. The deputies gathered at the Great Hall of the People for the 12-day meeting of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, an advisory body that serves as a link between the Communists and other groups. Chairman Li Xiannian, China's former president, presided over the gathering, which included delegates from China's eight sanctioned ``democratic'' parties and various mass organizations. The conference is held each spring concurrently with the annual session of the National People's Congress, China's legislature. The congress is to open its meeting Tuesday. The consultative conference has no political power and is involved mainly in carrying out investigations and offering suggestions to the Communist Party and the state on various social and economic problems. The meeting is receiving attention this year. The Communist Party, jolted by the collapse of Communist governments in Eastern Europe, stresses the advantages of its system of Communist rule supplemented by cooperation with non-Communist groups. Party leaders urged members to establish better ties with the masses, to listen more closely to the ideas of the loyalist democratic parties, and to promote more non-Communists to government positions. ``Multiparty cooperation under the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party must be persisted in and perfected and must not be negated or weakened,'' the party's official People's Daily said in a commentary marking the start of the meeting. The daily said it hoped consultative conference members will ``speak their minds freely, be active in offering suggestions and ... contribute to the country's stability and development.'' Conference Deputy Secretary General Lu Zhichao said Saturday the body ``contributes to scientific and democratic decision-making.'' He also stressed the conference's ``full endorsement and support'' for the political and economic policies of the party, including the military suppression of the student-led pro-democracy movement last spring.

DOC.HEAD: Carter Says Syria Ready for Peace Talks With Israel
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter said Sunday he believes Syrian leader Hafez Assad is ready to negotiate peace with Israel. Carter told The Associated Press that after talks with the Syrian president Thursday, he felt that Assad is ``ready to make peace, under the framework of an international conference.'' Carter, on the fourth leg of his Middle East tour, said such a conference could set the stage for the direct negotiations that Israel has sought. ``President Assad has told me ... that he would be very glad to have bilateral direct talks with Israel to resolve all the differences, including the Golan Heights,'' Carter told reporters. Asked if he believed that Assad would be ready to compromise on the Golan, he said: ``I am not authorized to say, but I think he would negotiate in good faith.'' Israel captured the 450-square-mile Golan Heights in the 1967 Middle East war and annexed it in 1981. Israel has insisted the strategic heights, which overlook the Sea of Galilee, are essential to its security. A newspaper in the United Arab Emirates reported Sunday that Syria will demilitarize the Golan Heights if Israel withdraws its troops from the territory. The government-owned Al-Bayan said this was the outcome of talks between the United States and Syria. The paper did not say where or when the talks took place. It said they were ``secret and high-level.'' Carter met with Labor Party leader Shimon Peres, who told parliament last week he ``received information from an authoritative source that the Syrians are proposing peace negotiations, demilitarizing the Golan Heights.'' He refused to say if he believed Assad would agree to demilitarization. U.N. peacekeepers have separated the two armies in the Golan since former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger negotiated an agreement in 1974. Israel radio quoted Carter as telling Peres that Syria would be willing to join in negotiations if there was progress in proposed Israeli-Palestinian talks. Syria, as well as nearly all Arab countries in the Middle East, has refused to officially recognize Israel and has remained in a technical state of war with the Jewish state since its establishment in 1948. Only Egypt has signed a peace treaty with Israel in return for the Sinai peninsula captured from it in the 1967 Middle East war. Carter mediated in 1978 the peace treaty, known as the Camp David Accords. Carter also met with caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of the right-wing Likud Bloc. Aides quoted Shamir as saying he was ready to continue peace efforts on the basis of Carter's autonomy plan for the occupied lands ``without the deviations that some have tried to impose upon it.'' Shamir referred to recent U.S. efforts to get concessions from him on the participation of east Jerusalem Arabs in a proposed Palestinian-Israeli dialogue and subsequent elections.

DOC.HEAD: 15 Die in Supermarket Fire in Japan
LaserPhotos TOK4,6
DOC.TEXT: A fire in a supermarket Sunday killed 15 people and injured six, including two who jumped from a fifth-floor window to escape the smoke and flames, officials said. It took 57 fire engines three hours to put out the blaze at the Nagasakiya store in Amagasaki, 300 miles west of Tokyo, said fire official Hiroshi Kawamoto. The cause of the fire was being investigated. Kawamoto said the fire broke out on the fourth floor of the five-story supermarket shortly after noon. He said all 15 fatalities probably died of smoke and gas inhalation. The victims were found on the fifth floor, where the employees' cafeteria, offices, a storage area and a game center are located. Of the six injured people, two were in the game center when the fire broke out and jumped from a window. They were seriously injured by their falls. Kyodo News Service quoted employee Shizue Nomura, 70, as saying she was having lunch in the employees' cafeteria with several others at noon. ``I heard the words, `Fire! Fire!' and tried to flee, but smoke suddenly came down on us,'' she said. Mrs. Nomura said she and three other people were able to escape by climbing down from the roof to a neighboring building. The fire was the worst in a large retail store in Japan since 1973, when more than 100 people were killed in a fire at Taiyo Department Store in Kumamoto. Nagasakiya operates 122 stores throughout Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Bound For Namibia And South African, Angolan Peace Moves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Baker leaves at 5 p.m. EST; Should stand
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III is off to Africa on Sunday with the aim of helping to end apartheid in South Africa and seeking a cease-fire in a 14-year war in Angola. In five fast-paced days, Baker also will attend ceremonies marking the independence of Namibia and hold meetings with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. The celebration of a new nation's birth, attended by dozens of world leaders in Windhoek, the Namibian capital, is a springboard for Baker to meet also with Nelson Mandela, the South African black activist, and with Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos. Baker's aides made clear before his departure that the Bush administration has no intention of yielding to Mandela's demands for stiffer sanctions against South Africa and that it would not recognize Angola until the Luanda government settles with the U.S.-armed UNITA rebels based in the southern part of the country. But Baker also is ready to assure Mandela that the administration would keep pressuring President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa to free all political prisoners and to end a 3 1@2-year state of emergency. That stance puts Baker somewhere between the Mandela and de Klerk camps. His plan on Angola, meanwhile, is to seize on the current military stalemate to call for negotiations between the government and UNITA rebels headed by Jonas Savimbi. Savimbi receives $35 million to $40 million in covert U.S. aid annually, according to congressional sources. Baker will follow up on his Windhoek talks by seeing de Klerk and Foreign Minister R.F. Botha in South Africa on Thursday. On Friday, Baker's aides said he would tour Soweto, the black township outside of Johannesburg and visit with Walter Sisulu, an African National Congress official like Mandela, and Archbishop Desmond Tutu, a anti-apartheid activist. Later in the day, Baker will fly to Zaire for a meeting with Jonas Savimbi, the head of the UNITA group. But Sisulu said in a telephone interview in South Africa that he and his wife, Albertina, will skip the meeting with Baker because the couple has plans to travel to London on March 21. Two other ANC officials, Govan Mbeki and Raymond Mhlaba, will likely see Baker, Sisulu said. Tutu said he expects to meet Baker, but details have yet to be confirmed. Tutu's aides said the meeting might be held in Cape Town rather than Johannesburg. Mandela, whose meeting with Baker is to take place in Namibia, has refused to see the American official on South African soil, saying he opposes ``high-profile visits'' to South Africa. ``They (the visits) suggest that President de Klerk has done something positive, something fundamental which requires the world to review sanctions ...,'' he said. De Klerk, who freed Mandela from prison last month, has invited the 71-year-old Mandela and exiled black leaders to begin negotiations on April 11. The move was welcomed by the State Department. Both sides _ the white community and black majority _ were credited with deciding to approach an end to apartheid through negotiations rather than confrontation. ``We're very happy at most recent developments, which we think represents a real change in the thinking in that country,'' a senior U.S. official said Friday. In Angola, Baker believes the time is right to promote a cease-fire in part because the two sides have been at a military stand-off in Mavinga, a Savimbi stronghold, since December. The United States is alone among Western countries in withholding diplomatic recognition to Angola, although that country has developed a private economy and ships 75 percent of its oil to the United States through Chevron and Conoco. Washington has protested Soviet support for Angola and the presence of Cuban troops in the country. About half of the 50,000 Cubans have left under a complex agreement that also ended South African control over Namibia. The rest are supposed to depart by next year. But Soviet aid, even though it is decreasing, ``continues to be humongous.'' the senior U.S. official said. ``We're talking about a decrease from about a billion dollars a year to $600 million.'' ``We're not asking for the overthrow of the government,'' the official said. ``We are not asking for any type of regime. We're not asking that Jonas Savimbi be made president of Angola.'' Signalling U.S. conciliation, he went on: ``All we're asking for is for the government of Angola to reconcile with a major dissident organization which represents a significant number of Angolan people.'' In the event of ``a new political order,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, ``we will be very happy to bow out.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Team Divided on Soviet Threat, Defense Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Disagreement inside the Bush administration over the possibility that drastic changes in the Soviet Union will be reversed is raising new questions about the size of the U.S. defense budget. While CIA Director William Webster testified earlier this month the political changes in the Soviet Bloc are irreversible, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has maintained that Moscow could reassume its former confrontational pose. Treasury Secretary Nicholas S. Brady said Sunday that the administration is still sticking with Cheney's proposed $3.2 billion cut in inflation-adjusted defense spending for fiscal 1991 beginning next Oct. 1. ``Three billion dollars is it; that's what Secretary Cheney says; that's what it is,'' Brady said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation'' program. ``That's our position at this point in time.'' Webster's testimony, however, is one indication of disagreement within the administration, particularly between Cheney and White House Budget Director Richard Darman, over whether bigger defense cuts might be acceptable. A senior White House official who refused to allow his name used was quoted by The New York Times on Sunday as saying the ``irreversibility'' of changes in the Soviet Union makes deeper military spending cuts possible. The newspaper quoted senior administration officials as saying they were willing to acquiesce to total cuts of $10 billion to $11 billion but adding that Cheney was still fighting ``the emerging consensus.'' A cut of $10 billion to $11 billion would produce a fiscal 1991 defense budget of $296 billion to $297 billion defense, roughly the same as this year, compared to the $303 billion Pentagon spending plan that Bush submitted to Congress in January. Brady called the Times story inaccurate, saying, ``I've sat in all of these discussions and there has been no talk about a $10 billion cut.'' Meanwhile, Senate Budget Committee Chairman Jim Sasser, D-Tenn., called Sunday for a $20 billion cut in the Pentagon's budget or ``3 percent less for defense than what we spent last year.'' Bolstering the case for further slashes in defense spending was the House Armed Services Committee chairman's interpretation last week of a classified Joint Chiefs of Staff assessment of military strength. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said the service chiefs now believe the United States and its allies could fight and hold off the Soviet Union in Europe without resorting to nuclear weapons. ``I look at this net assessment and I say, we win. We can go the other way. NATO wins, the good guys win,'' Aspin said. The Pentagon based its assessment on the Soviet Union's unilateral troop reductions announced by President Mikhail Gorbachev in December 1988 and the U.S. intelligence community's conclusion last year that the Soviet threat has lessened. The Joint Chiefs also took into account the U.S.-Soviet treaty expected later this year to reduce conventional forces. That pact would create an imbalance with the United States keeping 30,000 troops on the flanks in addition to the 195,000 U.S. and Soviet forces in Central Europe. One aspect under fire in Cheney's spending plan is an $80 million increase over last year to develop a short-range nuclear missile as a replacement for the ground-based Lance missile. The new missile would be deployed principally in West Germany, but officials there have criticized creating a weapon that's principal targets would be in East Germany, Poland or Czechoslovakia. ``The follow-on to the Lance does not make sense given the change in the European borders,'' said Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee. McCurdy said the administration's call for the program reflects a ``policy that has not caught up to the reality of the environment.'' Aspin predicted last week that Congress would not fund the Pentagon's request of $112 million for the program. Democrats say Webster's comments juxtaposed against Cheney's failure to take advantage of the changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union provide them with an opening to craft their own defense agenda for the future. ``This gives the Democrats the opportunity to establish policy in this vacuum that's good for America and good for the party,'' said McCurdy. Another top member of the panel, Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass., said Cheney's five-year defense plan should be forthcoming and once that is in hand, the Democrats should put forth their own policy. ``The Democratic Party has got to strike out. We have not done that,'' Mavroules said last week. ``We have to take both arguments (Cheney and Webster) and then formulate our own policy.'' Republicans contend Democrats will continue to argue for significant cuts in defense spending but will turn parochial when it comes to determining where the cuts will be made. ``The real battle is in the jobs bill,'' Rep. John Rowland, R-Conn., said of the defense budget. ``I've never seen such confusion or indecision.'' The oft-stated GOP strategy is to paint the Democrats as budget-conscious only when someone else's district is involved.

DOC.HEAD: Nobel Prize Raised to $653,000
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to ADD value of prizes in 1901 in today's terms.
DOC.TEXT: The money awarded to Nobel Prize winners is being raised this year to $653,000 each from $489,000, the head of the Nobel Foundation was quoted as saying Sunday. The foundation is hoping to eventually make the prize _ after inflation _ worth what it was in 1901, said Stig Ramel. His comments appeared in the Svenska Dagbladet. In 1901, the first year the Nobels were awarded, the prize money was 150,000 kronor. In today's terms, that would be $784,000. Last year's prizes were worth about $489,000 each. Svenska Dagbladet said this year's increase in prize money was secured by a planned sale of the foundation's 22 percent stake in the real estate company Bevaringen. Further increases are planned. The inventor of dynamite, Alfred Nobel, created the Nobel prizes in physics, chemistry, medicine, literature and peace. In 1968, Sweden's central bank instituted a sixth prize, the Nobel memorial economics prize, which carries the same prize sum as the others. The Nobels are awarded in September and October.

DOC.HEAD: Key Orthodox Party Changes Stand As Talks Open On New Cabinet, AMs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with rare TV appearance by Shas spiritual leader, INSERT 2 grafs after 7th pvs, `We believe...' Pickup 8th pvs, `The Shas'...'
DOC.TEXT: The small ultra-Orthodox religious faction that helped topple the Likud-led government announced Sunday it will support the right-wing Likud to form a new coalition government much like the last one. The announcement by the Shas, or Torah Guardians, came as President Chaim Herzog opened meetings with political leaders to decide who will form the next Cabinet. Shas legislator Yair Levy said his party based its recommendation on concerns that right-wing extremists could take control of the government and hamper peace efforts. ``So we asked that there be a national unity government in order to be able to advance the peace process,'' he told reporters. The Likud leader, Yitzhak Shamir, had refused to accept U.S.-backed compromises that would have sped up the long-stalled peace process. This led to his downfall Thursday in a vote of non-confidence in parliament. Five of the six Shas lawmakers abstained from supporting Shamir in the vote, which led to the collapse of the so-called unity government of Likud and the center-left Labor Party. ``We believe and hope that after what happened that even Likud will understand without a peace plan it is very difficult to exist,'' Levy said. In a rare TV appearance, Shas spiritual leader, Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, criticized Shamir's policy saying it ``invited bloodshed and war upon Israel.'' ``One man sins and everyone else must suffer?'' Yosef asked. He added that his party's move to continue to support Likud was based on sentiments of its constituents. The Shas' reversal may influence Herzog in naming the next prime minister. Israeli newspapers have reported that Labor leader Shimon Peres appeared to be Herzog's likely choice. Herzog was expected to announce his selection this week. But the actual formation of a government could take weeks or months as Likud and Labor seek to form alliances. The outcome depends greatly on four small religious parties, including Shas. Their 18 members in the Knesset, or parliament, hold the balance of power in the 120-seat body. The result could be a coalition of right-wing and religious parties led by Likud; a leftist-religious coalition headed by Labor; another Likud-Labor Cabinet or _ if all else fails _ new elections. Shamir remains caretaker prime minister until there is a new government. Labor is technically parliament's largest faction with 39 seats. Likud has 35 but also controls a five-seat liberal faction. Peres, 66, was quoted by the national Itim news agency as expressing confidence he could put together a governing coalition. ``There are 70 legislators who support the peace initiative, in my opinion,'' said Peres, listing religious, left-wing and Arab parties. ``However, I know the difficulty of getting everyone together under one roof.'' Levy said his party did not recommend who should lead Likud in forming the government, but the right-wing party's leaders called Sunday for the 74-year-old Shamir to again be given the task. Party leaders made the announcement after Likud parliament members headed off a rebellion against Shamir Saturday night with the surprise backing of former Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, the prime minister's arch rival. Sharon, who resigned from the Cabinet last month with sharp criticism of Shamir, praised the prime minister for standing up for Likud principles rather than accept the compromise and back U.S. peace proposals. ``With full awareness that he would lose his position and that the government would collapse, Shamir stood for our principles,'' Sharon said. ``We must support someone who would do that.'' Israeli news reports said some Labor and religious leaders want Herzog to name former Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin instead of Peres to form a new Labor-led government. Rabin is Labor's No. 2 man and a longtime rival of Peres for the party's leadership.

DOC.HEAD: Trial of Man Accused of Slaying Family, Starting New Life, Starts This Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: L'E. is cq in 14th graf
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY12
DOC.TEXT: A mild-mannered former consultant who authorities say killed his wife, mother and three children and then lived quietly for 18 years under an assumed name now passes his time in his jail cell reading the Bible. Lawyers for John E. List and prosecutors, meanwhile, are busy preparing for trial starting Tuesday and jockeying over whether a five-page letter List left behind, intended for his pastor, can be used as evidence. ``It's been categorized over the years as a somewhat detailed diary of events,'' said Lt. Bernard Tracy, the latest in a long line of Westfield detectives handling the case since 1971. Police believe that List's wife, Helen, 45; his 85-year-old mother, Alma; and their children Patricia, 16, John Jr., 15, and Frederick, 13, had been dead about a month when their bodies were found Dec. 7, 1971, in the mansion the family shared in Westfield, N.J., a New York City suburb. List, who had written notes to his children's teachers saying the family would be away for a few weeks, had vanished. Police were finally called to the house when neighbors noticed that lights that had been left on in the house had burned out. When authorities entered the house, they found religious music blaring from a radio and the wife and children's bodies lined up neatly in sleeping bags in the ballroom. List's mother's body was found in her upstairs apartment. All had been shot to death. Police also found the letter, addressed to List's pastor. Its contents have never been detailed, but reportedly, List claimed he was distraught over his family's wavering religious convictions. As police searched for List, the abandoned 18-room mansion became a landmark for thrill-seeking teen-agers. It burned down mysteriously a year after the bodies were found. List, now 63, remained at large until last June, when the crime was featured on the Fox television show ``America's Most Wanted,'' along with a plaster bust of what List might look like nearly two decades later. Several people recognized List as the man they knew as Robert P. Clark, a married accountant living in Midlothian, Va. Although Army fingerprint records showed that Clark and List were the same person, the defendant conceded only last month that he is indeed List. List's attorney, Elijah Miller Jr., said the concession was necessary for legal reasons to file the evidence motions. Prosecutors must still prove List's identity. Defense attorneys will argue that the police search of List's home was illegal and that the letter to his pastor is protected by ``priest-penitent'' privilege. Confidential communications with a pastor can be held privileged under New Jersey rules governing trial evidence. The state will argue that the letter ``does not meet the requirements of the evidence rule,'' said Assistant Prosecutor Eleanor Clark, declining to comment further. Even before the routine pretrial arguments are made, however, Superior Court Judge William L'E. Wertheimer said he will choose a jury, with selection to begin Tuesday. The jurors then will be sent home with instructions to ignore publicity about the case. Wertheimer imposed the unusual schedule _ pretrial motions are usually decided before jury selection _ to reduce the exposure of prospective jurors to news accounts. The judge said he will then decide pretrial matters, including the letter. The document has never been released, although authorities have discussed some of its contents. List felt his family's religious convictions were wavering and that he had to kill them for their own good, police familiar with the case said. Investigators also said List was in financial straits _ that he had two mortgages on the Westfield home, was failing as a financial consultant and had been siphoning money from his mother's $200,000 savings account. Others have said that List may have been distraught over his wife's drinking and his daughter's desire to be an actress. List gets few visitors as he awaits trial at the Union County Jail, said Warden Warren Maccarelli. He said List is separated from the general prison population for ``safety concerns'' and spends his time reading the Bible and other religious works. ``We continue to have him on our prayer list,'' said the Rev. Joseph M. Vought of the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour in Richmond, Va., where List, as Clark, was a member for several years. Aside from the letter, the state plans to introduce the usual evidence of murder trials: ballistics reports, medical and fingerprint evidence, and testimony by the officers who searched the house, the prosecutor said. Those pieces of evidence, even without the letter, are enough to bring List to trial, said Tracy. ``I think there are five real important pieces lying on the ground with bullet holes in them,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Americans Kidnapped Briefly in Mexico On Spring Break
DOC.TEXT: Four Americans on spring break were held against their will and threatened by a group of Mexicans before a police cruiser passed by and rescued them, Mexican police say. Three Matamoros, Mexico, residents face a judge Monday on charges of deprivation of freedom in the incident, which began early Friday. The three college students and a friend, all from the Oklahoma City area, had been visiting bars in Matamoros and were heading to the Gateway International Bridge to return to Brownsville when they accepted a ride, said Marland Crabtree, one of the Americans. ``As soon as we got in, they turned around and started to drive really fast,'' said Crabtree, 25. ``They drove us all over town going at about 100 miles an hour through city streets and running stop signs.'' Last year, a University of Texas student was kidnapped in Matamoros while on spring break and was killed at a nearby ranch, allegedly by members of a drug cult. Fourteen other bodies were also found at the ranch. Crabtree, his brother Darren, 19, Jeff Jones, 21, and a 19-year-old woman told police they were held for about three hours, threatened with death and taken to a vacant warehouse. The woman, who was not identified, said she was sexually molested. The abductors were ordering the Americans to go into the warehouse when Matamoros police officer Ruben Morales Gonzalez drove by about 3:30 a.m. ``I saw them there, and I thought it was strange for them to be at that side of town at those hours,'' said Gonzalez. ``When I stopped, one of them raced toward the car and told me they were taken against their will. Then I called for reinforcement.'' Darren Crabtree said the Americans feared for their lives when the abductors told them to go into the warehouse. ``At that point we thought they were going to kill us because last year those people got killed during spring break,'' said Marland Crabtree. ``They were telling us that we better go in because they had a gun.'' Gonzales said it was unlikely that he would have spotted the Americans if they had been in the car, since its windows were tinted black. The Oklahomans told the Brownsville Herald they could not get out of the car's back seat because it had electric-powered windows and child safety door locks. The Oklahomans were kept at the Matamoros jail until Friday afternoon because Mexican officials feared they would leave the country without telling a court reporter what had happened. The three men arrested were Jesus Rangel Gonzalez, Oscar Garcia Velazquez and Olga Lidia Castillo, all of Matamoros.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Killed In Black Factional Fighting In Natal Province
DOC.TEXT: Seven people were killed in fighting between black factions in Natal province, and one man was burned to death, police said Sunday. About 3,000 blacks have been killed since 1987 in Natal province in fighting between supporters of the African National Congress and members of Mangosuthu Buthelezi's Inkatha party. Buthelezi returned from a visit to Lusaka, Zambia, on Sunday and said that nation's president, Kenneth Kaunda, had offered to act as a mediator between the factions. Buthelezi said he had not asked Kaunda to take on the role, but that the president was the only person with the necessary credentials. ``He has the confidence of the ANC leadership and I have always had confidence in him _ and he has had no problem with me over the years,'' Buthelezi said. ANC leader Nelson Mandela has offered to meet with Buthelezi and his uncle, Zulu King Goodwill Zwelithini, but no date has been set. Buthelezi and Mandela have had years of friendly contact. But Buthelezi says ANC leaders in exile in Zambia have called for his assassination, and he has criticized them for their support of bombings and economic sanctions as ways to end South Africa's apartheid. According to a daily unrest report issued by police, six blacks were killed by other blacks in Natal province during the previous 24 hours and a seventh was killed by police during the clashes. It said seven blacks were arrested in the fighting and that nine people were injured, three of them policemen. In one incident in Imbali, outside the Natal provincial capital of Pietermaritzburg, police said a group of blacks attacked a house, stabbed a man in the chest with sharp instruments, poured paraffin over him and set him on fire. In violence elsewhere in the country, police said a man was killed and two were injured when officers fired shots at a group of black men attacking Zulu migrant workers living in a hostel in Boteleng township near Johannesburg. Police said when they arrived, the attackers turned on them and officers fired a shotgun at the crowd. Police said gasoline bombs were thrown at two black policemen's houses in Botaleng, but caused no injuries. During the past six weeks, more than 300 blacks and one white man have been killed in violence, including black factional fighting and riots against police in black townships and rural homelands throughout the country. Mandela, who returned from a five-nation tour Saturday, said the violence reflected black rejection of apartheid, but that the ANC would try to stop it. Some government officials, including President F.W. de Klerk, have blamed black leaders for instigating the violence, saying they are not ready to negotiate a peaceful solution to the country's race problems.

DOC.HEAD: Three Pilots Accused of Drunken Flying to Appeal License Revocations
DOC.TEXT: Three Northwest Airlines pilots accused of flying a commercial jetliner from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis while intoxicated will appeal their license revocations, two attorneys said. The National Transportation Safety Board will hear the appeals April 3, said attorneys representing Robert Kirchner, first officer, and Joseph Balzer, second officer on the March 8 flight. The Federal Aviation Administration revoked the licenses of Kirchner, of Highland Ranch, Colo.; Balzer, of Antioch, Tenn.; and Capt. Norman L. Prouse, of Conyers, Ga., March 9 after its investigation showed the cockpit crew boarded the flight within eight hours of drinking, the federal limit. Northwest fired the three pilots on Friday following its own investigation, saying they had violated the company's stricter rules prohibiting drinking less than 12 hours before flying. Bruce Hanley, the Minneapolis attorney who represents Balzer, and Mark McDermott, a Washington, D.C., attorney representing Kirchner, said Saturday that their clients maintain Northwest or the FAA could have stopped the flight. The two attorneys told the Star Tribune that Northwest had enough information to ground Flight 650 before it left Fargo with 91 passengers aboard. Northwest has declined to discuss what role it played before takeoff. Hanley said all three members of the cockpit crew also will appeal their dismissal by Northwest through their union, the Air Line Pilots Association. ``Northwest is trying to polish its own public image by putting the blame on the pilots,'' said McDermott, a former FAA attorney and vice president of the bar association that represents individuals before the transportation board. McDermott said it was ``ludicrous'' that Northwest or the FAA could not have stopped the flight. Only three Northwest crews were staying overnight in Fargo the night before the flight, McDermott said. Northwest said it got an anonymous telephone tip at midnight, six hours before takeoff, that a ``Capt. Sugo'' had been drinking in a Moorhead bar, but did not find the name on its pilots roster. McDermott said he finds it difficult to believe Northwest would not have checked out the three crews.
