At 2:15 a.m., four hours before takeoff, the FAA contacted Northwest about an anonymous tip and went to the airport to meet the crew before the takeoff. Northwest refuses to comment on what actions it took before the departure. Hanley said a Northwest gate agent ``had to have seen'' the three pilots before their departure. ``If they (the FAA and Northwest) perceived there was a problem, they should have stopped them,'' Hanley said. ``There's no question the plane would not have taken off without proper clearance.'' McDermott said he will challenge the results of blood-alcohol tests of the three pilots conducted by the Hennepin County Medical Center. Those tests showed the three all had blood alcohol levels above the legal limit. FAA regulations prohibit concentrations of .04 percent or above. On the issue of time lapse between drinking and flying, McDermott and Hanley said they will contend that their clients stopped drinking before 10:30 p.m. The plane was scheduled to depart at 6 a.m., did not take off until 6:25 a.m. All three pilots were met by an FAA inspector before they took off. The inspector called other FAA officials after the plane departed. An FAA inspector then joined airport police to meet the Boeing 727 jetliner when it landed at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. The inspector executed a citizen's arrest, and the three were taken into custody by police. In addition to having their licenses revoked and being fired, the three pilots also could face misdemeanor charges of flying while intoxicated. Such charges are being considered by authorities in both Minnesota and North Dakota.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Troop Pullout From Sri Lanka Nearly Complete
DOC.TEXT: The commander of the Indian peacekeeping force said Sunday the last of his troops would withdraw by the end of the week, leaving the towns and jungles they once patrolled to the guerrillas they were sent to disarm in 1987. More than 1,155 Indian soldiers were killed in the 2{-year peacekeeping operation, the longest foreign venture by the world's fourth-largest army. ``If the weather remains as it is, I expect to pull out the last contingent by March 24,'' Lt. Gen. Amarjit Singh Kalkat told reporters at China Bay, one of only two military camps in Sri Lanka still occupied by Indian troops. About 5,500 soldiers remain in northeastern Sri Lanka, down from an estimated peak of 125,000 at the height of the jungle war against the Tamil Tiger guerrillas who once again move openly on the streets of Trincomalee. The guerrillas waged war against Sri Lanka's Sinhalese-dominated government since 1983 before turning their guns on the Indian peacekeepers. They have entered the political process but have not given up arms. Kalkat said the Indian mission had accomplished its purpose. ``The aim was to bring normalcy for the democratic process to go through, and it went through,'' the general said. ``At this point, that military group (the Tigers) is saying they have full faith and confidence in the (Sri Lankan) government,'' Kalkat said. ``At the same time, the government of Sri Lanka is reposing full faith in the militant group and is dealing with them.'' He also said the Indian army had learned valuable lessons about ``operating in a politico-military environment.'' ``In these kinds of operations, the military and political strategies directly contradict each other,'' Kalkat said. ``This was the biggest onus on my commanders.'' In Trincomalee, a town of 50,000 people, the Indians' departure went largely unnoticed. The fish market was crowded, and men stood in groups near the town's solitary cinema, waiting for the show to start. There was no sign of civilian administration. Instead, a young man in green fatigues with a Czechoslovak revolver appeared to be in charge. ``We have taken over,'' he said, identifying himself as A. Ruban, a senior member of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. ``You've seen the situation,'' Ruban said in the Tamil language. ``Our cadres are enough to maintain peace.'' The Tigers took over the town March 10 after the Indian troops withdrew to China Bay and the pro-Indian Tamils running the provincial government fled. Tiger guerrillas and the Sri Lankan soldiers and police they once fought now share law and order duties. While soldiers and police operate checkpoints and guard some government buildings, the Tigers roam Trincomalee in convoys of pickup trucks, brandishing machine guns and automatic rifles. ``Within three months we will have elections,'' he said. ``Until then, we have to create and maintain an atmosphere of trust.'' The Tamil revolt began in 1983 to press demands for a separate homeland in northeastern Sri Lankan for their ethnic minority. More than 11,000 people have been killed since then. At least 6,000 more died in a Sinhalese backlash against the government and its peace overtures to the Tamils. The Tamils, who make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, claimed they were discriminated against in jobs and education by the Sinhalese, who form 75 percent of the population. The Sri Lankan army, made up almost entirely of Sinhalese, initially attempted to crush the revolt with an all-out attack on Tamil areas. Tamil guerrillas responded with attacks on the government troops and massacres of Sinhalese civilians. Neighboring India, which has a politically powerful Tamil minority of its own, tacitly supported the insurgents and tolerated guerrilla training camps on its soil. On July 29, 1987, an Indian-sponsored plan giving the Tamils limited autonomy in exchange for an arms surrender was signed by the New Delhi and Colombo governments. India said it consulted Tamil leaders about the proposals. India also agreed its troops would enforce the surrender. But the Tigers reneged on the deal and turned their guns on the Indians.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Conduct Military Maneuvers in Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5 grafs for 3-4 pvs bgng, `We will...' to ADD detail on rally, Gorbachev stand, RECASTS translation of Gorbachev quote; pickup 5th graf pvs, `The military....' SUBS 5 grafs for 15th `On Saturday...' to revise crowd estimate, ADD rally detail; pickup 16th graf pvs, `The leaflets...'
DOC.TEXT: Soviet military jets repeatedly streaked over the capital of Lithuania during military maneuvers Sunday, one day before a Moscow deadline demanding that the Baltic republic renounce its declaration of independence. At the same time, however, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev struck a conciliatory tone, saying he still planned to talk with the Lithuanians about returning to the Soviet fold. And he said there had been no ultimatums. ``We will carry on the dialogue,'' Gorbachev told reporters Sunday after voting in runoff elections, which were held in Russia and other parts of the Soviet Union's Slavic heartland. Also Sunday, 50,000 to 100,000 Lithuanians demonstrated against independence at a rally in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital. Soviet television said the demonstration included calls for civil disobedience and for the creation of workers' squads to secure order and defend socialist property against the secessionist government. The size of the protest, shown on national television, damaged the Lithuanian government's claim that the population fully supports secession. Gorbachev has said he is concerned for the rights of non-native residents and fears that splitting the Soviet Union would prompt hundreds of thousands to migrate. On Sunday, he continued to insist that Lithuania's March 11 independence declaration was illegal and must be decided by the entire Soviet Union, not just the republic. He said economic, political, cultural and technical ties were too strong to tear apart and ``human contacts have become particularly deep.'' He added that he would work for a new federation agreement that would satisfy everyone. The Soviet military maneuvers surprised the Lithuanian government, parliamentary spokesman Vladslovas Panumis said in a telephone interview. But military officers told Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis that the training had been planned in advance, Panumis said. A Westerner in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, said it was unclear whether there were many planes landing at a military base or whether it was just one or two jets making repeated passes over the city. The Baltic Tribunal, an emigre newspaper in Copenhagen, says there are eight military bases in Lithuania, including one near Vilnius. At least 1 million Soviet troops are believed to be stationed in Lithuania, which is on the Soviet Union's western border. Another parliament spokesman quoted Lithuanian Premier Kazimera Prunskiene as saying the military maneuvers on the border with Latvia and in southeastern Lithuania seemed to be routine and there was no cause for concern. Telephone communications between Lithuania and the West were out of order Saturday and Sunday, but it was possible to telephone to the republic from Moscow. A shift supervisor for the Moscow central telephone office said the international telephone channels to Lithuania were closed down Saturday for maintenance work and she had no idea when they would be restored. The Soviet Parliament on Thursday directed Gorbachev to defend Soviet interests and citizens in the Baltic republic of 3.8 million. It declared the Lithuanian move illegal and the Soviet Constitution still in force. Gorbachev on Friday sent Landsbergis a telegram giving him until Monday to respond to how the directive is being realized. He did not say what the Kremlin would do if the Lithuanians refused to respond. He and his aides say they have ruled out the use of force. On Sunday, Gorbachev said the telegram was not an ultimatum. ``I think we shall receive a reply from the authorities of present-day Lithuania and, depending on what it is, everything will become clear. The character and content of the answer will define our next steps,'' he said. ``We shall act responsibly with a view to realizing the aspirations of the Lithuanian people from the viewpoint of strengthening their independence and sovereignty, but at the same time, within the scope of cooperation with all republics,'' he said. Landsbergis and aides met Sunday to draft a response stating that Lithuanian law will observe the legal rights of the Soviet Union and protect national minorities. On Saturday, Landsbergis appealed to democratic nations for official recognition of his new government. Meanwhile, a military helicopter had dropped leaflets on Vilnius calling voters to an anti-independence rally on Sunday. Demonstrators at the rally called the newly elected Lithuanian parliament's declaration of independence ``an anti-constitutional coup.'' I. Kucherov, a Communist Party member who remained loyal to Moscow when the majority of the Lithuanian party split from the Soviet party in December, said on the evening news show ``Vremya'' that he called for civil disobedience and for government workers to refuse to carry out separatist orders. Sunday's protest was sponsored by the Vilnius Communist Party and Young Communist League, the Edinstvo pro-Russian movement, the Socialist Federation of Workers and the Council of Veterans of War and Labor. The crowd was estimated at 50,000 by a correspondent and at 100,000 by Soviet television and the Lithuanian Interior Ministry. The leaflets dropped by the helicopter stated: ``Who asked if we agreed?'' according to one read to The Associated Press over the telephone by Gintautas Alksneses, a member of Sajudis. The leaflet accused the independence activists of representing ``those who owned bourgeois Lithuania and disposed of the fates of people, sold Lithuanian land and factories to foreign capital and cost hundreds of thousands of Lithuanians their jobs, forcing them to flee the country in search of bread.'' The leaflets also demanded a referendum on the question of independence, which was declared a week ago by the first freely elected parliament in Lithuania in 50 years.

DOC.HEAD: Opera Opens in Amazon After Eight Decades of Silence
DOC.TEXT: After eight decades of slow decay, the renovated Teatro Amazonas has opened a new season of opera in the 19th century Belle Epoque building in the heart of the Amazon jungle. The 659-seat opera house was two-thirds full Saturday night for an evening of Brazilian classical music, arias and part of Brazilian composer Heitor Villa-Lobos' ballet ``The Amazon Forest.'' The audience, in tuxedos and evening gowns, were special guests of state Gov. Amazonino Mendes. He authorized the $8 million, three-year renovation of the building, which first opened its doors in 1896 when a rubber boom had made Manaus one of the richest cities in the world. About 300 people demonstrated on opening night to protest the cost of the renovation at a time of economic crisis. Inflation in Brazil was 2,700 percent during the past 12 months and poverty is widespread. ``The people paid, the people want to enter!'' protesters shouted before police moved in and dispersed the crowd. No one was injured. The night's entertainment also suffered from technical difficulties. During the Villa-Lobos ballet, the sound system went out and the performance had to be restarted. The neo-classical opera house with its multicolored, tiled dome roof, painted ceiling by Crispim de Amaral and plush interior with velvet-covered chairs, was built with the money of the rubber barons who dominated the city in the late 1800s. The barons, who boasted of their sophistication, spoke French and sent their white shirts to be laundered in Europe. Chandeliers and mirrors came from Venice, tiles from Marseilles, marble from Carrara and lampshades from Paris. A new opera house in Paris, the Opera-Bastille, made its own debut Saturday with a performance of Hector Berlioz' ``The Trojans.'' The Teatro Amazonas, about 1,700 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro, had been silent for most of the past 83 years, fizzling with the end of the rubber boom. After a 1907 performance, the theater was mostly abandoned, with only an occasional play or concert performed on its once glorious stage. By the early 1980s, time, rain, and termites had nearly destroyed the building. The head-to-toe renovation included a paint job for the pink pastel facade, 36,000 new tiles and a sound system. More than 3,000 gallons of insecticide were injected into the wood to prevent termites from eating the building a second time. The legendary rise and fall of the Teatro Amazonas was the subject of German director Werner Herzog's movie, ``Fitzcarraldo.''

DOC.HEAD: Thugs Attacks Sisters at Catholic School
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ At least four masked thugs broke into an elite Roman Catholic school for girls Sunday and assaulted the resident sisters with clubs and machetes, a French diplomat reported. Four French sisters and one Haitian sister were hospitalized with injuries. The thugs attacked eight St. Joseph of Cluny sisters and tried to strangle them, French ambassador Jean Raphael Dufour told The Associated Press. Dufour said one was stabbed in her bed at the St. Rose of Lima girls school in the capital, Port-au-Prince. ``One has the feeling the motive wasn't only money,'' he said of the incident, which occurred early Sunday morning. He indicated the reasons might be political but did not elaborate. The thugs took money and files when they fled, he said. The French-based St. Joseph of Cluny religious order last year celebrated its 125th anniversary in Haiti, where it runs several schools. Dufour said he planned to meet with provisional president Ertha Pascal-Trouillot Sunday evening to protest the incident. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot was inaugurated Wednesday after a weeklong popular uprising toppled the military government of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril.

DOC.HEAD: With East Germany
Kohl Calls East German Election Result a Call For Reunification
With AM-Germany-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl called Sunday's election victory by the East German coalition he helped promote a clear mandate for swift reunification. Kohl, who made frequent trips to East Germany to campaign for the three-party conservative alliance, also urged East Germans to stop migrating to the West and begin rebuilding their country. Official returns reported by East Germany's ARD television gave victory to the conservative Alliance for Germany, a three-party coalition. The big showing by conservatives in East Germany's first free elections was a huge personal victory for Kohl. Based on television projections, the alliance captured the largest single bloc of seats in the new East German parliament. Kohl, conciliatory in the face of victory, called for a broad governing coalition in East Germany, where political groups in recent months largely have been shaped by the principal West German parties. ``This first truly free, direct vote is a historical event,'' Kohl said at a news conference in Bonn. ``The events in East Germany, the most peaceful revolution in the history of the German people, made it possible that it came to such an election.'' The East German conservative alliance is led by the Christian Democrats, sister party of Kohl's Christian Democratic Union. The East German Christian Democrats favor quicker reunification than the rival Social Democrats, whose party was supported by the West German Social Democrats. West German Social Democrats have accused Kohl of using the reunification issue to fan German patriotism and boost his own standing in the West German elections in December. They said the conservative victory in East Germany was based on unrealistic expectations and promises made by their counterparts in the West. They accused Kohl of promising the relatively impoverished East Germans a rosy future if they merge their nation quickly with prosperous West Germany. Oskar Lafontaine, the probable top candidate for the Social Democrats against Kohl, said the chancellor will now have to uphold his ``big promises.'' ``The decisive thought for East Germans may have been, ``If we vote for Kohl, the money will flow,''' Lafontaine said in an interview with the ARD television network. Kohl said the projected election results were a mandate for reunification and Western-style democracy. ``The East German citizens have decided against every form of extremism,'' Kohl said. ``Most important, they want to follow a path, together with West Germany, that will lead to unification.'' The new East German government is likely to exist only long enough to negotiate the details of the unification of the nations. Kohl said East German voters had ``clearly rejected'' the Communists, who reconstituted themselves as the Party for Social Democracy and were projected to finish third in the balloting. The chancellor urged East Germans to stay at home and help reconstruct a new country, a reference to the tens of thousands of East Germans who have fled to West Germany in the past year. ``My message at this hour is: Stay home,'' Kohl said. ``Work with us in your villages, cities and communities, in your factories and in your local administrations to build up this beautiful country.''

DOC.HEAD: FBI Arrests One of Two Brothers Sought for Questioning in Firebombing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead, edits throughout to tighten; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The FBI on Sunday arrested the younger of two brothers wanted for questioning in the firebombing of a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration office, a spokesman said. The bombing early Saturday caused $4 million in damage but no injuries, and came two days after the brothers were indicted on drug charges. John Lewis Ciganek, 22, was arrested on the drug charges, said agent Brian Kensel, speaking for the FBI team investigating the bombing. He declined to give details of the arrest. Authorities continued searching for Jeffrey A. Matthews, 23, formerly known as Jeff Ciganek. Kensel said the FBI wanted to talk to the brothers about the bombing but declined to label them or anyone else prime suspects. ``There have been no warrants issued in connection with the explosion,'' he said. Last month, federal drug agents told sheriff's deputies that Matthews had threatened DEA property during a drug investigation, according to Lee County Sheriff's Department records. The fire following the bombing gutted the 6,000-square-foot, one-story building at a shopping and business mall, agency officials said. The drug agency was the building's only tenant. Kensel said investigators determined that the blast was caused by a pipe bomb, and that a ``liquid accelerant,'' probably gasoline, was used to spread the fire. Following the bombing, Sheriff John McDougall ordered deputies to guard at least 13 prosecutors, judges and law enforcement officials who were part of a joint task force investigating and prosecuting drug dealers in his southwestern Florida county McDougall called the bombing ``a declaration of war.'' He said protection might be extended to others, such as jurors and witnesses, who participated in a recent federal grand jury probe of drug trafficking. Guards were posted at the federal courthouse and the office building that houses the U.S. attorney's local office. The bombing is also being investigated by the state Department of Law Enforcement and the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. Matthews and Ciganek, who were investigated for at least three months, were indicted Thursday on two counts each of conspiracy to distribute cocaine, officials said. A third man and a woman, Kenneth Bird Sr., 41, and Kelly Susskind, 20, who were indicted on the same charges, were arrested Friday. They were being held without bond in the county jail. The eight to 10 employees who worked at the destroyed building will find a new office in the same city, officials said. ``The Drug Enforcement Administration is not leaving Fort Myers. The Drug Enforcement Administration is here to stay,'' said Gregory Kehoe, first assistant U.S. attorney from Tampa. Three hours before the bombing, a pipe bomb exploded outside the Fort Myers home of Gary Wicall, a fire inspector who investigated other bombings over several months at Fort Myers Beach. ``Someone's sending me a message. Someone wants to scare me. But frankly, they've just angered me,'' Wicall said.

DOC.HEAD: Flooding Continues Across South, Snow in Northeast, Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Record flooding continued to swamp the South on Sunday, and scattered snow fell across sections of the Northeast and the Midwest. Floods that began late last week continued in Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi, Georgia, eastern Tennessee and the Carolinas, as well as in northeast Texas and New England. In Georgia, Kinchafoonee Creek, Little River and Murder Creek reached record flood levels. In Vinings, the Chattahoochee River reached its highest mark since a flood in 1946. In southern Alabama, two days of flooding left at least 3,500 people homeless and killed eight others by Sunday. Damage in the town of Elba alone, where a levee broke Saturday, was estimated in the millions of dollars. The Tallapoosa River neared the record level reached in 1961 at the Tallapoosa, Ala., water plant and was still rising. The Alabama River was expected to crest about 3 feet higher than a damaging flood in April 1979 in Montgomery and Selma. Scattered snow fell on parts of Colorado, Iowa, Illinois, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan, Indiana, Pennsylvania and New York. Rain fell from Illinois to Iowa and from Missouri to Kansas. Advisories for blowing, drifting snow were posted for western Minnesota. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 6 degrees in International Falls, Minn. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 14 degrees in Detroit Lakes, Minn., and Ely, Minn., to 82 degrees in McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Biaggi in Halfway House
DOC.TEXT: Former Rep. Mario Biaggi has been transferred from the federal prison in Texas where he's been serving a 2{-year sentence for bribery to a halfway house in the city, New York Newsday reported Sunday. The newspaper quoted unidenitified sources as saying the former 10-term Democratic congressman from New York arrived at the Brooklyn halfway house on Friday. Biaggi was convicted in 1987 of accepting illegal gratuities _ vacation expenses for himself and his girlfriend _ from then-Brooklyn Democratic leader Meade Esposito in exchange for seeking federal help for one of Esposito's insurance clients. Esposito was also convicted in the case. In addition, Biaggi was convicted of interstate travel to commit a crime and obstruction of justice. He served 11 months of the 2{-year sentence at a minimum-security prison in Fort Worth. It was unclear how long Biaggi would spend at the halfway house, a six-story, brick-faced building with terraces, where inmates live in dormitories and may hold outside jobs, New York Newsday said. In a separate case last year, Biaggi was convicted of extorting payoffs from the Bronx-based Wedtech Corp. in return for using his political influence to help the defense contractor. Biaggi is appealing his conviction and eight-year sentence in that case.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-democracy Activists Claim Victory in Moscow, Leningrad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with unofficial results from Leningrad, Moscow, pickup 8th graf pvs, `The Soviet...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: Pro-democracy activists claimed victories Sunday in local Moscow and Leningrad elections, while Latvians and Estonians in their first free vote in 50 years elected parliaments that activists hope will press for independence. Crucial runoff elections were held in Russia, Byelorussia and the Ukraine. The areas make up the Soviet Union's Slavic heartland, accounting for about 80 percent of its territory and two-thirds of the country's population. From Moscow to Vorkuta in northern Russia, reformers ran against Communist Party and government officials. In Moscow, the pro-democracy bloc claimed 10 of 14 contested seats in Sunday's runoff, said Irina Boganseva of the Voters' Club. Pro-democracy activists in Leningrad claimed many victories in individual races and estimated they would control at least 65 percent of the city council, said Elena Zelinskaya of the Northwest Information Agency. Early returns showed only one Communist Party official winning a seat, she said. Further results were not expected until Monday and official tallies were days away. In the two Baltic republics of Estonia and Latvia, annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940, supporters of independence movements hoped their candidates would emerge victorious, following the example of nearby Lithuania. Lithuania's parliament was taken over by independence supporters in elections in February and early March, and the lawmakers declared the republic independent on March 11. The Soviet Congress declared the move illegal and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave the republic three days to respond. The deadline expires Monday, but Gorbachev has offered to hold talks with the Lithuanians. Latvia followed Lithuania and legalized alternative political parties several months ago. Estonia has not removed the Communist Party's constitutional guarantee on power but a variety of political parties put forward candidates without interference. The Soviet Parliament legalized multiple political parties for the entire country Tuesday, but that was too late for strong movements to form in the heartland of Russia, Byelorussia and the Ukraine. In Latvia, average voter turnout was 75 percent, the republic's Electoral Commission said. The pro-independence Latvian People's Front nominated 185 candidates out of the total 390 competing for the 201 parliament seats. Election officials said 69 percent of the contenders there are Communists, including some People's Front members, the official Soviet news agency Tass said. People Front's spokeswoman Anda Anspoka said the front hoped to gain a two-thirds parliamentary majority ``to fight for independence.'' Thousands of Popular Front supporters rallied in the Latvian capital of Riga Sunday, urging voters to support their movement. At least five other parties, including the Green or environmental party, competed in the Latvian elections, Tass said. Estonian journalist Michael Taro predicted the People's Front would win about 35 of the 105 seats in Estonia, with 15 or 20 more going to other pro-independence groups. In Estonia, about 63 percent of the voters turned out by 2 p.m., said Annu Laido of Estonia's Electoral Commission. The lowest turnout at that point was 54 percent in Tartu. In the three Slavic republics, voters chose between candidates in some 1,610 runoffs, held after no candidate gained 50 percent of the vote in the main round on March 4. ``According to data reaching us, voter turnout today is somewhat lower,'' than on March 4, secretary of Russia's electoral commission Anatoly Petrov told Tass. Turnout by noon was especially low in Western Siberia, between 26 percent and 27 percent. In Moscow, officials reported a 57 percent turnout after the polls closed. ``I think people want to participate, because they believe that things would change for the best, that these are the first democratic elections. For the first time, we have alternative candidates'' for the republic and local councils, said Ivan Petrov, chairman of the electoral committee at a polling station in Moscow's Kievsky district. Tensions ran high at some Moscow stations, located in libraries, movie houses or schools. The runoffs put many members of the Democratic Russia group, a coalition of reformist radicals, against party bureaucrats, police officials and nationalist candidates. In Moscow's Proletarsky district, former political prisoner Victor Bulgakov faced Yuri Gorbachev, a local KGB official, a Moscow activist said. And in Vorkuta, where coal miners have staged repeated strikes, mine engineer Victor Yakovlev faced Soviet coal industry minister Mikhail Shadov. Some reformers accused political rivals of playing down the importance of the elections in the hope that insufficient turnout would require a new election, giving the conservatives a second chance. Soviet law requires at least 50 percent of the voters to go to the polls for an election to be valid. Mikhail Zarapin, a reformist candidate who lost in the March 4 round at the Tagansky district and now functions as an independent observer in the elections, said he felt people were just too ignorant. ``They don't really know the candidates. Some would take the three ballots and just cross out the first name in each of those. Others think they should cross out people from outside their district,'' he said. Candidates were not required to run in the district where they live. Another Russian said people were tired of the Soviet Union's new-found political games and did not believe elections would change much. ``I have to vote,'' one young woman said as she emerged from the voting booth. ``But frankly, I would rather not vote for any of them.''

DOC.HEAD: Contender for Premier Led Party Beyond Tainted Past
With AM-Germany-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lothar de Maiziere, who may become East Germany's first democratically elected premier, leads a party that once supported the ousted hard-line Communists in a puppet parliament. He has tried to deal with his party's past by openly acknowledging mistakes and wrongdoing, and his strategy seems to have worked. West Germany's ARD television network, reporting official returns, said late Sunday that the conservative Alliance for Germany, led by de Maiziere's party, had won East Germany's first free elections. That put de Maiziere in an excellent position to become premier. His Christian Democrats are the leading party in the Alliance for Germany, which is backed by West Germany's governing Christian Democrats. ``We have an enormously large responsibility,'' de Maiziere told reporters during a frenzied celebration at party headquarters Sunday night. He is a fervent supporter of quick unification with West Germany. The bearded, 50-year-old de Maiziere sidestepped questions about becoming premier. ``I don't want to talk about personnel questions tonight. I don't want to burden the coalition negotiations,'' he said. ``I just want to celebrate.'' It was another remarkable scene in the political transformation of Eastern Europe. Until last fall, de Maiziere's party was one of the four controlled by the hard-line Communists. De Maiziere, who became party chief after last fall's popular East German revolt, has acknowledged his party was financed by the Communists in exchange for its parliamentary support. He has also admitted that some Christian Democratic leaders stole party funds. The party leader, who is descended from a prominent Huguenot family, has even said his party's past will make a fresh start in a democratic East Germany very difficult. Many East Germans now openly despise people who supported the ousted hard-line Communist regime. De Maiziere has not devoted his life exclusively to politics. He is a lawyer and talented viola player. For many years, he headed the Lutheran Church Council. He rose to prominence after the popular revolution last fall as deputy premier in the caretaker government of reform Communist Hans Modrow. In the election, however, his party embraced support from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats. De Maiziere, who is married with three daughters, has strong personal ties to West Germany. His uncle, Ulrich de Maiziere, held a top post in the West German army. His cousin, Thomas de Maiziere, is the West Berlin spokesman for West Germany's Christian Democrats.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crash-Lands In Storm; Four American Divers Hurt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS to UPDATE with four Americans only slightly injured, other details; TAN-SAHSA all caps is cq; CORRECTS locators; no pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A Honduran airliner carrying 25 Americans home from a diving trip crash-landed on Roatan Island in a Caribbean rainstorm Sunday, and four passengers were slightly injured, an airline official said. Marcos Briceno, manager of TAN-SAHSA airlines, said in a telephone interview the four Americans were treated for minor injuries at a hospital on the island and released a few hours later. Briceno said sharp, strong winds suddenly whipped the old DC-3 plane as it was landing on the island's beachside airstrip ``towards its right side ... until the wing and the engine on that side came to rest in water'' off the runway. The aircraft was a twin-engine, propeller driven plane dating to World War II, when it was widely used to ferry American troops to and from Europe. Briceno said the plane, with a crew of four, had taken off ``normally'' from the Island of Guanaja for the 45-mile flight to Roatan. The twin islands in the Caribbean, about 280 miles northeast of Tegucigalpa and 43 miles off the mainland, are resorts favored by divers because of the clear water surrounding them. ``The plane took off normally from Guanaja at 6:03 a.m. and ... was landing at 6:28 a.m. at the Roatan airstrip when it happened,'' Briceno said. ``There were 25 passengers on board, all American men.'' Briceno said the passengers, members of a Miami-based diving tour, had arrived Saturday in Guanaja after a stop at La Ceiba, a port on the Honduran mainland. ``They will stay the night at a luxury hotel in Roatan and all are returning to Miami tomorrow,'' he said. ``The accident was due to the heavy rains and winds whipping the Caribbean region at the time and not to mechanical failure or human error.'' He said a passenger list was not immediately available. U.S. Embassy spokesman Terry Kneebone and an airline communications employee, Roberto Siallas, earlier also confirmed the accident had occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Crews Work To Clean Up Hazardous Chemical Spill
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guard crews used vacuum trucks Sunday to suck up a hazardous chemical solvent that spilled into the Delaware River while being unloaded from a Norwegian tanker. The spill forced the evacuation of about 250 people from a three-block area in northeast Philadelphia on Saturday. Six police officers and five workers at a pier near the spill were treated for headaches and nausea after breathing fumes of the chemical, cumene. Coast Guard officials said 12,843 gallons of cumene, which is used in fingernail polish remover, spilled aboard the Jo Rogn, and a small, undetermined amount ran into the river. Fifteen workers used six vacuum trucks to remove a 20,000-gallon mixture of water and cumene, said Coast Guard Lt. Robert Mitchell. The chemical appeared as a ``light film'' on the river's surface, and by 1 p.m. no noticeable spill remained, he said. The cleanup was to resume Monday morning, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Louis Moore. The tanker was carrying 3.2 million gallons of cumene, which is a fire hazard and dangerous if inhaled, swallowed or absorbed through the skin. Most of the cumene was contained and put into a slop tank, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Richard Minnich. A small amount leaked into the river, but most of it evaporated quickly, he said. ``A suspect valve appears to be the source,'' Minnich said. ``Apparently the (ship) sensors said it was OK, but it was found to be open or partially open.'' Because the slop tank contained other material, Coast Guard officials said they could not estimate how much of the cumene was recovered from the river. The main concern was not aquatic or marine life, but fire hazards, they said. The Fire Department declared the emergency under control about noon Saturday, four hours after the spill was reported, and allowed the estimated 250 evacuees to return home. The spill occurred when the tanker was unloading the chemical into a holding tank at Unitank Co. The tanker is owned by Odfjell Shipping, of Bergen, Norway and the shipping agent was identified as AspenShipping Co. in Philadelphia, Mitchell said. Harold Yates, a spokesman for the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, said the water at a sewage treatment plant about a mile north of the pier will be monitored. But he said there was no danger of contamination of drinking water because the nearest source for water on the Delaware River is upstream.

DOC.HEAD: Leipzig Residents Enjoy Fruits of Revolution
With AM-German-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The people who began the revolt that brought down a Communist dictatorship already were looking Sunday beyond the elections made possible by their bold defiance. The pro-democracy fervor that exploded in Leipzig last year was replaced by quiet contemplation Sunday, when East Germans held democratic elections for the first time. Despite the free balloting, many residents instead focused on the inevitable reunification with West Germany. Bernd Fischer, a 29-year-old engineer, said he took pride in last fall's demonstrations. ``Totally new things were being created then. Now, especially after the election campaign, that feeling was gone.'' ``The only point of the vote was to shape a Germany to be united as soon as possible,'' he said. ``We hope the election will bring us progress _ good work, good pay and good life for all.'' He and his wife, Kerstin, 27, said they voted for the German Social Union, a Leipzig-based rightist party calling for quick unity. ``It was uplifting moment,'' said Seigmar Maywald, 50, after he voted. ``What was born in the demonstrations reached its peak in the elections.'' But his companion, 34-year-old Evelyn Werner, said: ``We can't rest on our laurels _ just keep on saying that we're heroes.'' ``It's enough politics for now. The rest we must achieve through hard work,'' Maywald added. Activists in Leipzig, East Germany's second-biggest city, began the huge demonstrations that forced the ouster of hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker on Oct. 18. The movement was initially led by grass-roots reform groups that held huge rallies every Monday in Leipzig. Later, conservatives who supported swift German unity began dominating the rallies. But downtown Leipzig was quiet on election day. Services at St. Nicholas Church, a focal point of the demonstrations, drew sparse gatherings. Signs that reunification with West Germany was on the minds of many were evident in the Western newspapers, fresh oranges and electronics that were brought from across the border and hawked on the streets. For 87-year-old Luise Woithon, the election was a chance to ponder a dark past. She remembered four decades of rigged Communist voting and the 1932 elections that put the Nazis in power. ``We're hoping for better times,'' she said. The Rev. Christian Fuehrer, Lutheran pastor at St. Nicholas, was among the driving forces in the revolution's early days and helped lead the call for free elections. ``Now we have to build the rule of law in East Germany,'' he said. ``A single German state is inevitable, but it has to come from within a European framework.'' Fuehrer voted for Alliance 90, a somewhat leftist group that includes New Forum, once the most influential opposition group. The alliance is expected to have only token representation in the new freely elected parliament. Despite its terrible showing, New Forum still held a post-election party. ``We expected an outcome like this,'' member Ralph Lange said with a shrug. ``But it is a little worse than we thought.''

DOC.HEAD: Comedian-Actor Robin Harris Dies
DOC.TEXT: Robin Harris, a comedian and actor who appeared in the movies ``Do the Right Thing,'' ``Harlem Nights'' and ``House Party,'' was found dead in a hotel room Sunday, officials said. He was 36. Harris gave a comedy show Saturday night at the Regal Theater and apparently died in his sleep at the Four Seasons Hotel, said Ardenia Brown of Jam Productions Ltd., promoter of the show. He was found by his mother, who accompanied him to Chicago, and was declared dead on arrival at 9:02 a.m. at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, said hospital administrator Shirley Jackson. An autopsy was scheduled to determine the cause of death, according to the Cook County medical examiner's office. A Chicago native, Harris moved to Los Angeles with his family when he was 8. He performed at black nightclubs in the Los Angeles area after graduating from Ottawa University in Kansas. Harris played the role of Sweet Dick Willie, a middle-aged black man who hung out on a street corner in Spike Lee's 1989 film, ``Do the Right Thing.'' ``I couldn't write that character as funny as Robin could,'' Lee said in an interview with the Los Angeles Times last summer. ``He has a sophisticated country wit. He was born in Chicago and raised in L.A. but he reaches way back to Mississippi.'' Harris had recently filmed an HBO comedy special at Chicago's Vic Theater and also appears in Lee's upcoming film, ``Love Supreme,'' Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: Glasgow Gunman Kills One, Wounds Others, Shoots Self
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to CORRECT that only five people wounded by gunfire; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A motorist struck a woman with his car Sunday, then opened fire on passers-by and killed one man before seriously wounding himself, witnesses and police said. Five people were wounded by the gunfire. The incident began about 2 a.m. as people left clubs and discotheques in the city center. A car knocked down a young woman, and when a bystander tried to talk with the driver, the motorist got out and started shooting, witnesses said. Police said the man shot indiscriminately at passers-by with a 9mm Browning pistol. Thomas McIntyre, 20, was killed, and three women and two men were wounded, police said. Three of the wounded were treated at Glasgow Royal Infirmary for minor injuries and then released, a hospital spokesman said Sunday. One person was in serious condition and another in critical condition, he said. The 22-year-old woman hit by the car, was being treated for leg and back injuries. The gunman was in intensive care at the hospital, said police detective superintendent Dennis Mair. Police would not identify the 24-year-old man, and they gave no motive for the shooting.

DOC.HEAD: Five Top Contenders For U.S. Oscars Win British Academy Awards
DOC.TEXT: Five top contenders for U.S. Oscars won British academy awards Sunday, with the American drama ``Dead Poets Society'' named best film of 1989. Pauline Collins was named best actress for her portrayal in ``Shirley Valentine'' of a housewife who escapes boredom in Liverpool and finds fulfillment in Greece. Miss Collins, giving her thanks, said it was a brave decision ``to put a middle-aged unknown'' in a major film. Daniel Day Lewis took best actor honors for his portrayal of crippled Irish writer Christy Brown in ``My Left Foot.'' Accepting the award from actress Angela Lansbury, Day Lewis expressed his ``lasting admiration'' for the late writer. Kenneth Branagh was named best director for ``Henry V,'' in which he played the title role. The 29-year-old actor had also been nominated for best actor. American writer Nora Ephron walked off with the award for best original screenplay for ``When Harry Met Sally,'' a comedy about a decade-long friendship that turns into love. ``Dead Poets Society,'' the story of an inspirational boarding-school teacher played by Robin Williams, beat ``My Left Foot,'' ``Shirley Valentine'' and ``When Harry Met Sally'' for the best film award. In addition, Maurice Jarre's music for ``Dead Poets Society'' was honored for best original film score. Miss Collins, Day Lewis, Branagh, Ephron and the ``Dead Poets Society'' have been nominated for Academy Awards, which will be announced in Los Angeles next Monday. The British Academy of Film and Television Arts awards films released in Britain in 1989. Oscar hopefuls such as ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' ``Born on the Fourth of July'' and ``The Fabulous Baker Boys'' did not open in time to be considered. ``Dangerous Liaisons,'' a 1988 Oscar nominee, received 10 British nominations and won two awards: Michelle Pfeiffer was named best supporting actress for her portrayal of the virtuous woman led astray and Christopher Hampton won for best adapted screenplay. In the U.S. Oscars, Miss Pfeiffer is nominated as best actress for her role as a nightclub singer in ``The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' Irish actor Ray McAnally won a posthumous award as best supporting actor for his role as Christy Brown's father in ``My Left Foot,'' his final film role before he died last year. The choice was greeted with cheers. The best film in a foreign language was Frenchman Bertrand Tavernier's ``Life and Nothing But'' about the emotional havoc wrought by World War I. A host of celebrities from both sides of the Atlantic attended the black-tie awards ceremony at the Grosvenor House Hotel. The celebrity presenters included actors Sean Connery, William Hurt and Ben Kingsley. Actress Jodie Foster was also a presenter. Princess Anne, president of the British Academy, presented its Special Award for 1990 to Dame Peggy Ashcroft, 82, for her dominant role in British show business for half a century. The princess also presented a special award for outstanding British contribution to cinema to veteran director Lewis Gilbert, 70. His latest film was ``Shirley Valentine.'' In television categories, the best actress award went to Diana Rigg for her role as the obsessive, homicidal mother in ``Mother Love.'' The best actor award was given to John Thaw for his work as ``Inspector Morse,'' a sour, crossword-loving detective from Oxford.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Leader Pledges Support for Libya in Face of U.S. Threats
DOC.TEXT: PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat pledged Sunday to defend Libya ``with our blood'' from U.S. threats, state-run Libyan Radio reported. The radio, in a report monitored in Rome and London, said Arafat spoke Sunday after a meeting with Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. The leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization said he had told Gadhafi of the Palestinians' ``solidarity with the Libyan Arab people and its leader, who are facing U.S. threats,'' Libyan Radio reported. ``We will stand by our people in the Great Jamahiriyah (Libya) with our blood,'' he was quoted as saying. Arafat was apparently referring to U.S. charges that a plant at Rabta, 60 miles southwest of Tripoli, was producing chemical weapons. Libya says it makes pharmaceuticals. Earlier this month, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said he did not rule out a U.S. military strike to shut down the factory. Fire swept through the plant on Wednesday and Libya has accused the United States and West Germany of involvement. The radio said Arafat left Tripoli Sunday afternoon, but did not say how long he had stayed. Arafat is a frequent visitor to Libya.

DOC.HEAD: Croatian Leader Apparent Target of Assassination Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Bodyguards overpowered a gunman who rushed up to a Croatian opposition leader in an apparent assassination attempt Sunday, a television report said. The incident occurred in the town of Benkovac in southwestern Croatia, an area mainly populated by Serbs, during a meeting to establish a local branch of the Croatian Democratic Union party, Yugoslav television said. An unidentified man brandishing a pistol tried to approach party leader Franjo Tudjman, but bodyguards pounced on him as he ran toward the rostrum, the report said. The man was injured in the scuffle and taken away by the police, the television said. Tudjman reportedly was unhurt, but the meeting was discontinued. Tudjman, a historian and former Yugoslav army major-general, was sentenced in 1971 to two years in jail. He was accused of extremist Croatian nationalism during a purge of Croatian leadership. Last year, he re-emerged on the political scene when he announced the formation of the Croatian Democratic Union, which has been accused by Yugoslav authorities of stirring up Croatian nationalism. The Union, which reportedly has more than 200,000 members and plans to contest next month's parliamentary elections in Croatia, has been criticized particularly in Serbia. Tudjman has complained about Serbian leadership as well. Serbia and Croatia are the two largest of Yugoslavia's six states. The Croatian Democratic Union has also been sharply denounced by Serbs in Croatia, who claim the party is ideologically similar to the extremist nationalist organization of Ustashas. The Ustashas were SS-like units in the army of the Croatian puppet state set up by Nazi Germany when it occupied Yugoslavia in 1941. The Croatian group has rejected the comparison.

DOC.HEAD: At 86, Al Hirschfeld Still Learning His Art
DOC.TEXT: Al Hirschfeld's caricatures of theater personalities have graced the pages of The New York Times for six decades. But the master of line drawing is not done learning. ``All I know is that when it works, I'm aware of it. But how it's accomplished, I don't know,'' said Hirschfeld, who turns 87 in June. Now, 98 of his works _ 31 of them originals _ are featured in a traveling exhibit that premiered Saturday at the Brandywine River Museum, the first of 15 stops on a U.S. tour organized by the Trust for Museum Exhibitions. The mainly black-and-white exhibit gives viewers plenty of chances to search his subjects for the hidden name of his daughter, Nina, a Hirschfeld trademark. Hirschfeld said the exhibit puts his ``early sins prominently on display.'' But his illustrations from the 1920s through the 1980s also show his development as an artist. ``Through trial and error you eliminate and eliminate and get down to the pure line and how it communicates to the viewer,'' Hirschfeld said Friday. ``The last drawing you do is the best one _ it should be.'' Hirschfeld spends his days finding the right lines to make the face, be it Sidney Poitier or Oliver Hardy. His seemingly simple, sweeping stroke catches Mikhail Baryshnikov in air, Fred Astaire dancing up a wall or Leonard Bernstein conducting an orchestra. Using basically an ``s'' on its side and a couple more sweeping strokes, he creates the folded arms of Peter Ustinov in an imaginary ``Odd Couple'' role as Oscar Madison, part of an ``Unlikely Casting'' series done for Playbill. His lines can be heavy to create the eyes, nose and mouth of Zero Mostel as Tevye in ``Fiddler on the Roof,'' or hundreds, maybe thousands of sharp wisps to capture his black, bushy beard. Margo Feiden, whose New York galleries house several of the works in the exhibit, said Hirschfeld is doing his best work now. ``It's very clearly defined now,'' said Ms. Feiden, who is Hirschfeld's agent. ``It's very distilled. ... One day he's going to be able to draw a dot in the middle of the page and we're going to be able to know who that is.'' Hiding the name of his daughter in his work began in Philadelphia. Nina was born in 1945 while he was making a sketch for the Philadelphia opening of the play ``Are You With It?'' so he put her name in the background. He kept hiding Nina's name for a while, and when he tried to stop, public demand wouldn't let him. He can't get a handle on the fascination, which once led to a $60,000 Pentagon grant to a University of Pennsylvania professor to study the search for Ninas. He thought it was ``insane'' and was even less impressed when the professor told him the work would help pilots read maps. ``You drop a pebble in the water and the ripples never cease,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Command Says No Evidence Helicopters Were Attacked
DOC.TEXT: There is no evidence that two U.S. helicopters crashes that killed 11 Americans last month were caused by terrorist attacks, the U.S. military said Sunday. ``We are still investigating, but we are treating the matter as an accident because there are no indications in the aircraft that it was an attack,'' said a spokesman for the U.S. Southern Command who asked not to be further identified. Leaflets signed by the Dec. 20 Movement, or M-20, and distributed in the western city of David claimed responsibility for the Feb. 21 crashes near Colon, at the northern end of the Panama Canal. The fliers also said the group was responsible for the March 2 bombing of a discotheque in Panama City that killed one American soldier and injured 28 other American soldiers and Panamanians. ``The helicopters were flying in the middle of a storm,'' the Southern Command spokesman said Sunday, repeating the cause given at the time. The spokesman declined to comment on M-20, which takes its name from the date of the U.S. invasion that overthrew dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. The Panamanian government has not acknowledged the group's existence, but officials have said pro-Noriega groups exist and were likely to have access to weapons caches believed still hidden in the country. A communique from the Government and Justice Ministry on Saturday said 26 AK-47s and one Falk automatic rifle were confiscated Friday in security operations for the David International Fair. The agricultural and crafts fair, which attracts Americans and visitors from neighboring countries, opened Friday. The M-20 leaflets said the group formed as a result of the U.S. invasion and that its ``principal ojective is everything that smells of gringos.'' It threatened to kill U.S. soldiers and attack American property and the David fair. A member of the communist Party of the People was arrested Friday in David for distributing the fliers, and officials said two other members were sought. However, the Panama City daily La Prensa on Sunday quoted a party official as denying any ties between the party and the group. ``Any attempt to link any member of our party with actions that vary from the PP line is a fabrication that reflects the beginning of a witch hunt in this country,'' Luther Thomas, the party's international relations secretary, was quoted as saying. ``We do not know about an M-20 group or any other group of this type.''

DOC.HEAD: After a 10-Year Wait, Thousands Snap up Tickets to See Bozo
DOC.TEXT: Bozo, they still love you. After a 10-year freeze, a Chicago television station opened the phone lines Saturday and unloaded more than 125,000 cheap passes to ``Bozo's Circus'' over the next five years. ``We'd call the response overwhelming,'' said WGN-TV spokesman Tom Leach. The show first aired on Sept. 11, 1961, starring Bob Bell as the red-haired, floppy-footed clown. When Bell retired in 1981, Joey D'Auria took the billing in a show seen in more than 20 million homes worldwide. The station, which is carried on many cable channels, stopped distributing tickets in 1980 when the waiting list grew too long. But 5{ hours after opening a Bozo hotline, it was swamped with 35,000 calls. For $3, each caller was allowed to get four tickets to a Bozo taping. The show is taped every weekday from September through April. Leach said a portion of the money will cover the cost of registering and the rest will go to a West Side neighborhood center. Some callers mistakenly rang the phone at a real estate office in suburban Chicago that has the name number but a different area code. ``A lot of people were angry because we couldn't give them tickets to Bozo,'' said Sue Wiskowski of Fair Realty Executives in Aurora.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Daily Criticizes Birth Control Campaign
DOC.TEXT: A Tehran daily Sunday criticized the government's campaign to curb Iran's population explosion, an effort that has underlined ideological disputes between President Hashemi Rafsanjani and his radical rivals. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, quoted an editorial in the radical Jomhuri Islami newspaper as saying the government had taken an ``unprincipled approach'' in seeking to slow down population growth. Iran's population is swelling at a rate of about 3.9 percent a year, one of the highest in the world. Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists, has recognized that unchecked population growth threatens to outstrip economic development and jeopardize the country's reconstruction drive following the August 1988 cease-fire in the war against Iraq. The government put the population at 55 million recently. Before the 1979 Islamic revolution, the figure was 37 million. It is expected to top 100 million by the year 2010. The Jomhuri Islami editorial reflected opposition by revolutionary hard-liners to the birth control campaign the government began last year and the radicals' growing criticism of Rafsanjani's policies. They argue that a large population will help Iran become the leader of the Islamic world and ensure its power and prosperity. Blunting population growth is central to Rafsanjani's drive to revitalize Iran's limping economy, expand industry and attract foreign investment, which the anti-Western radicals charge undermines the purity of the revolution. Jomhuri Islami noted: ``Those advocating population control warn that the current rate of increase is too high ... and that the country will not be able to provide food, education, medicines and so on.'' It said they argue that ``the present shortcomings in social services are the natural outcome of rapid population growth ... Even proper planning will not solve the problem and it is unlikely to establish harmony between the existing facilities and the population's needs.'' On the other hand, the editorial said, ``opponents of population control argue that ... the main problem is migration of villagers to the cities and its side effects such as congestion in the capital and major cities.'' Tehran is bursting with a population that has doubled in recent years to about 7 million. ``If Tehran is exploding due to the high rate of population increase, there are many abandoned villages throughout the country that are in miserable condition due to the lack of population,'' the editorial said. Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has supported the government's campaign by declaring that birth control does not violate Islam. Islam itself has been seen as a factor for the alarming surge in Iran's population since the revolution, whose leaders stressed early marriage and encouraged large families. The marriage rate doubled from 4.5 per thousand in 1975 to 9.8 percent in 1983, according to available statistics. But the economy has not been able to keep up. There is a shortage of housing and schools, and unemployment has risen. Tehran and other cities regularly suffer power cuts and water shortages. Food accounts for an estimated one-third of all imports because the agricultural sector has deteriorated alarmingly since 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Floods Kill Eight, Leave 3,500 Homeless in Alabama
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to UPDATE with nine dead, 3,700 homeless; SUB grafs 6-9, `State troopers ...,' with 10 grafs to UPDATE with details, flooding in other sections of nation, Selma evacuations, Alabama road and school closings; picks up 10th graf, `In Elba ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MY2
DOC.TEXT: Two days of flooding across south Alabama left at least 3,700 people homeless and killed nine others by Sunday, and one town remained a muddy pond a day after its levee failed. ``I cannot begin to imagine everything that's been lost or damaged,'' said U.S. Rep. Bill Dickinson after taking a helicopter tour of Elba, where 1,500 people were evacuated after the Pea River levee ruptured Saturday. Sixteen inches of rain had fallen in the area in the two days before the earthen barrier gave way. About 45 miles downstream in Geneva, emergency workers shored up another levee and continued evacuating residents, who started leaving their homes Friday night. Margaret Mixon, emergency management director for Geneva County, where about 450 people had fled, said officials believed the Geneva levee would hold. But she added: ``I guess Elba was pretty confident, too.'' Rivers throughout southern Alabama swelled to as much as 21 feet above flood levels Sunday as the water from the nearly non-stop rains drained toward the Gulf of Mexico. Flooding also continued in sections of Louisiana, Mississippi, Georgia, Tennessee, the Carolinas and Florida, as well as in northeast Texas and New England. Alabama state troopers said six people drowned Friday night in Covington County when a car fell into a rain-swollen creek where a bridge had washed out, and two more people died the same way Saturday night in neighboring Escambia County. A third man died in the county Saturday when he walked into a flooded area to check on his parents. About 200 people were forced to leave their homes in Escambia. A state police helicopter early Sunday rescued three people trapped on Alabama 229 by roaring floodwaters from the Tallapoosa River at Tallassee, about 25 miles northeast of Montgomery. Two rescue squad members were forced to abandon their boat while trying to reach a driver whose pickup truck had stalled in the water, said trooper Capt. Roy Smith. The chopper plucked the two rescuers from the water and rescued the driver from the bed of his truck more than three hours after the drama began. In the Montgomery area, about 80 miles northwest of Elba, some 500 people had to be evacuated as the muddy Alabama River rose to 19 feet above flood stage, with an even higher crest expected Monday. Downstream to the west in Selma, about 200 people were evacuated as the river rose toward its record 1961 flood level, said emergency management director Warren Rhoades. Hundreds more could be evacuated by Tuesday afternoon, when the river is expected to crest 13 feet above flood level, Rhoades said. The Choctawhatchee River was 21 feet above flood stage in the southeast Alabama town of Newton, about 30 miles east of Elba, and sheriff's deputies said some 500 people had been evacuated since Friday in Newton and surrounding Dale County. Evacuations in Covington, Houston and Dallas counties brought the total number of evacutations to about 3,700. Most people were staying with friends or in motels and very few were in shelters, said Lawrence Bowden of the Alabama Emergency Management Agency. State troopers reported dozens of road closings from Montgomery south to the Florida line. About three dozen schools in four counties said they would be closed Monday because of flooding. In Elba, the water receded slightly Sunday, gushing through a 100-foot hole on the levee's north side and pouring back into the Pea River through a large crack that formed on the south side. But water still covered all but the tops of first-story windows at the Coffee County Courthouse, and the city's three public schools were still submerged. On Saturday, water had reached second-story windows at the courthouse. Pumps would be used to help divert the current back into the river bed, said William Fuller, chief of the Army Corps of Engineers' emergency management division in Mobile. The water was up to the windows of Lela Wilson's one-story home, which she moved into about a week ago. ``It hurts. It honestly hurts. It seems like everything you work for you wind up losing,'' she said. Merchants in Brewton, west of Elba, began mopping up the 6 feet of water that filled stores and the first floor of City Hall on Saturday. Rep. Dickinson said southeast Alabama should ``certainly qualify'' for federal disaster relief once Gov. Guy Hunt made a request to federal amergency management officials. Elba Mayor Fred Moore said he would talk with Hunt after officials assesed the damage, which he estimated would run into millions of dollars in his town alone. Dickinson, who carried a camera to photograph the damage, pledged his help at the federal level. Col. Larry Bonine, the district engineer for the Corps of Engineers in Mobile, said it was too early to tell whether the Elba levee ruptured from the weight of the water, or whether the river rose higher than the barrier and washed so much of it away that it gave in, called overtopping. ``If the water overtopped it, there's not too many levees that are built to handle that,'' he said. The earthen levee was constructed around Elba in the 1930s by the Works Progress Administration after a record flood engulfed the town of 4,400 in 1929. ``Levees are built based on historical flood data,'' said Fuller. ``This storm exceeded the capacity that was built into the design. This was built for the '29 flood.'' Bonine was not sure when the levee last was inspected or if it met the standards of a Corps-built structure. Fuller said engineering teams would be brought in to inspect it.
