DOC.HEAD: Baptist Church Collapses, Injures Two
DOC.TEXT: A storefront church collapsed Sunday afternoon, trapping an 84-year-old Baptist minister and a female worshiper under a pile of rubble, authorities said. The Rev. Romey L. Barber, his wife and two female parishoners were leaving the Southern Tabernacle Missionary Baptist Church about 1:20 p.m. when the three-story building collapsed forward onto them, according to Fire Department supervisor Stephen Imszennik. The pastor and 53-year-old Jean Tucker were trapped for a half hour, authorities said. Barber suffered multiple fractures and was in serious condition at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital, while Ms. Tucker was in guarded condition at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, spokeswomen said. The building appeared to have been ``structurally defective in some way,'' Imszennik said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Guild Approves Agreement With Post-Dispatch
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper Guild members Sunday overwhelmingly approved a three-year contract with the St. Louis Post-Dispatch and called off a byline strike that began 12 days ago. Members of Guild Local 47, who've been working without a contract since the old one expired Feb. 28, voted 365 to 69 for the new pact, which is to be signed Monday. The 630-member local, the largest of the 11 unions at the newspaper, represents reporters, some editors, photographers, adverstising sales personnel, business workers and clerks. Reporters and photographers had withheld bylines and photo credits since March 7 to protest an earlier, tougher contract offer from the company. ``We're pleased that two-thirds of all unionized employees at the Post-Dispatch have negotiated new contracts,'' newspaper Publisher Nicholas G. Penniman IV said following Sunday's vote. The Guild was the sixth union to reach an agreement with the Post-Dispatch. Five remain without a contract. The contract calls for a 4 percent pay raise each year, a drug-testing policy, a clause prohibiting strikes or lockouts, and a $600 contract-signing bonus for each member, payable by April 13. It also calls for 21 employees to be exempted from Guild jurisdiction, instead of the 26 exemptions the company asked for last week. The contract gives the paper the right to hire free-lancers to cover some news events and to hire advertising salespeople to sell ads on a commission-only basis for the paper's zoned editions. Herbert Goodrick, executive secretary of Guild Local 47, said members who supported the contract ``recognized that it's not an ideal contract, but we feel, given the alternative, that we can live with the agreement.''

DOC.HEAD: Some ANC Leaders Willing to Meet With Baker in South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Desmond Tutu and some African National Congress leaders said Sunday they will meet Secretary of State James Baker III when he visits South Africa this week, even though ANC leader Nelson Mandela criticized the trip. ``If the secretary of state wants to see me, of course I'll see him. But I will not meet him in South Africa,'' Mandela said Saturday after returning from a five-nation tour. During his trip, he called on foreign governments to cut all diplomatic ties with the Pretoria government. Baker, who flies to neighboring Namibia on Monday, has invited Mandela to a meeting there. Both men will be attending celebrations of the South African colony's independence. Mandela has indicated he will accept that invitation. The U.S. official then intends to fly to Cape Town on Thursday to meet with President F.W. de Klerk and black leaders. ``We do not want any high-profile visits to South Africa because these can result in a lot of confusion,'' Mandela said Saturday. ``They suggest that President de Klerk has done something positive, something fundamental which requires the world to review sanctions and other strategies, which we have invited in order to increase pressure on South Africa.'' De Klerk freed Mandela last month after he served 27 years in prison for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white government. The president also legalized the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups. Walter Sisulu, a member of the ANC's national executive and a close friend of Mandela, said Sunday night he had received an invitation to meet Baker in Soweto, outside Johannesburg, but would be unable to accept it because he will be in London. However, he said ANC leaders Govan Mbeki and Raymond Mhlaba, who were imprisoned with Mandela for plotting to overthrow the government, will meet with the secretary of state. Asked to explain why ANC leaders would meet with Baker inside the country after Mandela's comments, Sisulu said the issue had not thoroughly been discussed earlier. In any case, he said, Mandela's meetings are considered different from those of the other black leaders. Tutu, the Anglican archbishop of Cape Town who won the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, said he expected to meet Baker, probably in Cape Town, although the meeting hadn't been confirmed. Regarding Mandela's statement, Tutu said: ``I appreciate the necessity for political leaders to keep foreign governments under pressure to take a firm stand against apartheid.'' By law and custom, apartheid establishes a racially segregated society in which the 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs. The 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate districts, schools and health services.

DOC.HEAD: Network Says Hardliners Win Struggle; Means No Early Hostage Release
DOC.NOTE: EDS: inserts graf 5, ``Spokeswoman Alixe Glen xxx with no comment
DOC.TEXT: Efforts by moderate officials in Iran to push for the release of hostages being held in the Mideast have been derailed by hardliners opposed to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, ABC News said Sunday night. In a report from Paris attributed to sources within the Hezbollah movement in Lebanon, Pierre Salinger reported that leaders of groups holding hostages in Lebanon were summoned to Tehran for meetings last week. ``There, the current plan to release the hostages was sabotaged by Iranian hardliners opposed to Rafsanjani,'' Salinger reported. ``The hostage leaders returned to Lebanon three days ago and one of the organizations, Islamic Jihad, issued a statement saying the hostages wouldn't be released,'' he said. ``This position was confirmed at a secret meeting in Lebanon 48 hours ago.'' Spokeswoman Alixe Glen said there would be no White House reaction to the report Sunday night. There had been several weeks of hints that the hostage issue might be moving toward a solution until March 15 when Islamic Jihad's threatened to kill three captive American educators unless its demands were met regarding Jewish immigration from the Soviet Union. The demands were not spelled out. The Tehran Times newspaper in Iran, which has close ties to Rafsanjani, said in recent editorials that the hostages should be freed on humanitarian grounds. Rafsanjani himself said he thought the issue was moving toward a solution. Also, Sheikh Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah, spiritual guide of Hezbollah, said last month in a sermon that a humanitarian means of freeing the hostages must be found.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Alliance Wins in First East German Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD parties that make up the Alliance for Germany, SUB grafs 4-5; pickup 6th graf pvs, `The final...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XBER3, 11, 12, 13, 17, 29, 35, 37
DOC.TEXT: An alliance of conservative parties favoring quick unification and backed by the Bonn government scored a powerful victory in East Germany's first free elections Sunday, according to official returns. However, the Alliance for Germany fell short of winning a majority in the new 400-member Parliament. The elections marked the first free balloting in East Germany's 41-year history and capped the transition to democracy since the fall revolution that ended one-party Communist rule. The results will help set the pace of unification, which only became possible following the democratic changes across Eastern Europe last year. Since then, many East Germans have clamored for unification with prosperous West Germany as a way to a better life, and the election results seemed to reflect that widespread sentiment. The Alliance for Germany defeated the leftist-leaning Social Democrats, who only a few weeks ago were considered the front-runners. The alliance _ made up of the Christian Democrats, the German Social Union and Democratic Awakening _ received strong support from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's governing party. The final official returns, announced early Monday by election commission chairwoman Petra Blaess, gave the alliance 48 percent of the popular vote and 193 seats in the parliament. The Christian Democrats, who led the alliance, alone gained 41 percent of the vote for 164 seats. The Social Democrats received 22 percent and 87 seats. The reformed Communists finished as the third-strongest individual party with 16 percent and 65 seats. The conservative alliance could gain the extra margin for a majority from the centrist Liberal alliance, which won 21 seats. A variety of other parties won the remaining spots. There were 24 parties or organizations competing for seats in the parliament, which is to hold office for a four-year term. Commentators in East Germany and West Germany agreed Kohl played a key role in helping the conservatives win by promising quick replacement of East Germany's nearly worthless currency with the West German mark and other financial benefits. Kohl also campaigned extensively on behalf of the alliance. ``It was a victory for Kohl,'' West Germany's ARD television network said. ``I just want to celebrate,'' Lothar de Maiziere, head of the Christian Democrats, said at his party's headquarters. He was viewed as the top contender to become East Germany's first democratically elected premier. After the voting, he said a ``grand coalition'' with the Social Democrats and other parties was possible to lead the country toward unification with the greatest possible popular support. He said a broad coalition also was needed to muster the two-thirds parliamentary majority necessary to change East Germany's constitution and pave the way for quick reunification. With such a majority, the East German parliament could simply declare a merger with West Germany. De Maiziere also promised his party would strive for quick economic, monetary and social union with West Germany. Kohl also voiced support for a broad coalition. ``The German citizens have decided against every form of extremism,'' he said at a news conference in Bonn, the West German capital. ``Most important, they want to follow a path, together with West Germany, that will lead to unification.'' Gregor Gysi, chairman of the reformed Communist party, immediately offered support to the Social Democrats to prevent the conservatives from gaining a two-thirds parliamentary majority. The current caretaker government is led by a Communist, Hans Modrow. He and Gysi had proved surprisingly popular during the campaign as they tried to shed their party's hard-line image. The election came five months to the day after hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker was toppled in the country's peaceful revolution. A roaring crowd of 2,000 supporters jammed the conservative alliance's headquarters late Sunday, waving party banners and West German flags and drinking and dancing. ``As quickly as possible, unification!'' Dieter Schloder said. ``There is no question about it.'' In Washington, the White House saluted the election. ``We have long supported the aspirations of the people of East Germany to decide their own future through a freely elected parliament and government,'' said White House deputy press secretary Alixe Glen. Virtually all the parties favored unification with West Germany, but at different paces. About 12.2 million people were eligible to vote, and some districts reported 80 percent turnout by midday. People lined up at polling stations in cities as well as makeshift voting booths in rural pubs and eateries. Some people cast ballots from hospital beds. ``This is the greatest day of my life after being put down all these years,'' whispered 66-year-old Annelisa Schoen, choking back tears of joy as she voted in East Berlin. Some voters seemed a bit perplexed by the huge selection that included such contenders as the Beer Drinker's Party. ``We have nothing we can draw from, no experience with the new parties that we can use as a measure. There's no way we can know if we are voting for the right person,'' said Christel Wilke, a poll supervisor in Schoenwalde, 18 miles north of Berlin. The elections were the result of a peaceful revolution that was touched off by an exodus of East Germans to the West. The nationwide movement ousted Honecker on Oct. 18, led to the opening of the Berlin Wall in November and other once-sealed borders, and ended the Communists' guaranteed monopoly on power. Honecker and many of his former associates now are accused of abuse of power while in office and face trial, but even they were allowed to vote, East Germany's official ADN news agency said. The new government will take part in unification talks with West Germany and the four World War II allies _ Britain, France, the Soviet Union, and the United States. A major issue is the military strength and alignment of a unified Germany. The Western powers want what is now West Germany to remain part of the NATO military alliance. The Soviets and East German Communists have called for a neutral single state. Just when the new government will take office was unclear. The election campaign was bitter. The election originally was scheduled for May, but it was moved up because of fears that Modrow's interim leadership would collapse. There were claims that former secret police agents would use false sets of identity cards to vote several times and boost the Communists' chances. No irregularities were reported, however. The Communists tried hard to remove the taint of the Honecker leadership, even changing their name to the Party of Democratic Socialism. But the memories of years of repression were not easily erased. Despite reforms, thousands of East Germans have continued to leave their homeland for West Germany. As one way to stem the flood, Kohl and the Alliance for Germany support making the powerful West German mark East Germany's currency as well. De Maiziere reitered this desire Sunday night. ``The most important thing now is that people don't continue to leave,'' he said. At his news conference in Bonn, Kohl agreed. ``My message at this hour is: Stay home,'' he said. ``Work with us in your villages, cities and communities, in your factories and in your local administrations to build up this beautiful country.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan Releases Its First Satellite Into Lunar Orbit
DOC.TEXT: Japan's first lunar probe launched a smaller satellite into orbit around the moon early Monday, a government space official said. The probe, called the Muses-A satellite, is circling the Earth in a highly elliptical orbit that brought it within 10,213 miles of the moon, said Yasunori Matogawa, spokesman for the government-funded Institute of Space and Astronautical Science. Shortly before the 400-pound probe crossed the moon's path during its swing-by, it released a second, smaller satellite that was driven into lunar orbit by a ``kick motor,'' he said. Matogawa said the procedure went as planned. The smaller satellite will move in an orbit ranging from 12,400 to 43,400 miles from the moon. The mission will give Japan valuable experience in targeting orbits and in the use of swing-bys for future spacecraft traveling to distant planets. The Muses-A will pass the moon eight or nine more times during the next year it is expected to remain in orbit. As the Muses-A crossed the moon's path, observation equipment aboard the probe photographed the moon, but the images were not very clear because of the satellite's relatively long distance from the moon, Matogawa said. There is no observation equipment on the smaller satellite. Both the Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, which is conducting the mission, and Japan's other space agency, the National Space Development Agency, have plans for manned space flights and interplanetary travel. The satellite, launched in January from Uchinoura Space Center in southern Japan, is a symbolic step forward in Japan's budding space program. Until now, only the United States and the Soviet Union have sent missions to the moon.

DOC.HEAD: Pipeline Explosion Kills 13 in Iranian Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with cause of blast, other details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A gas pipeline exploded in western Tehran on Sunday and started a huge fire, killing 13 people and injuring scores more, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the pipeline blew up at 11:30 a.m. on a major thoroughfare, igniting a ``massive fire.'' It took firefighters 90 minutes to douse the blaze, IRNA said. It said a fleet of ambulances took the casualties to hospitals in the capital. At least 10 cars were destroyed and 15 buildings badly damaged by the explosion, the agency reported. The explosion left a large crater, it said. State-run Tehran radio quoted an unidentified official in charge of emergency operations as saying engineers had been connecting a safety valve to the pipeline at the time of the blast. ``According to the reports I have received, their carelessness led to big escape of gas, and a spark set it ablaze,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: There will be no add.
DOC.TEXT: East Germans voted in their first free elections Sunday for a parliament that will steer the country toward unification with West Germany. Early projections predicted a landslide victory for a conservative alliance favoring quick unification. West Germany's ZDF television network said the three-party Alliance for Germany would get 53 percent of the vote. The leftist-leaning Social Democrats, who campaigned for a more cautious approach to unification, had 21 percent, it said. The projections were based on exit polls. The Communists, who lost their 40-year monopoly on power in the fall revolution, were projected to win 14 percent to 15 percent of the vote. They had fared badly in pre-election polls, despite the popularity of Communist Premier Hans Modrow and intensive efforts to shed their hard-line image. Only a few weeks ago, the Social Democrats were considered the strongest contenders. But the Alliance for Germany got massive campaign help from West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

Soviet military jets repeatedly streaked over the capital of Lithuania during military maneuvers Sunday, one day before a Moscow deadline demanding that the Baltic republic renounce its declaration of independence. At the same time, however, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev struck a conciliatory tone, saying he still plans to talk with the Lithuanians about returning to the Soviet fold. And he said there have been no ultimatums. ``We will carry on conversations,'' Gorbachev told reporters after voting in runoff elections. He continued to insist that Lithuania's March 11 declaration was illegal and must be decided by the entire Soviet Union, not just the republic. He said he would work for a new federation agreement that would satisfy everyone.

Disagreement inside the Bush administration over the possibility that drastic changes in the Soviet Union will be reversed is raising new questions about the size of the U.S. defense budget. While CIA Director William Webster testified earlier this month the political changes in the Soviet Bloc are irreversible, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has maintained that Moscow could reassume its former confrontational pose. Treasury Secretary Nicholas S. Brady said Sunday that the administration is still sticking with Cheney's proposed $3.2 billion cut in inflation-adjusted defense spending for fiscal 1991 beginning next Oct. 1. ``Three billion dollars is it; that's what Secretary Cheney says; that's what it is,'' Brady said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation'' program. ``That's our position at this point in time.''

Talks between Greyhound and its striking drivers abruptly broke down Sunday when company officials accused union leaders of failing to negotiate and committing new violence. ``The union is stonewalling on the contract,'' Greyhound executive vice president Anthony Lannie said in a statement. ``They had nothing new for us today (Sunday) or yesterday while stepping up the violence.'' Lannie charged that violence continued Saturday even while the two sides were meeting for the first time since 6,300 drivers and an estimated 3,000 other Greyhound workers walked out March 2 over wages, job security and grievance procedures. In Washington, Jeffrey Nelson, a spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, called Lannie's statement ``the desperate words from a desperate man. We clearly condemn violence and anything we can do to discourage our members we are doing so.''

DOC.HEAD: Roger and Who: Speculation Grows Over Soon-to-be Vacated GM Driver Seat
LaserPhotos DT1 and DT2 of March 15
DOC.TEXT: When General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger B. Smith retires in July, many industry analysts and company stockholders expect his replacement to be more familiar with load-bearing shocks than no-load funds. After a troubled decade of direction under a bean counter who never worked in a prototype design studio, rumblings are increasing both in and out of the auto giant for a car guy to take control. Smith, who will cap a 41-year career with GM, has been harshly criticized for paying excessive heed to profits and too little attention to products during his tenure as chairman. The image of an accountant who never really understood the car business has dogged Smith for a long time. His most recent brush with bad publicity is the acclaimed documentary film ``Roger & Me,'' which chronicles the devastation caused by GM plant closings and layoffs around Flint, Mich., birthplace of the corporation in 1908. As GM's chairman since New Year's Day 1981, Smith also has made the tough decisions, like reducing hourly and salaried work forces to maintain the company's profitability. When he officially steps down July 31, it will be 19 days after his 65th birthday, the age of mandatory retirement from one of the world's largest manufacturers. Well before then, the board of directors probably will designate the next occupant of the 14th floor corner office of the General Motors Building. That almost certainly will occur by the company's annual meeting in mid-to-late May. It may be as soon as the next regular board meeting April 2. The competition is focused on five men _ GM's president and four executive vice presidents. The new chief executive will face many problems, including a decaying share of the U.S. car and truck market, ferocious competition from Japan and streamlining the corporation, which employs about 750,000 people worldwide. Tens of thousands of other people employed by other companies directly rely on GM for their jobs as well. ``The investors that I speak to express the preference of an operations guy rather than a finance guy,'' said auto analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan Stanley & Co. of New York. Smith began his GM career as a general accounting senior clerk in Detroit and rose through the financial side. At Ford Motor Co., Chairman Harold Poling came up in finance but has considerable product experience. Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca's background is primarily product-oriented. ``You would think that with GM's slide in market share, you would have to assume that it's product-related,'' said auto analyst Joshua Harari of Standard & Poors Corp. in New York. ``They've modernized their plants, they've been successful in Europe and in the truck market in the United States, so a product guy in the car market might help.'' GM's U.S. car and truck market share has dropped from 44.1 percent at the end of 1980, the day before Smith became chairman, to 34.6 percent at the end of last year. The market share GM lost went principally to the Japanese, on the strength of their U.S. assembly plants, and to GM domestic rival Ford. Also during Smith's reign, GM embarked on an aggressive plant modernization program, spending billions of dollars in new equipment and methods of building distinctly different cars and trucks. In the mid-1980s, and continuing to a lesser extent today, GM was criticized for making cars for divisions that looked basically the same. The hybrid names ``Oldsmobuick'' and ``Chevymobile'' still pop up from time to time. As GM's market share slid, so did profits. By the end of 1986, the much-smaller Ford was out-earning GM. Ford's profit dominance of GM continued for the next two years. GM regained the profit lead last year. Smith began a cost-cutting plan in 1987 and has vowed to lop more than $12 billion off the company's expenses. Profits have been propped up by the sales of GM's European-made cars, Vauxhall and Opel, which enjoyed critical and commercial success. ``Whatever management did successfully in Europe should be duplicated'' in the United States, Harari said. ``I don't know if it's so much pulling in the people or the techniques used in Europe.'' All of it has led to a lot of speculation about who's next. Large institutional stockholders, including the California Public Employees Retirement System and the New York State and Local Retirement System, expressed intense interest in the search process but were rebuffed by GM in written pleas for briefings. GM says the search process and who's doing it is a private function of the board. A team drawn from the 14 outside directors is conducting the search. Most short lists of likely chairmen include GM President and Chief Operating Officer Robert C. Stempel, Executive Vice President F. Alan Smith of the Operating and Public Affairs Staffs Groups and Executive Vice President John F. Smith Jr., who directs GM's international operations. Also mentioned are Executive Vice President William E. Hoglund of the automotive components group and Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer Robert T. O'Connell. ``From here, it still looks like Stempel to me,'' independent auto analyst David Healy said. ``Then there are a bunch of guys named Smith.''

DOC.HEAD: Bus Boss Says Strike Won't Deter Him
With AM-Greyhound Strike
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound buses have traversed America's landscape since 1914, when a Swedish immigrant paid $600 for a fancy Hupmobile to haul miners from Hibbing, Minn., to a saloon 10 miles away in Alice. In the 76 years since, the company has changed owners several times and evolved into the only nationwide bus company, blessed with widespread recognition but troubled by high costs, low profitability and labor unrest. Its current owner says the latest strike, the second walkout in seven years, may delay but won't stop the company's rebound. ``We were rebuilding what had become a very weak resource,'' said Chairman Fred Currey. ``We were right on track and this is an interruption of that rebuilding process, there's no doubt about that.'' The drivers union struck March 2 and Greyhound has been operating at reduced levels since, using permanent replacements and nonstrikers. Currey led the investor group that bought the bus company from Phoenix-based Greyhound Corp. for $270 million in 1987. Four months later, he bought Trailways Lines Inc. for $80 million and merged the two under the Greyhound label. He has made the combined company a personal campaign, traveling the country appealing directly to employees to help restore Greyhound. In some meetings, he emphasizes teamwork by having employees stand arm-in-arm. ``Middle income and lower income people in this country don't have any other intercity transportation and I can take great satisfaction in being part of an organization that fulfills that need,'' Currey said in an interview. The strike has not altered Currey's personal approach. The first day, he left his Dallas skyscraper office and walked to the bus terminal nearby where a few drivers were picketing, some carrying ``Drop Dead Fred'' signs. ``They're good people,'' Currey said, ``although few of them understood our contract proposal, and I must say I'm fearful they do not understand what a permanent replacement means.'' He has returned to the Dallas picket line at least once and last Monday rushed to Jacksonville, Fla., where eight people were injured in a sniper attack on a bus. Currey worked the terminal crowd, thanking people for traveling Greyhound and hopping a bus himself for a ride to Orlando. ``I took the trip because I thought it was important for Greyhound people not to be intimidated,'' he said. What is now Greyhound Lines Inc. traces its ancestry to Carl Eric Wickman, a Swedish immigrant who in 1913 bought the Hibbing, Minn., Hupmobile dealership. After he couldn't sell a particularly well-appointed, eight-passenger Hupmobile _ complete with copper-clad headlights and brass radiator cap and crank handle _ he bought it himself for $600 and began charging iron ore miners 15 cents for a one-way, 10-mile trip between the Hibbing firehouse and a saloon in Alice. A round trip cost a quarter. Wickman sold and then repurchased the company, eventually moving it to Duluth and later Chicago as a network of regional bus companies came under the Greyhound umbrella. For a time in the '50 and '60s, the company's mascot was a purebred greyhound, wearing a jeweled tiara and named ``Lady Greyhound.'' By the time it moved from Chicago to Phoenix in 1971, the company had been condensed into one system as Greyhound Corp., a manufacturing and financial conglomerate. Greyhound officials point to 1983 as the beginning of the bus system's decline because the bus industry was deregulated and the company went through a bitter, 47-day drivers' strike. Four years later, when Currey and others bought the company, he won an agreement from the union for a 22 percent wage cut. ``These were the most unusual labor discussions I have participated in because Currey, rather than coming to the table to see how much he could squeeze from the employees, came to ask the employees to work with him in rebuilding the company and to share the benefits of the results,'' said Domenic Sirignano, union president at that time. Now, the words have changed. ``The company's recent contract offers have demonstrated once again that the reward Greyhound had in mind for its employees amounted to millions for management and pennies for the people who drive and maintain the buses and for the office workers who ensure the efficient operation of the Greyhound system,'' said James La Sala, international president of the Amalgamated Transit Union. Some critics claim the current strike is union-busting, a charge Currey denies. His aides say Currey's respect for organized labor was evident in the contract he signed with the union before buying the company. ``He had the option of starting all over with a clean piece of paper and a totally new work force,'' said company spokesman George Gravley. ``If we were a union-busting company, what better chance would we have?'' Greyhound lost $20 million its first two years and made a $730,000 profit on last year's $1 billion in revenue. Executives say the company cannot afford more than the $63 million, three-year pact it has offered. The union says its latest offer would cost less that management's, but Greyhound values it at more than $200 million over the life of the contract. Greyhound drivers were paid an average $24,743 last year. Currey says Greyhound will be back at full operation by the end of the month, but the money spent to withstand the strike threatens a $100 million capital improvement program. ``That is what is most disturbing to me,'' Currey said.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Stockholders Demand Meeting With Chairman
DOC.TEXT: A group of Exxon Corp. shareholders, claiming the oil company's environmental problems have threatened the value of their holdings, are demanding a meeting with the company's chairman to explain Exxon's recent accidents and plans for avoiding them in the future. In a letter dated Friday, managers of pension funds from California, New York and Massachusetts, which own more than 14 million shares of Exxon stock, called on Exxon Chairman Lawrence G. Rawl to discuss the string of accidents that have wreaked environmental havoc from Alaska to New York. The group said it wants the nation's largest oil company to disclose its plans for implementing environmental safety systems and improving its environmental record. ``We want to emphasize the importance of holding this meeting as soon as possible,'' said the letter signed by Gray Davis, California state comptroller and manager of the nation's largest public pension fund; Elizabeth Holtzman, New York City comptroller and manager of its employee pension fund; and Paul Quirk, executive director of Massachusetts' pension fund board. ``In addition to the environmental damage ... Exxon is creating enormous potential financial liabilities that may harm the economic performance of the corporation. These problems are beginning to harm the financial health of Exxon,'' the letter said. Exxon officials could not be reached by telephone for comment Sunday. The March 24 wreck of the Exxon Valdez in Alaska has so far cost the company nearly $3 billion in clean-up expenses. Exxon set aside $1.3 billion last year, but the letter noted, ``this estimate does not include the potential effects of litigation.'' More than 170 civil suits are pending against Exxon by fishermen and others who claim they suffered losses because of the Alaska spill. And last month's federal indictment of Exxon on charges related to the spill could result in huge fines against the oil company. Two spills in New York and New Jersey waterways since January have further sullied the company's reputation and generated more lawsuits, including suits by the states of New York and New Jersey. Shareholders also are concerned that Exxon's recent problems have undermined the value of its stock, Ms. Holtzman said in a telephone interview. ``When investment houses are not recommending the purchase of Exxon stock, then we are concerned about the effect on our portfolio,'' she said. Ms. Holtzman said the pension funds cannot get rid of their shares because it would drive down the price of the stock. Together, the three pension funds own slightly more than 1 percent of Exxon's 1.3 billion outstanding shares. ``We can't sell our stock overnight; we're in for the long haul,'' she said. In New York Stock Exchange composite trading Friday, Exxon stock closed at $47.50, up 62{ cents. The stock has been largely flat in the year since the spill; it traded in the $45 range at the time of the accident. The latest posturing by Exxon shareholders comes about five weeks before the company's April 25 annual meeting in Houston, which could be a repeat of 1989's spirited gathering. Unlike last year, however, shareholders will get the opportunity to vote on environmental resolutions that could affect the company. Last year's meeting was held soon after the Alaska spill and shareholders did not have time to submit such resolutions. Six shareholder proposals on environmental issues have been cleared by the Securities and Exchange Commission for inclusion in Exxon's proxy statement this year. The company opposes all six proposals, which among other things call for Exxon to ``take leadership in dealing with (the) damage'' caused by its Alaska spill. Another resolution calls for an environmental report card based on the Valdez Principles, a set of guidelines formulated by environmentalists calling for conservation, restoration of damaged environments, reduction of wastes and other moves to protect the environment. The resolutions are not expected to pass since Exxon stock is so widely held and no single shareholder _ individual or group _ owns as much as 2 percent of the company's outstanding shares. But the stockholders who initiated the proposals hope they will increase pressure on Exxon to become more environmentally sensitive.

DOC.HEAD: Despite OPEC Agreement, Oil Prices Likely to Slide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: REWRITES throughout to UPDATE with analyst comments.
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices will likely slide further in the weeks ahead despite OPEC's fresh call for restraints on crude production, analysts said Sunday. ``Prices are going to come under a lot of pressure,'' predicted Peter Gignoux, director of the international energy department of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in London. Peter Bogin, associate director for oil markets at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris, predicted a gradual slowdown in prices before a key OPEC pricing meeting in late May. However, the softening of oil prices will likely have little impact on gasoline prices at the pump. Ministers of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, hoping to keep the target price of oil at $18 a barrel, wound up a special committee meeting late Saturday by urging caution during the second quarter. Demand for crude normally slumps in the April-June period when spring arrives in the United States and other consuming nations. As a result, Bogin said, prices could drop as much as $1.70 a barrel in the weeks ahead. The average price of a basket of crudes monitored by the cartel unexpectedly soared to $20.56 a barrel in early January but has since fallen, reaching $17.91 last week. West Texas Intermediate, the key American grade, has been trading between $20 and $21 a barrel. Every dollar decline _ or rise _ in the price of a barrel of oil amounts to about a 5 cent change in gasoline prices. But even if gasoline prices slipped in the second quarter, they likely would firm in the summer months when demand increases again. Gasoline accounts for the bulk of petroleum used in the United States. OPEC is estimated to be producing as much as 24 million barrels of oil a day, exceeding its output cap of about 22 million barrels for the January-June period. OPEC Secretary-General Subroto said internal estimates forecast demand of 20.8 million barrels a day in the second quarter. To try to halt price erosion, the ministers renewed their determination to abide by their individual supply limits. To do so, some would have to turn off the taps. ``We expect that we will withdraw some quantities from the market during the (coming) months,'' said Algerian Oil Minister Sadek Boussena. But analysts were skeptical that chronic cheaters Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates would limit production to meet their quotas. ``We don't think Kuwait will cut back unless there is an intense weakening in prices,'' said Bogin. Kuwait, analysts estimate, is producing at least 1.7 million barrels a day, compared with a quota of 1.5 million barrels a day. Kuwaiti Oil Minister Ali Khalifa al-Sabah has said his country does not feel bound by its cap when prices remain at $18. Gignoux, the Shearson analyst, said the United Arab Emirates was unlikely to reduce production. The emirates, which have not accepted its quota of about a million barrels a day, has been pumping double that, analysts say. Much of the ministers' closed-door talks were in preparation for the May meeting when they will set pricing and output guidelines for the last half of the year. The ministers opened the monitoring committee meeting Friday evening and then met informally on Saturday. Only eight nations technically belong to the panel, but all OPEC members were represented. OPEC's members are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.
